(2) All licenses pursuant to this division shall be a mere grant of privilege to carry on the business during the term of the license, subject to all terms and conditions imposed by this division and state law. (3) Any holder of a license issued in accord with this division is required to apply for and obtain an alcoholic beverage license from the State of Georgia before any sales commence. Additionally, any holder of a license issued in accord with this division is required to abide by all applicable state regulations and laws. (4) All licenses issued under this chapter shall have printed on the face the following words: THIS LICENSE IS A PRIVILEGE CONDITIONAL ON THE HOLDER MEETING ALL STANDARDS FOR SUCH LICENSE AND OPERATING REGULATIONS APPLICABLE THERETO SET OUT IN CITY ORDINANCES AND GEORGIA LAW. FAILURE TO MEET SUCH STANDARDS OR TO COMPLY WITH SUCH OPERATING REGULATIONS SHALL SUBJECT THE HOLDER OF THE LICENSE TO HAVE THE LICENSE REVOKED FOLLOWING NOTICE AND HEARING. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 2, 7-12-2010) Sec. 4-103. - Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed in this section, except if the context clearly indicates a different meaning, to-wit: (1) Alcohol means malt beverage and wine. (2) Beer or malt beverage means any alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of any infusion or decoction of barley, malt, hops or any other similar product, or any combination of such products in water containing not more than fourteen (14) percent alcohol by volume and including, but not limited to, ale, porter, brown, stout, lager beer, small beer, and strong beer. The term does not include sake, known as Japanese rice wine. (3) Eating establishment means any public place, including a place available for rental by the public, selling prepared food for consumption by the public on the premises with a full service kitchen. A full service kitchen shall consist of a three-compartment pot sink, a stove or grill permanently installed, and refrigerator, all of which must be approved by the health and fire departments. An eating establishment shall be prepared to serve food every hour the establishment is open and shall derive at least seventy (70) percent of the gross receipts annually from the sale of prepared meals or food. (4) Hotel/motel means any building or other structure providing sleeping accommodations for hire to the general public, either transient, permanent or residential. Such businesses shall have one (1) or more public dining rooms with a full service kitchen, as that term is defined in subsection (3) of this section. Hotels/motels shall have the privilege of granting franchises for the operation of any licensed establishment described in this division, and the holder of such franchise shall be included in the definition of a hotel/motel pursuant to this definition. (5) Licensee means the person to whom a license for the sale or distribution of malt beverages or wine is issued under this division. In the case of a partnership or corporation, all partners, officers, and directors of the partnership or corporation are licensees. A license issued under this division permits the licensee to sell malt beverages and/or wine for beverage purposes by the drink for consumption only on the premises where sold. (6) Person means any individual, firm, partnership, cooperative, nonprofit membership corporation, joint venture, association, company, corporation, agency, syndicate, estate, trust, business trust, receiver, fiduciary, or other group or combination acting as a unit, body politic, or political subdivision, whether public, private, or quasi public. (7) Premises means one (1) room or more all contiguous in nature operating under the same trade name. (8) Retail consumption dealer means any person who sells malt beverages or wine for consumption on the premises, at retail, only to consumers and not for resale. (9) Wine means any alcoholic beverage containing not more than twenty-four (24) percent alcohol made from fruits, berries, or grapes either by natural fermentation or by natural fermentation with brandy added. Wine includes, but is not limited to, all sparkling wines, champagnes, combinations of such beverages, vermouths, special natural wines, rectified wines, and like products. The term "wine" does not include cooking wine mixed with salt or other ingredients so as to render it unfit for human consumption as a beverage. A liquid shall first be deemed to be a wine at the point in the manufacturing process when it conforms to the definition of wine contained in this section. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 3, 7-12-2010; Ord. No. 16-01, § 1, 2-8-2016) Sec. 4-104. - Licenses, generally. All licenses issued under this division shall: (1) Permit the licensee to sell the beverage or beverages for which the license is issued solely within the City of LaFayette, Georgia, pursuant to the terms of this division and consistent with the laws of the State of Georgia and the United States; (2) Expire on December 31 of each year and an application for renewal shall be made and filed annually on or before October 31 of each year. Any licensee must annually meet the requirements set forth by the city in order to obtain a renewal of any license. Any licensee making proper application with supporting documents for a license to operate during the following calendar year, and having filed such application before October 31, shall be permitted to continue to operate pending final approval of the licensee's application for the following year if final approval is not granted before January 1; (3) Not be transferred from one (1) person to another or from one (1) location to another; and (4) Permit the licensee to sell malt beverages or wine or combination thereof, depending upon the license issued, for beverage purposes by the drink for consumption only on the premises where sold. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 4, 7-12-2010) Sec. 4-105. - Types of licenses to be issued. Only the following licenses shall be issued under this division: (1) Malt beverages by the drink for consumption on the premises; (2) Wine by the drink for consumption on the premises; and (3) Malt beverages and wine by the drink for consumption on the premises. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 5, 7-12-2010) Sec. 4-106. - Sale or possession for sale without license or beyond boundaries of premises covered by license, penalties. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or possess for the purpose of sale any malt beverage or wine if the person does not have a license granted by the city to sell or possess for sale malt beverage or wine or to make deliveries beyond the boundaries of the premises covered by the license. Violations of this section shall be dealt with pursuant to section 4-107 hereof. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 6, 7-12-2010) Sec. 4-107. - Penalties for violation of division. Any violation of the provisions of this division may upon determination of violation result in suspension or revocation of a license issued pursuant to this division; or the mayor and council may in lieu of suspension or revocation thereof impose a civil penalty of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 7, 7-12-2010) Sec. 4-108. - Type of retail establishment where permitted. (a) No malt beverage or wine shall be sold for consumption on the premises where sold except in areas zoned either B-1 or B-2 and which are being used as one of the following: (1) An eating establishment, as that term is defined in section 4-103(3) hereof. When eating establishments are located in hotels or motels, every entrance to the establishment shall be from a public lobby, hallway, mall or other publicly used interior portion of the primary use structure; or (2) An indoor nonprofit civic and cultural center qualified under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code capable of serving prepared food, with a full service kitchen, as that term is defined in section 4-103(3); prepared to serve food every hour they are open and deriving at least seventy (70) percent of its total annual gross sales from the sale of prepared meals or foods and recreation activities. These eating establishments must be located in a zoning district which permits restaurants as conforming uses or where these eating establishments are incidental to a hotel or motel. (b) Prohibited location. No license will be issued for the retail sale of malt beverages and/or wine for consumption on the premise within the following areas in the city: (1) Within three hundred (300) feet of any church building or alcohol treatment center measured in a straight line, from the nearest "building" corner of any of these buildings to the nearest corner of the building in which the outlet or proposed outlet is to be operated. The word "building" shall mean a structure used at the time of filing of the application for license for the purposes of church, hospital or rest home. Additionally, for the purpose of this division, a church is defined as an organization for the purpose of preaching the gospel and other related religious activities located within a permanent structure either owned or leased by such organization or which is used by such organization with the permission of the owner on a regular basis for such purpose. Such organization must either consist of at least twenty-five (25) adult members on its official rolls that meet on a regularly scheduled basis not less than one (1) time per week with an average attendance of not less than twenty-five (25) people of such organization, must be duly recognized and affiliated with a parent religious denomination and be either chartered, recognized or approved by such parent religious denomination. Such organization must also qualify under the rules of Internal Revenue Service as an organization to which contributions may be deducted for federal income tax purposes. (2) Within three hundred (300) feet, measured in a straight line, from the nearest property line of any school or schoolhouse to the nearest corner of the building in which the outlet or proposed outlet is to be operated. (3) Within three hundred (300) feet, measured in a straight line, from the nearest property line of any city recreation area to the nearest corner of the building in which the outlet or proposed outlet is to be operated. (4) Within three hundred (300) feet, measured in a straight line, from the nearest property line of any housing authority property to the nearest corner of the building in which the outlet or proposed outlet is to be operated. (5) In any existing building or establishment having a history of or reputation for prostitution or other sex offenses; fighting, shooting, stabbing or other violence; gambling; illegal dealing in alcoholic beverages or drugs; or other violations of the law. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 8, 7-12-2010; Ord. No. 12-04, § 3, 9-10-2012) Sec. 4-109. - Separate application and separate license for each location of sale. Separate applications must be made for each location and separate licenses must be issued for each location. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 9, 7-12-2010) Sec. 4-110. - License fee. (a) The fees for licenses issued pursuant to this division are as follows: (1) Retail dealer of malt beverage to be consumed on the premises five hundred dollars ($500.00) per calendar year; (2) Retail dealer of wine to be consumed on the premises five hundred dollars ($500.00) per calendar year; (3) Retail dealer of malt beverage and wine to be consumed on the premises one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per calendar year. The license fee shall not be prorated based upon the day of the year that the license is issued. (b) Each application for a license under this division shall be accompanied by a certified check for the full amount of the appropriate license fee, together with a separate check or cash in the amount of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) to defray investigative and administrative costs. If the application is denied and the license refused, or if the applicant withdraws his application prior to the license being issued, the license fee shall be refunded, but the one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) cost paid for investigative and administrative fees shall be retained by the city. However, any person applying for more than one (1) license at the same time shall pay only one (1) fee to defray investigative and administrative expenses. Any applicant for a license under this division who has in existence at the time of making the new application an existing license under this division shall pay no investigative and administrative fee. A notice of each application to sell malt beverages and/or wine by consumption shall be advertised in the official legal organ of the county, once a week for two (2) weeks immediately preceding consideration of the application. (c) Once a license has been issued, however, no portion of the license fee shall be refunded if the license is revoked, suspended, or surrendered. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 10, 7-12-2010) Sec. 4-111. - Hours and days of sale. (a) Malt beverages and/or wine shall not be sold or distributed for consumption on the premises except Monday through Saturday between the hours of 10:00 a.m. through 12:00 midnight and on Sunday from 12:30 p.m. until 11:30 p.m. (b) Election day sales. The sale of malt beverage and/or wine under this division shall be prohibited on election days within the city during the hours the polls are open. (c) Christmas day sales. The sale or distribution of beer and/or wine for consumption on the premises shall not be permitted on Christmas day. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 11, 7-12-2010; Ord. No. 18-10, § 2, 12-10-2018) Sec. 4-112. - Employment of underage persons prohibited. No person shall allow or require a person in his employment under eighteen (18) years of age to dispense, serve, sell, or take orders for any malt beverage or wine. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 12, 7-12-2010) Sec. 4-113. - Failure to require and properly check identification. It shall be a violation of this division not to require and properly check identification for such persons as reasonably necessary to ensure that an underage person is not sold, served, or does not have in his possession malt beverage or wine while in a licensed establishment. Identification in this section shall mean any document issued by a governmental agency containing a description of the person, such person's photograph and giving such person's date of birth and shall include, without being limited to, a passport, military ID card, driver's license or state department of public safety ID card. Nothing herein shall require mandatory checking of all customers' identifications. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 13, 7-12-2010) Sec. 4-114. - Brown bagging. It is prohibited for any person to bring his own malt beverage and/or wine in any establishment either licensed or unlicensed to serve malt beverage and/or wine. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 14, 7-12-2010) Sec. 4-115. - Display of license at place of business. The city license issued pursuant to this division shall at all times be kept plainly exposed to view to the public at the place of business of the licensee. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 15, 7-12-2010) Sec. 4-116. - Transferability of license/change in ownership. There shall be no transfers of licenses. Any change in ownership of any licensed entity other than a publicly traded corporation shall necessitate a new application and payment of the entirety of the license fee and administrative fee. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 16, 7-12-2010) Sec. 4-117. - Inventory stored only on premises. No licensee under this division shall keep any malt beverage or wine at any place except the licensed place of business. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 17, 7-12-2010) Sec. 4-118. - Notice. For purposes of this division, notice shall be deemed delivered when personally served or when served by certified mail, within three (3) days after the date of the deposit in the United States mail; or the date of confirmation of delivery from an overnight delivery service. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 18, 7-12-2010) Sec. 4-119. - Poured malt beverage and wine. Poured malt beverages or wine shall be transported from point of dispensing to the customer by permitted employees only. Permitted employees are those who have applied for and received a pouring license authorizing such employees to take orders and transport alcoholic beverages to customers. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 19, 7-12-2010) Sec. 4-120. - Regulations as to employees and managers. The following regulations shall apply to all establishments holding a license for consumption of malt beverages and/or wine on the premises: (1) No person shall be employed to dispense malt beverages or wine or serve in any managerial position by an establishment holding a license under this division until such person has been fingerprinted and cleared by the director of public safety for the city or his designee and/or city code enforcement officer indicating that the person is eligible for such employment as per the minimum requirements for an applicant under this division. (2) This section shall not be construed to include employees whose duties are limited solely to those of busboy(s), cooks, or dishwashers. (3) No permit shall be issued until such time as a signed application has been filed with the city clerk or designee and upon payment of a fee in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) and a search of the criminal record of the applicant completed. The application shall include, but shall be limited to, the name, date of birth and prior arrest record of the person, though the fact of an arrest record shall be used for investigative purposes only, and shall give rise to no presumption or inference of guilt. Due to the inclusion of the arrest information, the application shall be regarded as confidential and shall not be produced for public inspection without a court order. (4) The city clerk or a designee shall have a complete and exhaustive search made relative to any criminal record of the person fingerprinted. If the person is eligible for employment, the city clerk or a designee shall issue a permit to the person, by mail, stating that the person is eligible for employment. If it is found that the person is not eligible for employment, the director of public safety or city code enforcement officer or other designee shall notify the person, in writing, that he or she is not eligible for employment, the cause of such denial and his or her right of appeal. (5) No person shall be granted a pouring permit unless it appears to the satisfaction of the city clerk or a designee that such person has not been convicted or pled guilty or entered a plea of nolo contendere to any crime involving moral turpitude, illegal gambling, illegal possession or sale of controlled substances or the illegal sale or possession of alcoholic beverages, including the sale or transfer of alcoholic beverages to a minor in a manner contrary to law, keeping a place of prostitution, solicitation of sodomy, or any sexually related crime within a period of five (5) years preceding the date of the application and is not on probation or parole. A person's first time conviction for illegal possession of alcohol as a misdemeanor or violation of a city or county ordinance shall not, by itself, make a person ineligible for an alcohol pouring permit. No person shall be granted a pouring permit who has been convicted, plead guilty or entered a plea of nolo contendere to any federal, state, or local law for any felony within five (5) years preceding the date of the application and is currently on probation or parole. For purposes of this division, a conviction or pleas of guilt or nolo contendere shall be ignored as to any offense for which a person whose sentence was entered under the Georgia First Offender Act, as amended. Except, however, that any such offense shall not be ignored if the person violated any term of probation imposed by the court granting first offender treatment or committed another crime and the sentencing court entered an adjudication of guilt as to the crime for which the person had previously been sentenced as a first offender. (6) An alcohol pouring permit shall be issued for a period of three (3) calendar years from the date of the application. As provided in subsection (11) of this section, the alcohol pouring permit must be in the possession of the employee while the employee is working at the licensed establishment and available for inspection by members of the city police department. After application of the pouring permit is completed with the city, the employee may immediately commence work on a temporary basis provided the employee retains the receipt for the permit on his or her person at all times at the premises for which the alcohol license has been issued, and thereafter, if a permit is issued, must maintain on his or her person at the premises the actual pouring permit. If a permit is not issued, the employee must immediately cease work upon being notified that a permit will not be issued to the employee. (7) No person shall be issued a permit if it is determined that the person falsified, concealed or covered up any material fact by any device, trick or scheme while making application to the city clerk for an alcohol beverage pouring permit under this section. If it is determined that a person is in violation of this subsection and a permit is denied for this reason, then ninety (90) calendar days must elapse from the date of notification of the denial of the permit before the person may submit a new application for a permit. (8) All permits issued through administrative error can be immediately terminated and seized by the city clerk or designee. (9) Replacement permits will be issued within thirty (30) days of original date, upon paying one-half of the fee charged for alcohol pouring permits. After thirty (30) days of original application date, a new application and fee must be submitted. (10) All permits issued under this division remain the property of the city and shall be produced for inspection upon the demand of any city police officer, city code enforcement officer, city clerk or a designee. (11) No licensee shall allow any employee or manager required to hold a permit to work on premises unless the employee or manager has in his or her possession a current valid city pouring permit. For new employees, a receipt issued by the city clerk may be used for a maximum of ninety (90) days from the date of its issue unless notified that a permit will not be issued. Licensees are required by this division to inspect and verify that each employee required to do so has in his or her possession a valid current alcohol pouring permit. (12) It shall be the duty of all persons holding any license issued under this division to file with the city clerk the name of the establishment, the license number and a list of all employees, with their home addresses and home telephone numbers, twice annually during the month of June and again during the month of December. (13) The permit issued under this section shall be issued to individuals only and as long as the permit is valid, may be used at any employer licensed by this division until said license is revoked, suspended, terminated, or expires. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 20, 7-12-2010) Sec. 4-121. - Open area and patio sales. (a) Alcoholic beverage sales can be made by a licensed consumption on premises establishment in a patio/open area type environment if the establishment has been approved to do so by the code enforcement officer and is in compliance with any and all other regulations of the city. Also, all sales of malt beverages and wine under this provision must be in opaque containers and not in bottles or cans. (b) The requirement for approval is that the patio/open area be enclosed by some structure providing for public ingress/egress only through the main licensed premises. The purpose of this requirement is to prevent a customer from leaving the outside sales area with an open drink without the licensee's knowledge. (c) The height of such structure shall be a minimum of three and one-half (3½) feet above the patio floor, but the structure does have to shield or restrict visibility into or out of the patio/open sales area. The structure must be permitted and approved by the code enforcement officer and meet all building and fire code regulations. (d) The only exit from the patio/open sales area is to be through the licensed establishment's main premises and through an approved fire exit, not for general public use unless an emergency exists. The fire exit must be of a type that sounds an alarm so that the establishment will be alerted in the event of unauthorized use when no emergency exists. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 21, 7-12-2010) Sec. 4-122. - No consumption outside premises. (a) It is prohibited for customers to leave the premises with open containers of malt beverage or wine, and it is the licensee's responsibility to ensure that no open containers of malt beverage or wine are sold and carried out of the premises. (b) It is prohibited for customers to gather outside a malt beverage and/or wine establishment and consume malt beverage and/or wine. (c) It is prohibited for the manager or any employee of a licensee to allow persons to gather outside a malt beverage and/or wine establishment and consume malt beverage and/or wine. (d) This section does not apply to open area/outside sales as set forth in section 4-41 hereof. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 22, 7-12-2010) Sec. 4-123. - Enforcement of division. The director of public safety and/or the code enforcement officer or their designees shall have the authority to enforce this division and to inspect establishments under this division. These inspections shall be made for the purpose of verifying compliance with the requirements of this division and state law. This section is not intended to limit the authority of any other officer to enforce this division or conduct inspections authorized by other provisions of this division or state law. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 23, 7-12-2010) Sec. 4-124. - Establishment can be closed in cases of emergency. The director of public safety or a designee may immediately close an establishment licensed under this division in case of emergency for the safety of the public, as determined in the sole discretion of the city or a designee or to investigate a crime for a period of time not to exceed twenty-four (24) hours. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 24, 7-12-2010) Sec. 4-125. - Excise tax. (a) In addition to the license fees required in this division and in addition to the excise taxes levied by the state, there is hereby imposed an excise tax on alcoholic beverages in the following amounts: (1) Where malt beverages, commonly known as tap or draft beer, are sold in or from a barrel or bulk container, a tax of six dollars ($6.00) on each container sold containing not more than fifteen and one-half (15½) gallons and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of fifteen and one-half (15½) gallons. (2) Where malt beverages are sold in bottles, cans, or other containers, except barrel or bulk containers, a tax of $0.05 per twelve (12) ounces and a proportionate tax on all fractional parts of twelve (12) ounces. (3) On the first sale or use of wine, a tax of $0.22 per liter and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of a liter. (b) No person shall sell at retail for consumption on the premises within the city any alcoholic beverage on which the taxes imposed by this division have not been paid. (c) Every licensee under this division for the sale of alcoholic beverages in the city shall keep all invoices relating to each purchase of alcoholic beverages and such other records, receipts, invoices and other pertinent papers in such form as the city clerk may require. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 25, 7-12-2010) Sec. 4-126. - Method of payment. Said excise tax shall be paid to the city by each wholesale dealer on all malt beverages and wine sold and/or delivered to licensees hereunder within the corporate limits of the city not later than the tenth day of each month, based upon the units of malt beverage and wine sold and/or delivered during the previous calendar month by said wholesalers to licensees hereunder. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 26, 7-12-2010) Sec. 4-127. - Report. The wholesale dealer shall keep true and correct records of all sales and shipments of malt beverages and wine to licensees hereunder and shall render a sworn statement of the truth and accuracy of the report accompanying the monthly report to the city, and said report shall show the exact quantities of malt beverages and wine, by size and type of container and the amount of excise tax collected. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 27, 7-12-2010) Sec. 4-128. - Right of audit. The city shall have the right to audit and to require production of records from each wholesaler supplying licensees hereunder within the city and also from each licensee hereunder so supplied with malt beverages and wine by each wholesaler. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 28, 7-12-2010) Sec. 4-129. - Failure to make a timely report and pay tax; penalty. Failure to make a timely report and remittance of the above taxes shall render a wholesale dealer liable for a penalty equal to ten (10) percent of the total amount due, in addition to the amount of tax due; and, additionally, if said report is not filed or if said taxes are not remitted and paid within thirty (30) days from the date that same are due, the city shall have the right to suspend and/or revoke any wholesale license and further to prohibit said wholesaler from making any deliveries of any type whatsoever within the corporate limits of the city. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 29, 7-12-2010) Sec. 4-130. - Initial application for license. (a) Application for the sale of malt beverages and/or wine for consumption on the premises license shall be as follows: Each initial applicant shall make written application to the city clerk or a designee for the privilege of engaging in the sale of malt beverages for consumption on the premises; using forms approved and furnished by the city clerk. (1) The application shall be filed with the city clerk with a fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for investigation of the application and of the proposed location and processing of the application. (2) The application shall state: a. As to the applicant: Full name, age, home address, business address, telephone number, place of permanent residence, date of establishment of permanent residence at said location, address of last place of residence, name of spouse and all minor children, complete record of all convictions, guilty pleas and pleas of nolo contendere for violation of all laws, city, state and federal, of applicant and of applicant's spouse. If the applicant is a partnership said information shall be furnished as to each partner. If the applicant is a corporation said information must be furnished as to each director, each officer, and each stockholder who owns or controls ten (10) percent or more of the issued and outstanding stock of said corporation. b. As to applicant's proposed establishment manager or managers (if not same as applicant): Full name, age, home address, business address, telephone number, place of permanent residence, date of establishment of permanent residence at said location, address of last place of residence, name of spouse and all minor children, complete record of all convictions, guilty pleas and pleas of nolo contendere for violation of all laws, city, state and federal, of outlet manager's spouse. c. Exact location (street address) of proposed business establishment. d. Name and address of owner or landlord and resident manager, if any, of property proposed for location and whether or not there is a building proposed to be used already erected thereon. e. Name or trade name under which the proposed business shall be operated. f. Name and address of all persons having any financial interest in the business by way of ownership of building or stock, receipt of income from business or otherwise. This shall not apply to any stockholder who owns less than ten (10) percent of the issued and outstanding stock of the corporation. g. If the applicant is a corporation, the address of the principal place of business, the registered office, and the name of the registered agent or agents of the corporation. h. Such other information as may be required from time to time by the city through interrogatories or otherwise. (3) The application shall be sworn to by all applicants. (4) There shall be attached to the application a copy of applicant's license, application for license, or proposed application for a license from the State of Georgia, if one be required. (b) Prohibited premises. It shall be unlawful to grant a license for the sale of malt beverages and/or wine for consumption on the premises where the proposed location does not have a front entrance to the premises which is clearly visible from a public street, road or highway. (c) Prohibited persons. It shall be unlawful to grant a license for the sale of malt beverages and/or wine for consumption on the premises to: (1) A person who is not a citizen of the United States for a period of twelve (12) months next preceding the date of filing of the application, and if the applicant is a partnership these requirements apply to all partners in said business, whether a general partner or a limited partner; however, the provisions of this subparagraph shall not apply to a corporation. (2) A corporation which is not duly qualified to do business in the State of Georgia and which is not in good standing with all of the rules and regulations of the Georgia Corporation Code and the Secretary of State of Georgia, and which does not have a registered agent for service of process within the county; however, the provisions of this subparagraph shall not apply to an individual or a partnership which has no corporate partners. (3) A person who has been convicted of a felony, or any crime of moral turpitude, within ten (10) years immediately prior to the filing of said application. (4) A person who has been convicted or who has entered a plea of guilty or nolo contendere for any felony or any misdemeanor involving the illegal possession, transportation or sale of any alcoholic spirits, prohibited liquors, wine or malt beverages, or taxability thereof within ten (10) years immediately prior to the filing of said application. (5) A person who has been convicted or who has entered a plea of guilty or nolo contendere for any felony or any misdemeanor involving the illegal possession, transportation or sale of any drug, narcotic or controlled substance within ten (10) years immediately prior to the filing of said application. (6) A person, partnership or corporation whose license under this division has been revoked for cause or who has had a license of any type under this division revoked for cause within five (5) years immediately prior to the filing of the application. (7) A person who is under the age of twenty-one (21) years. (8) A person who has been declared incompetent by a court of competent jurisdiction. (9) An elected official or police officer or other law enforcement officer of the City of LaFayette, Georgia. (10) If the applicant is a corporation, subsections (c)(3)—(5), (7)—(9) above shall not apply. (11) Any partnership or corporation where any individual having any interest, either as owner, partner, stockholder, director or officer, or his or her spouse, shall have been convicted or shall have entered a plea of guilty or nolo contendere within ten (10) years immediately prior to the filing of said application of any felony, or any crime of moral turpitude, or any felony or misdemeanor involving the manufacturing, possession, transportation or sale of beer, alcoholic spirits, wine, or prohibited liquors, or the taxability thereof, or a violation of this division, or shall have been convicted or shall have entered a plea of guilty or nolo contendere within ten (10) years immediately prior to the filing of said application for any felony or misdemeanor involving the illegal possession, transportation or sale of any drug, narcotic or controlled substance. (d) Additional considerations. The city in reaching its final determination on an initial application shall also be guided by following factors as to whether or not to grant such license: (1) The proximity of other establishments licensed hereunder. (2) The nature of the neighborhood immediately adjacent to the proposed location, that is, whether the same is predominantly residential, industrial or business. (3) Whether the proposed location has adequate off-street parking facilities or other parking available for its patrons. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 30, 7-12-2010) Sec. 4-131. - Renewals of licenses; denial of renewal. (a) All licenses shall be issued for a period of one (1) year, the same to be a calendar year, running from January 1 through December 31, and shall be renewable as a matter of course upon payment of the appropriate fee, except as is hereinafter set out in subsection (d) of this section and as otherwise provided in this division. (b) Each licensee shall make written application for renewal on or before October 1 of each year on forms approved by the city clerk. (c) Said application shall be referred to the director of public safety or a designee, who shall report on the licensee's activity, if any, and upon activity at the location of the licensed business, if any, during the year. (d) If the director of public safety or designee reports any activity which constitutes probable cause for not renewing a license, the renewal shall not be made, and the matter shall be referred to the city for its consideration. A public hearing on the denial of a non-renewal must be held no later than December 31. (e) Said city shall afford the licensee a public hearing, and in passing upon the application for renewal, the city shall be guided by the following factors applicable to an initial application: All matters contained in section 4-130 of this division and such evidence as is obtained and presented to the city as the result of the investigation provided for in subparagraph (c) of this section. The city shall consider all evidence presented at the public hearing. (f) At said public hearing the city may grant or deny for cause the renewal of any license issued hereunder. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 31, 7-12-2010) Sec. 4-132. - Suspension and revocation of licenses. (a) Summary action. (1) If, at any time during the holding of a license granted under this division, it should appear that the licensee has violated the provisions of this division or laws of the State of Georgia or federal laws relating to the possession, transportation or sale of any alcohol, alcoholic spirits, prohibited liquors, wine or malt beverages or taxability thereof or involving the illegal possession, transportation or sale of any drug, narcotic or controlled substance, or has become a person prohibited by this division from having a license granted to him, or if it should appear that said person's application contained known false information, or if it appears necessary for the public safety, health and welfare, the director of public safety, code enforcement officer or a designee may suspend and seize any retail license to sell malt beverages and wine within the city. (2) If the licensee is dissatisfied with such suspension, he may appeal to the city council by filing a written request with the city clerk stating his grounds and reasons. (3) The city council shall hold a hearing on such suspension within ten (10) days of the filing of such appeal. After such hearing, the city council may affirm, reverse or modify the action of the suspending officer and may revoke or suspend said license or place said licensee on probation or refuse to renew at the time of renewal. (b) Action by city. The city council shall have full power and authority to revoke, refuse to renew, suspend or place on probation any license to sell malt beverages and/or wine for consumption on the premises for violation of this division or violation of any laws of the State of Georgia or any federal laws involving possession, transportation or sale of any alcohol, alcoholic spirits, prohibited liquors, wine or malt beverages or taxability thereof or involving illegal possession, transportation or sale of any drug, narcotic or controlled substance, or if the licensee has become a person, firm or corporation prohibited by this division from having a license granted to him or it, or if it should appear that his application contained known false information, or when the city council shall determine, after notice and hearing, that the operation of the licensed business is detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of the public. (c) Hearings. (1) Except as provided in subsection (a)(1) of this section, no license shall be suspended, revoked or non-renewed without the opportunity for a hearing as provided herein. (2) The city council or its designee shall provide written notice to the licensee of its intent to suspend, revoke or not renew the license. Such written notification shall be given as provided in this division. The notice shall: a. Advise of the time and place specified for the hearing, which hearing shall be held not more than fifteen (15) days, but not less than ten (10) days from the date notice is given, as provided herein; b. Shall set forth in reasonable detail the ground or grounds for such action and the factual basis supporting the ground or grounds; and c. Advise the licensee of the right to present evidence, witnesses, and arguments and to be represented by counsel at the hearing. d. The city council shall make its final determination within ten (10) business days of the completion of the hearing. e. The city council's decision shall be personally served or mailed by certified mail, return receipt requested to the licensee and his attorney, with a copy to the city attorney, within ten (10) business days of the close of the hearing. The decision of the city council shall constitute final action by the city, subject to review upon petition for certiorari to the county superior court. (3) Upon receipt of notice of adverse action against the licensee under this section, the licensee may waive its right to a hearing and stipulate to a sanction, as recommended by the city manager in consultation with the director of public safety. Any stipulation entered under this subsection shall be in writing, signed by the licensee, and is nonappealable. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 32, 7-12-2010) Sec. 4-133. - Additional conditions. (a) No licensee or employee or agent of a licensee, in connection with the sale or other disposition of malt beverages and/or wine for consumption on the premises, shall: (1) Offer or deliver any free malt beverage or wine to any person or group of persons; (2) Deliver more than one (1) malt beverage or wine to one (1) person at a time; (3) Sell, offer to sell, or deliver any person or group of persons any malt beverage or wine at a price less than the price regularly charged for such malt beverage or wine during the same calendar week, except at private functions not open to the public; (4) Sell, offer to sell, or deliver to any person or group of persons an unlimited number of malt beverages or wine during any set period of time for a fixed price, except at private functions not open to the public; (5) Sell, offer to sell, or deliver malt beverages or wine to any person or group of persons on any one (1) day at prices less than those charged the general public on that day, except at private functions not open to the public; (6) Sell, offer to sell, or deliver malt beverages or wine in any container which holds more than thirty-two (32) fluid ounces (.947 liters), except to two (2) or more persons at any one (1) time; or (7) Encourage or permit on the licensed premises any game or contest which involves the drinking of malt beverages and/or wine or the awarding of malt beverages or wine as a prize. (b) Each licensee shall maintain a schedule of the price charged for all malt beverage and wine to be served and consumed on the licensed premises or in any room or part thereof. The licensee shall not vary the schedule of prices from day to day or from hour to hour within a single day. (c) No licensee shall advertise or promote in any way, whether within or without the licensed premises, any of the practices prohibited under subsection (a) of this section. (d) No provision of this section shall be construed to prohibit licensees from including a malt beverage or wine as part of a meal package, or to prohibit the sale or delivery of wine by the bottle or carafe when sold with meals or to more than one (1) person. (e) It is the intent of this section to prohibit activities typically associated with promotions referred to as happy hour or similarly designated promotions. (Ord. No. 2010-02, § 33, 7-12-2010) Secs. 4-134—4-149. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - DISTILLED SPIRITS DIVISION 1. - SALES OF DISTILLED SPIRITS BY THE DRINK
Sec. 4-150. - Definitions. Unless the context clearly indicates a different meaning, the following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this division, have the following meanings: (a) Date of notice means the date when a person is personally served with a written document or three (3) days after the date of the deposit in the United States mail when the document is served by certified mail; or the date of confirmation of delivery of the written document from an overnight delivery service. (b) Distilled spirits means any alcoholic beverage obtained by distillation or containing more than twenty-four (24) percent alcohol by volume. (c) Eating establishment means any public place, including a place available for rental by the public, selling prepared food for consumption by the public on the premises with a full-service kitchen. A full-service kitchen shall consist of a three-compartment pot sink, a stove or grill permanently installed, and refrigerator, all of which must be approved by the health and fire departments. An eating establishment shall be prepared to serve food every hour the establishment is open and shall derive at least seventy (70) percent of the gross receipts annually from the sale of prepared meals or food. (d) Hotel/motel means any building or other structure providing sleeping accommodations for hire to the general public, either transient, permanent or residential. Such businesses shall have one (1) or more public dining rooms with a full-service kitchen, as that term is defined in (c) of this section. Hotels/motels shall have the privilege of granting franchises for the operation of any licensed establishment described in this division, and the holder of such franchise shall be included in the definition of a hotel/motel pursuant to this definition. (e) Identification means any document issued by a governmental agency containing a description of the person, such person's photograph and giving such person's date of birth and shall include, without being limited to, a passport, military ID card, driver's license or state department of public safety ID card. (f) Licensee means the person to whom a license for the sale or distribution of distilled spirits is issued under this division. In the case of a partnership or corporation, all partners, officers, and directors of the partnership or corporation are licensees. A license issued under this division permits the licensee to sell distilled spirits for beverage purposes by the drink for consumption only on the premises where sold. (g) Person means any individual, firm, partnership, cooperative, nonprofit membership corporation, joint venture, association, company, corporation, agency, syndicate, estate, trust, business trust, receiver, fiduciary, or other group or combination acting as a unit, body politic, or political subdivision, whether public, private, or quasi-public. (h) Premises means one (1) room or more all contiguous in nature operating under the same trade name. (i) Retail consumption dealer means any person who sells distilled spirits for consumption on the premises, at retail, only to consumers and not for resale. (j) Wholesaler means any person who sells distilled spirits to other wholesale dealers or to a retail consumption dealer. (Ord. No. 18-10, § 3, 12-10-2018) Sec. 4-151. - License is a privilege. (a) Distilled spirits may be sold by the drink for consumption only on the premises within the city for the limited purposes described in this division under a license granted by the city upon the terms and conditions provided in this division. (b) The sale of distilled spirits by the drink within the city without first obtaining the licensure required by this division is prohibited. (c) Licenses issued under this division constitute a mere grant of privilege to carry on the business during the term of the license, subject to all terms and conditions imposed by this division and state law. (d) Any holder of a license issued in accordance with this division is required to apply for and obtain any and all necessary alcoholic beverage licenses from the State of Georgia before any sales commence. Additionally, any holder of a license issued in accordance with this division is required to abide by all applicable state regulations and laws. (e) All licenses issued under this division must have printed on the face the following words: THIS LICENSE IS A PRIVILEGE CONDITIONAL ON THE HOLDER MEETING ALL STANDARDS FOR SUCH LICENSE AND OPERATING REGULATIONS APPLICABLE THERETO SET OUT IN CITY ORDINANCES AND GEORGIA LAW. FAILURE TO MEET SUCH STANDARDS OR TO COMPLY WITH SUCH OPERATING REGULATIONS SHALL SUBJECT THE HOLDER OF THE LICENSE TO HAVE THE LICENSE REVOKED FOLLOWING NOTICE AND HEARING. (Ord. No. 18-10, § 3, 12-10-2018) Sec. 4-152. - Licenses, generally. (a) All licenses issued under this division shall: (1) Permit the licensee to sell distilled spirits for beverage purposes by the drink for consumption only on the premises where sold within the city under the terms of this division and consistent with the laws of the State of Georgia and the United States; (2) Expire on December 31 of each year and an application for renewal must be made and filed annually on or before the 31st day of October of each year. Any licensee must annually meet the requirements set forth by the city in order to obtain a renewal of any license. Any licensee making proper application with supporting documents for a license to operate during the following calendar year, and having filed such application before October 31, shall be permitted to continue to operate pending final approval of the licensee's application for the following year if final approval is not granted before January 1; and (3) Not be transferred from one (1) person to another or from one (1) location to another and any change in ownership of any licensed entity other than a publicly traded corporation shall necessitate a new application and payment of the entirety of the license fee and administrative fee. (b) Separate applications must be made for each location and separate licenses must be issued for each location. (c) The city license issued under this division must, at all times, be kept plainly exposed to view to the public at the place of business of the licensee. (Ord. No. 18-10, § 3, 12-10-2018) Sec. 4-153. - Application and license fees. (a) Each application for a license under this division must be accompanied by a certified check for the full amount of the appropriate license fee, together with a separate check or cash in the amount of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) to defray investigative and administrative costs. If the application is denied and the license refused, or if the applicant withdraws his application prior to the license being issued, the license fee shall be refunded, but the one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) cost paid for investigative and administrative fees shall be retained by the city. However, any person applying for more than one (1) license at the same time shall pay only one (1) fee to defray investigative and administrative expenses. Any applicant for a license under this division who has in existence at the time of making the new application an existing license under this division is not required to pay the investigative and administrative fee. A notice of each application to sell distilled spirits by consumption must be advertised in the official legal organ of Walker County, once a week for two (2) weeks immediately preceding consideration of the application. (b) The fee for a license issued under this division is one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per calendar year which will not be prorated based upon the day of the year that the license is issued. (c) Once a license has been issued, however, no portion of the license fee will be refunded if the license is revoked, suspended, or surrendered. (Ord. No. 18-10, § 3, 12-10-2018) Sec. 4-154. - Application process. (a) Applications for the sale of distilled spirits for consumption on the premises license must be made in writing to the city clerk or a designee for the privilege of engaging in the sale of distilled spirits for consumption on the premises using forms approved and furnished by the city clerk. (b) The application must be filed with the city clerk along with the applicable application fee. (c) The application must state: (1) As to the applicant: Full name, age, home address, business address, telephone number, place of permanent residence, date of establishment of permanent residence at said location, address of last place of residence, name of spouse and all minor children, complete record of all convictions, guilty pleas and pleas of nolo contendere for violation of all laws, city, state and federal, of applicant and of applicant's spouse. If the applicant is a partnership said information shall be furnished as to each partner. If the applicant is a corporation said information must be furnished as to each director, each officer, and each stockholder who owns or controls ten (10) percent or more of the issued and outstanding stock of said corporation. (2) As to applicant's proposed establishment manager or managers (if not same as applicant): Full name, age, home address, business address, telephone number, place of permanent residence, date of establishment of permanent residence at said location, address of last place of residence, name of spouse and all minor children, complete record of all convictions, guilty pleas and pleas of nolo contendere for violation of all laws, city, state and federal, of outlet manager's spouse. (3) Exact location (street address) of proposed business establishment. (4) Name and address of owner or landlord and resident manager, if any, of property proposed for location and whether or not there is a building proposed to be used already erected thereon. (5) Name or trade name under which the proposed business shall be operated. (6) Name and address of all persons having any financial interest in the business by way of ownership of building or stock, receipt of income from business or otherwise. This shall not apply to any stockholder who owns less than ten (10) percent of the issued and outstanding stock of the corporation. (7) If the applicant is a corporation, the address of the principal place of business, the registered office, and the name of the registered agent or agents of the corporation. (8) Such other information as may be required from time to time by the city through interrogatories or otherwise. (d) The application must be sworn to by all applicants. (e) A copy of applicant's license, application for license, or proposed application for a license from the State of Georgia, if one is required, must be attached to the application. (Ord. No. 18-10, § 3, 12-10-2018) Sec. 4-155. - Requirements for license; limitations. (a) In addition to evaluating the criteria required to be included with an application under section 4-152 of this division in reaching its final determination as to whether or not to grant an initial license application, the city will also be guided by the following factors: (1) The proximity of other establishments licensed hereunder. (2) The nature of the neighborhood immediately adjacent to the proposed location, that is, whether the same is predominantly residential, industrial or business. (3) Whether the proposed location has adequate off-street parking facilities or other parking available for its patrons. (b) The following limitations apply to licensure under this division: (1) Prohibited premises. It shall be unlawful to grant a license for the sale of distilled spirits for consumption on the premises where the proposed location does not have a front entrance to the premises which is clearly visible from a public street, road or highway. (2) Prohibited persons. It shall be unlawful to grant a license for the sale of distilled spirits for consumption on the premises to: (A) A person who is not a citizen of the United States for a period of twelve (12) months next preceding the date of filing of the application, and if the applicant is a partnership these requirements apply to all partners in said business, whether a general partner or a limited partner; however, the provisions of this subsection shall not apply to a corporation. (B) A corporation which is not duly qualified to do business in the State of Georgia and which is not in good standing with all of the rules and regulations of the Georgia Corporation Code and the Secretary of State of Georgia, and which does not have a registered agent for service of process within Walker County, Georgia; however, the provisions of this subsection shall not apply to an individual or a partnership which has no corporate partners. (C) A person who has been convicted of a felony, or any crime of moral turpitude, within ten (10) years immediately prior to the filing of said application. (D) A person who has been convicted or who has entered a plea of guilty or nolo contendere for any felony or any misdemeanor involving the illegal possession, transportation or sale of any alcoholic beverages, or taxability thereof within ten (10) years immediately prior to the filing of said application. (E) A person who has been convicted or who has entered a plea of guilty or nolo contendere for any felony or any misdemeanor involving the illegal possession, transportation or sale of any drug, narcotic or controlled substance within ten (10) years immediately prior to the filing of said application. (F) A person, partnership or corporation whose license under this division has been revoked for cause or who has had a license of any type under this division revoked for cause within five (5) years immediately prior to the filing of the application. (G) A person who is under the age of twenty-one (21) years. (H) A person who has been declared incompetent by a court of competent jurisdiction. (I) An elected official, police officer, or other law enforcement officer of the city. (J) If the applicant is a corporation, subsections (C) through (I), above, do not apply. (K) Any partnership or corporation where any person has an interest, either as owner, partner, stockholder, director, or officer, or his or her spouse, has, within ten (10) years immediately prior to submission of an application, been convicted or has entered a plea of guilty or nolo contendere for any: (i) Felony; (ii) Crime of moral turpitude; (iii) Misdemeanor involving the manufacturing, possession, transportation or sale of distilled spirits or the taxability thereof, (iv) Misdemeanor involving the illegal possession, transportation, or sale of any drug, narcotic, or controlled substance; or (v) Violation of this division. (Ord. No. 18-10, § 3, 12-10-2018) Sec. 4-156. - Renewals of licenses; denial of renewal. (a) All licenses are issued for a period of one (1) year, the same to be a calendar year, running from January 1 through December 31, and shall be renewable as a matter of course upon payment of the appropriate fee, except as is hereinafter set out in subsection (d) of this section and as otherwise provided in this division. (b) Each licensee must make written application for renewal on or before October 1 of each year on forms approved by the city clerk. (c) The renewal application will be referred to the chief of police or a designee, who will report on the licensee's activity, if any, and upon activity at the location of the licensed business, if any, during the year. (d) If the chief of police or designee reports any activity which constitutes probable cause for not renewing a license, the renewal will not be made, and the matter will be referred to the city for its consideration. A public hearing on the denial of a non-renewal will be held no later than December 31. (e) The city will afford the licensee a public hearing after which the city may grant or deny for cause the renewal of any license issued under this division. (f) In passing upon the application for renewal, the city will consider all evidence presented at the public hearing and will be guided by the following factors: (1) All matters contained in sections 4-154 and 4-155 of this division; and (2) Such evidence as is obtained and presented to the city as the result of the investigation provided for in subsection (c) of this section. (Ord. No. 18-10, § 3, 12-10-2018) Sec. 4-157. - Suspension and revocation of licenses. (a) License suspensions initiated by the chief of police, code enforcement officer, or a designee. (1) The chief of police, code enforcement officer, or a designee may suspend and seize any retail license to sell distilled spirits for consumption on the premises if, at any time during the holding of a license granted under this division, it should appear that the licensee has: (i) Violated the provisions of this division; (ii) Violated any laws of the State of Georgia or any federal laws involving possession, transportation or sale of any alcohol, alcoholic spirits, prohibited liquors, alcoholic beverages or taxability thereof or involving illegal possession, transportation or sale of any drug, narcotic or controlled substance; (iii) Become a person, firm or corporation prohibited by this division from having a license granted to him, her, or it; (iv) Submitted an application containing known false information; or (v) Engaged in conduct detriment to the health, safety, or welfare of the public. (2) If the licensee is dissatisfied with such suspension, the licensee may appeal to the city council by filing a written request with the city clerk stating the grounds and reasons. (3) The city council will hold a hearing on the suspension within ten (10) days of the filing of the appeal, after which the city council has the full authority and power to revoke, refuse to renew, further suspend, or place on probation any license which has been suspended as provided by this subsection. (4) The city council must make its final determination within ten (10) business days of the completion of the appeal hearing. (b) Adverse licensure actions initiated by the city council. (1) In addition to the procedures provided in subsection (a), the city council may, of its own volition, suspend, revoke, or not renew a license issued under this division following a hearing. (2) A notice explaining the proposed adverse action, i.e. suspension, revocation, or non-renewal, and the time and place designated for the hearing must be issued to the licensee in writing. (3) The written notice must set forth, in reasonable detail, the ground or grounds for the proposed adverse action and the factual basis supporting the ground or grounds; and advise the licensee of the right to present evidence, witnesses, and arguments and to be represented by counsel at the hearing. (4) The hearing will not be held prior to the passage often days following the date of notice of the proposed adverse action. (5) The city council must make its final determination within ten (10) business days of the completion of the hearing. (6) The city council's decision must be personally served, mailed by certified mail, return receipt requested, or by overnight delivery to the licensee and his attorney, with a copy to the city attorney, within ten (10) business days of the close of the hearing. (7) The decision of the city council constitutes final action by the city, subject to review upon petition for certiorari to the Superior Court of Walker County, Georgia. (c) Upon receipt of notice of adverse action against the licensee under this section, the licensee may waive its right to a hearing and stipulate to a sanction, as recommended by the city clerk in consultation with the chief of police. Any stipulation entered under this subsection shall be in writing, signed by the licensee, and is not appealable. (d) Except as provided in subsection (a) of this section, no license will be suspended, revoked, or non-renewed without the opportunity for a hearing as provided in this section. (Ord. No. 18-10, § 3, 12-10-2018) Sec. 4-158. - Type of retail establishment where permitted; locations of sales. (a) Distilled spirits may only be sold in the following types of retail establishments: (1) Eating establishments, including those located within a hotel or motel if every entrance to the eating establishment within the hotel or motel is from a public lobby, hallway, mall, or other publicly used interior portion of the primary use structure; or (2) An indoor nonprofit civic and cultural center qualified under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code capable of serving prepared food, with a full-service kitchen prepared to serve food every hour they are open and deriving at least seventy (70) percent of its total annual gross sales from the sale of prepared meals or foods and recreation activities. (b) Distilled spirits may only be sold for consumption on the premises where sold in areas zoned as "business" or in a zoning district which permits eating establishments as conforming uses or where an eating establishment is incidental to a hotel or motel. (c) No license will be issued for the retail sale of distilled spirits for consumption on the premises within one hundred (100) yards of any church building, housing authority property, or alcohol treatment center operated by the State of Georgia, the city, or Walker County, Georgia, or within two hundred (200) yards of any school building. This distance is measured by the most direct route of travel on the ground. (Ord. No. 18-10, § 3, 12-10-2018) Sec. 4-159. - Hours and days of sale. (a) Distilled spirits must not be sold or distributed for consumption on the premises except Monday through Saturday between the hours of 10:00 a.m. through 12:00 midnight. (b) The sale or distribution of distilled spirits for consumption on the premises is not be permitted on: (1) Sundays; (2) Election days within the city during the hours the polls are open; and (3) Christmas day. (Ord. No. 18-10, § 3, 12-10-2018) Sec. 4-160. - Prohibited activities; penalties. (a) It is unlawful for any person to sell or possess for the purpose of sale any distilled spirits if the person does not have a license granted by the city to sell or possess for sale distilled spirits or to make deliveries beyond the boundaries of the premises covered by the license. (b) No person shall allow or require a person in his employment under eighteen (18) years of age to dispense, serve, sell, or take orders for any distilled spirits. (c) It is a violation of this division not to require and properly check identification for such persons as reasonably necessary to ensure that an underage person is not sold, served, or does not have in his possession distilled spirits while in a licensed establishment. But nothing in this section requires mandatory checking of the identification of every customer. (d) It is prohibited for any person to bring his or her own distilled spirits in any establishment, i.e. brown-bagging, regardless of whether such establishment is licensed or unlicensed to serve distilled spirits by the drink. (e) No licensee shall keep any distilled spirits at any place except the licensed place of business. (f) No licensee shall buy, arrange to buy, or in any way affect the transfer of any distilled spirits except from a licensed wholesaler. (g) Any violation of the provisions of this division may, upon determination of violation, result in suspension or revocation of a license issued under this division; or the council may in lieu of suspension or revocation thereof impose a civil penalty of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). (Ord. No. 18-10, § 3, 12-10-2018) Sec. 4-161. - Regulations as to employees and managers. (a) No person shall be employed to dispense distilled spirits or serve in any managerial position by an establishment holding a license under this division until such person has been fingerprinted and cleared by the chief of police for the city or his designee or city code enforcement officer indicating that the person is eligible for such employment as per the minimum requirements for an applicant under this division. (b) No permit shall be issued until such time as a signed application has been filed with the city clerk or designee and upon payment of a fee in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) and a search of the criminal record of the applicant completed. The application shall include, but shall be limited to, the name, date of birth and prior arrest record of the person, though the fact of an arrest record shall be used for investigative purposes only, and shall give rise to no presumption or inference of guilt. Due to the inclusion of the arrest information, the application shall be regarded as confidential and shall not be produced for public inspection without a court order. (c) The city clerk or a designee shall have a complete and exhaustive search made relative to any criminal record of the person fingerprinted. If the person is eligible for employment, the city clerk or a designee shall issue a permit to the person, by mail, stating that the person is eligible for employment. If it is found that the person is not eligible for employment, the chief of police or city code enforcement officer or other designee shall notify the person, in writing, that he or she is not eligible for employment, the cause of such denial and his or her right of appeal. (d) No person shall be granted a pouring permit unless it appears to the satisfaction of the city clerk or a designee that such person has not been convicted or pled guilty or entered a plea of nolo contendere to any crime involving moral turpitude, illegal gambling, illegal possession or sale of controlled substances or the illegal sale or possession of alcoholic beverages, including the sale or transfer of alcoholic beverages to a minor in a manner contrary to law, keeping a place of prostitution, solicitation of sodomy, or any sexually related crime within a period of five (5) years preceding the date of the application and is not on probation or parole. A person's first-time conviction for illegal possession of alcohol as a misdemeanor or violation of a city or county ordinance shall not, by itself, make a person ineligible for an alcohol pouring permit. No person shall be granted a pouring permit who has been convicted, plead guilty or entered a plea of nolo contendere to any federal, state, or local law for any felony within five (5) years preceding the date of the application and is currently on probation or parole. For purposes of this division, a conviction or pleas of guilt or nolo contendere shall be ignored as to any offense for which a person whose sentence was entered under the Georgia First Offender Act, as amended. Except, however, that any such offense shall not be ignored if the person violated any term of probation imposed by the court granting first offender treatment or committed another crime and the sentencing court entered an adjudication of guilt as to the crime for which the person had previously been sentenced as a first offender. (e) An alcohol pouring permit shall be issued for a period of three (3) calendar years from the date of the application. As provided in subsection (j) of this section, the alcohol pouring permit must be in the possession of the employee while the employee is working at the licensed establishment and available for inspection by members of the city police department. After application of the pouring permit is completed with the city, the employee may immediately commence work on a temporary basis provided the employee retains the receipt for the permit on his or her person at all times at the premises for which the alcohol license has been issued, and thereafter, if a permit is issued, must maintain on his or her person at the premises the actual pouring permit. If a permit is not issued, the employee must immediately cease work upon being notified that a permit will not be issued to the employee. (f) No person shall be issued a permit if it is determined that the person falsified, concealed or covered up any material fact by any device, trick or scheme while making application to the city clerk for an alcohol beverage pouring permit under this section. If it is determined that a person is in violation of this subsection and a permit is denied for this reason, then ninety (90) calendar days must elapse from the date of notification of the denial of the permit before the person may submit a new application for a permit. (g) All permits issued through administrative error can be immediately terminated and seized by the city clerk or designee. (h) Replacement permits will be issued within thirty (30) days of original date, upon paying one-half (½) of the fee charged for alcohol pouring permits. After thirty (30) days of original application date, a new application and fee must be submitted. (i) All permits issued under this division remain the property of the city and shall be produced for inspection upon the demand of any city police officer, city code enforcement officer, city clerk or a designee. (j) No licensee shall allow any employee or manager required to hold a permit to work on premises unless the employee or manager has in his or her possession a current valid city pouring permit. For new employees, a receipt issued by the city clerk may be used for a maximum of ninety (90) days from the date of its issue unless notified that a permit will not be issued. Licensees are required by this division to inspect and verify that each employee required to do so has in his or her possession a valid current alcohol pouring permit. (k) It shall be the duty of all persons holding any license issued under this division to file with the city clerk the name of the establishment, the license number and a list of all employees, with their home addresses and home telephone numbers, twice annually during the month of June and again during the month of December. (l) The permit issued under this section shall be issued to individuals only and as long as the permit is valid, may be used at any employer licensed by this division until said license is revoked, suspended, terminated, or expires. (Ord. No. 18-10, § 3, 12-10-2018) Sec. 4-162. - Open areas and patio sales. (a) Alcoholic beverage sales can be made by a licensed consumption on premises establishment in a patio/open area type environment if the establishment has been approved to do so by the code enforcement officer and is in compliance with any and all other regulations of the city. Also, all sales of distilled spirits under this provision must be in opaque containers and not in bottles or cans. (b) The requirement for approval is that the patio/open area be enclosed by some structure providing for public ingress/egress only through the main licensed premises. The purpose of this requirement is to prevent a customer from leaving the outside sales area with an open drink without the licensee's knowledge. (c) The height of such structure shall be a minimum of three and one-half (3½) feet above the patio floor, but the structure does have to shield or restrict visibility into or out of the patio/open sales area. The structure must be permitted and approved by the code enforcement officer and meet all building and fire code regulations. (d) The only exit from the patio/open sales area is to be through the licensed establishment's main premises and through an approved fire exit, not for general public use unless an emergency exists. The fire exit must be of a type that sounds an alarm so that the establishment will be alerted in the event of unauthorized use when no emergency exists. (Ord. No. 18-10, § 3, 12-10-2018) Sec. 4-163. - No consumption outside premises. (a) It is prohibited for customers to leave the premises with open containers of distilled spirits, and it is the licensee's responsibility to ensure that no open containers of distilled spirits are sold and carried out of the premises. (b) It is prohibited for customers to gather outside an establishment and consume distilled spirits. (c) It is prohibited for the manager or any employee of a licensee to allow persons to gather outside an establishment and consume distilled spirits. (d) This section does not apply to open area/outside sales as set forth in section 4-162 of this division. (Ord. No. 18-10, § 3, 12-10-2018) Sec. 4-164. - Enforcement of division. The chief of police, code enforcement officer, or their designees have the authority to enforce this division and to inspect establishments under this division. These inspections are to be made for the purpose of verifying compliance with the requirements of this division and state law. This section is not intended to limit the authority of any other officer to enforce this division or conduct inspections authorized by other provisions of this division or state law. (Ord. No. 18-10, § 3, 12-10-2018) Sec. 4-165. - Establishment can be closed in cases of emergency. The chief of police or a designee may immediately close an establishment licensed under this division in case of emergency for the safety of the public, as determined in his or her sole discretion or to investigate a crime for a period of time not to exceed twenty-four (24) hours. (Ord. No. 18-10, § 3, 12-10-2018) Sec. 4-166. - Excise tax. (a) In addition to the license fees required in this division and in addition to the excise taxes levied by the state, there is hereby imposed an excise tax on the sale of distilled spirits. (b) Excise taxes on the wholesale of distilled spirits. There is hereby levied an excise tax computed at the rate of twenty-two cents ($0.22) per liter which shall be paid to the city on all distilled spirits sold in the city. Such tax shall be paid to the city by the wholesaler on all distilled spirits sold to retail dealers in the city as follows: (1) Each wholesaler selling, shipping, or in any way delivering distilled spirits to any retail dealer, shall collect the excise tax at the time of delivery to each retail dealer on or before the tenth day of the month following. (2) The twenty-two cents ($0.22) per liter rate shall be prorated so that all containers of distilled spirits shall be taxed on the basis of twenty-two cents ($0.22) per liter. (3) It is unlawful for any wholesaler to sell, ship or deliver in any manner any distilled spirits to a retail dealer without collecting the tax.
