It shall be unlawful for any retail dealer to possess, own, hold, store, display, or sell any distilled spirits on which such tax has not been paid. (4) The wholesale dealer shall keep true and correct records of all sales and shipments of distilled spirits to licensees hereunder and shall render a sworn statement of the truth and accuracy of the report accompanying the monthly report to the city, and said report shall show the exact quantities of distilled spirits, by size and type of container and the amount of excise tax collected. (5) The city shall have the right to audit and to require production of records from each wholesaler supplying licensees hereunder within the city and also from each licensee hereunder so supplied with distilled spirits by each wholesaler. (6) Failure to make a timely report and remittance of the above taxes renders a wholesale dealer liable for a penalty equal to ten (10) percent of the total amount due, in addition to the amount of tax due; and, additionally, if a report is not filed or if taxes are not remitted and paid within thirty (30) days from the date either is due, the city has the right to suspend or revoke any wholesale license and further to prohibit the wholesaler from making any deliveries of any type whatsoever within the corporate limits of the city. (c) Excise taxes on retail sales of poured distilled spirits by the drink. There is hereby levied an excise tax computed at the rate of three (3) percent of the charge to the public on sales of distilled spirits by the drink made by pouring outlets. (1) This tax does not apply to the sale of fermented beverages made in whole or in part from malt or any similar fermented beverage. (2) Such tax shall be paid to the city by the pouring licensee on all distilled spirits sold to customers by the drink in the city on or before the tenth day of the month following such sales. (3) It is unlawful for any pouring licensee to fail to pay such excise tax and no person shall sell at retail for consumption on the premises within the city any alcoholic beverage on which the taxes imposed by this division have not been paid. (4) Every licensee under this division for the sale of distilled spirits in the city shall keep all invoices relating to each purchase of distilled spirits and such other records, receipts, invoices and other pertinent papers in such form as the city clerk may require. (5) The city has the right to audit and to require production of records from each licensee. (Ord. No. 18-10, § 3, 12-10-2018) Sec. 4-167. - Additional considerations. (a) No licensee or employee or agent of a licensee, in connection with the sale or other disposition of distilled spirits for consumption on the premises, shall: (1) Offer or deliver any free alcoholic beverage to any person or group of persons; (2) Deliver more than one (1) alcoholic beverage to one (1) person at a time; (3) Sell, offer to sell, or deliver any person or group of persons any alcoholic beverage at a price less than the price regularly charged for such alcoholic beverage during the same calendar week, except at private functions not open to the public; (4) Sell, offer to sell, or deliver to any person or group of persons an unlimited number of distilled spirits during any set period of time for a fixed price, except at private functions not open to the public; (5) Sell, offer to sell, or deliver distilled spirits to any person or group of persons on any one (1) day at prices less than those charged the general public on that day, except at private functions not open to the public; (6) Sell, offer to sell, or deliver distilled spirits in any container which holds more than sixteen (16) fluid ounces, except to two (2) or more persons at any one (1) time; or (7) Encourage or permit on the licensed premises any game or contest which involves the drinking of distilled spirits or the awarding of distilled spirits as a prize. (b) Each licensee shall maintain a schedule of the price charged for all distilled spirits to be served and consumed on the licensed premises or in any room or part thereof. The licensee shall not vary the schedule of prices from day to day or from hour to hour within a single day. (c) No licensee shall advertise or promote in any way, whether within or without the licensed premises, any of the practices prohibited under subsection (a) of this section. (d) No provision of this section shall be construed to prohibit licensees from including an alcoholic beverage as part of a meal package, or to prohibit the sale or delivery of wine by the bottle or carafe when sold with meals or to more than one (1) person. (e) It is the intent of this section to prohibit activities typically associated with promotions referred to as happy hour or similarly designated promotions. (Ord. No. 18-10, § 3, 12-10-2018)

div.head: Chapter 5 - ANIMALS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Authority to regulate animals, § 1-21(i). Cross reference— Horses or ponies in parks, § 15-2. State Law reference— Municipal authority to provide for animal control, Ga. Const. 1983, Art. IX, Sec. II, Para. III(a)(3); animals generally, OCGA Title 4.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 5-1. - Horses, cattle, and so forth, running at large; staking, driving and leading requirements; impounding. It shall be unlawful for any person to allow or permit any horses, cattle, sheep, goats, or other livestock to run at large on the streets of the city, or to be staked so that they can go upon the streets of the city, or to drive or lead any such animals or livestock along or on the sidewalks in the city, or to drive or lead any such animals or livestock along and over the streets of the city, unless fastened to a rope, chain, or other substantial leading device. Any such rope, chain, or other substantial leading device must be securely held by a responsible person. Animals in violation of this chapter shall be impounded by members of the police department, other authorized employees or agents of the city, or the county animal control officers or their employees or agents. (Code 1975, § 2-10) Sec. 5-2. - Impounded animals—Sale when unredeemed within certain time; notice. If any animal impounded as provided in section 5-1 shall not be claimed and redeemed by the owner, or keeper thereof, within three (3) days after such impoundment, the chief of police or the assistant chief of police shall advertise the same for sale by posting three (3) written notices of such sale, one (1) such notice to be at the gate or door of the pound or place of confinement of the animal, one (1) at the city hall, and one (1) at the office of the police department. Such notices must be posted for not less than three (3) consecutive days prior to the date of sale. Prior to selling any animal impounded under section 5-1, the chief of police or any officer designated by him shall make a reasonable and diligent inquiry to determine the owner of such animal, and if the owner is determined, such owner shall be notified by telephone or in writing of the impoundment, the method and cost of redemption, and the time and place of any proposed sale of the animal. If the animal is not redeemed by the owner, on the day named for such sale, the chief of police or assistant chief of police shall sell the animal at public auction at the place of impoundment to the highest bidder for cash and shall pay over the proceeds to the city clerk who shall pay out of such proceeds all expenses and shall hold any balance subject to the use and order of the governing body of the city. (Code 1975, § 2-11) Sec. 5-3. - Same—Redemption by owner. At any time prior to the sale of any impounded animal, as provided in section 5-2, the owner of such animal may redeem the same by proving ownership of such animal to the chief of police and in his absence to the assistant chief of police and paying the charges provided herein for the impoundment of the animal and the cost of feeding such animal during the period of time that the same has been impounded. (Code 1975, § 2-12) Sec. 5-4. - Same—Charges for impounding, keeping and selling. The charges for impounding, keeping, and selling any animal as provided under this chapter shall be as set from time to time and a schedule of such charges is on file in the city clerk's office. (Code 1975, § 2-13) Sec. 5-5. - Record and monthly report of impounded animals by chief of police to city manager. The chief of police shall keep a record, in a book to be kept for such purpose, of all animals impounded. Said record and book shall fully describe the animal, the date impounded, the name of the owner, if known, the day of redemption by the owner, the day of sale of such animal, the charges charged to the owner if the animal was redeemed, the amount received from any redemption or sale and the amount paid to the city clerk. The chief of police shall present to the city manager a monthly copy of such record for the preceding month. (Code 1975, § 2-14) Sec. 5-6. - Manner of keeping. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, maintain or permit any animal or fowl in the city in such manner as to create an unsanitary condition or to create an obnoxious condition, or to become excessively noisy or to become a nuisance to the neighbors or citizens of the city, or to disturb the peace of the city. (b) Should a complaint arise for any one (1) or more of the causes referred to in subsection (a) of this section, the owner of such animal or fowl shall be given an oral or written warning of the complaint by the animal control officer or a police officer and shall be given five (5) days to correct and eliminate the violation. The animal control officer or a police officer shall investigate to determine if the violation has been eliminated within such period of time, and if the violation has not been eliminated or remedied, the owner will be promptly summoned to recorder's court and given a hearing regarding the complaint. If the recorder determines at the hearing that the owner has violated subsection (a) of this section, the recorder may impose a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) on the owner or order such animal impounded and disposed of in the manner provided by section 5-29(d). (Code 1975, § 2-15; Ord. of 10-1-85) Charter reference— Abatement of nuisances, § 5-24. Cross reference— Health and sanitation, Ch. 12. Sec. 5-7. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. 07/8, § 1, adopted Sept. 17, 2007, deleted § 5-7, which pertained to vicious dogs or other animals; keeping, impounding and disposing of and derived from Code 1975, § 2-16. Sec. 5-8. - Poisoning animals. It shall be unlawful for any person to put out or cause to be put out any poison within the city which is for the primary purpose of killing or causing harm to any dog, cat, or other domestic or domesticated animal. (Code 1975, § 2-17) Sec. 5-9. - Dead animals, disposal of carcass. (a) All carcasses shall be disposed of in such manner as complies with the rules and regulations of the county health department and the rules and regulations of all departments and agencies of the state whose primary purpose is to protect and promote the health of the citizens of this state. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person who owns or has an interest in any animal which has died, to leave the body or carcass thereof anywhere inside the city limits without proper disposal thereof as provided in (a) above. (Code 1975, § 2-18) Cross reference— Health and sanitation, Ch. 12. Sec. 5-10. - Commercial raising of poultry prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to raise poultry on a commercial basis within the city limits. (Code 1975, § 2-19) Sec. 5-11. - Poultry running at large prohibited. It shall be unlawful for the owner of chickens or other fowls to allow them to run at large within the city limits and all owners of such chickens or other fowls are hereby required to keep the same confined in pens on their own premises. (Code 1975, § 2-20) Sec. 5-12. - Violations. Except where otherwise provided, any violation of the provisions of this chapter shall be an offense punishable in accordance with section 1-17. (Code 1975, § 2-30) Secs. 5-13—5-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - DOGS, CATS AND OTHER DOMESTICATED PETS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Dogs generally, OCGA Title 4, Ch. 8.
Sec. 5-21. - Definitions. For the purpose of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein: Animal means any domesticated dog, cat, raccoon, skunk, opossum, or squirrel. Nuisance means, but is not limited to, defecation, urination, disturbing the peace, destroying private property, emitting noxious or offensive odors, emitting noxious or offensive sounds and noises. Owner of an animal is a person who owns, harbors, or keeps, or knowingly permits an animal to be harbored or kept or has an animal in his care, or who permits an animal to remain on or about his premises for more than five (5) days. Vaccination is protection against rabies by inoculation with anti-rabies vaccine, given in an amount sufficient to provide immunity from rabies for a minimum of one (1) year. (Code 1975, § 3-10; Ord. No. 07/8, § 2, 9-17-2007) Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. Sec. 5-22. - Collar, inoculation and identification tags required. (a) All animals over ninety (90) days old within the city shall wear a collar or harness to which is attached a metal identification tag of the kind hereinafter prescribed. Identification tags will be provided by the city upon presentation of a certificate of inoculation or vaccination for rabies to an employee of the city designated by the city manager at the city hall and upon a payment of a fee of two dollars ($2.00) if the animal is unaltered and a fee of one dollar ($1.00) if the animal is altered. The application for the identification tag shall state the name and address of the owner, the name, breed, age, color and sex of such animal. The license so granted by the city shall expire on June thirtieth of each calendar year, and shall be renewed on or before July first of each year. (b) Animals belonging to nonresidents of the city who do not keep such animals within the corporate limits of the city for fifteen (15) consecutive days shall be exempt from this section; provided, however, that all the other provisions of this article must be complied with. (c) All monies collected for the issuance of identification tags and licenses shall go into the city treasury to help defray the expense of animal and fowl control. (d) The annual license fees hereinabove provided in subparagraph (a) of this section shall be the license fee for the year beginning July 1, 1975 and ending June 30, 1976. Thereafter the annual license fee shall be as established from year to year by the city council. (Code 1975, § 3-11) Sec. 5-23. - Inoculation. All animals over ninety (90) days old within the city shall be inoculated annually so as to provide immunity from rabies for a period of at least one (1) year. All inoculations shall be administered by a licensed veterinarian or an authorized representative of the public health department. (Code 1975, § 3-12) State Law reference— Rabies inoculation, OCGA § 31-19-1 et seq. Sec. 5-24. - Tags. (a) A valid city identification tag and a valid rabies vaccination tag shall be securely attached to the animal's collar or harness, and must be secured to and on the animal at all times, and it shall be the duty and responsibility of the owner to see that the same is so attached and secured at all times. (b) Each city identification tag shall be so contrived as to permit it to be securely attached to the animal's collar or harness and shall have its respective number, the year in which issued and the "City of LaFayette" indented and impressed thereon. The design or color of such tags shall be varied from year to year so as to permit easy ascertainment as to whether or not the tag is current. (Code 1975, § 3-13) Sec. 5-25. - Record of tags. A complete record of animal tags issued by the city shall be kept by the city. The record shall show when the tag was issued, the period of time for which the tag is valid, to whom the tag was issued and the address of such person, for what particular animal the tag was issued; and if the owner and keeper of the animal are different persons, then both names and the addresses of each shall be entered. (Code 1975, § 3-14) Sec. 5-26. - Misuse of tag. It shall be unlawful for any person to remove a valid tag from any animal which has been tagged under the provisions of this article, or to place a tag upon any animal for which the same was not issued, or to procure a tag from the city or from any licensed veterinarian by misrepresentation, or to disfigure any tag or to alter the figures or words upon any tag. This provision shall apply to both the city identification tag and the rabies vaccination tag. (Code 1975, § 3-15) Sec. 5-27. - Restraint of animals. The owner or keeper of each animal within the city shall be responsible for keeping it from becoming a nuisance or from endangering or injuring any other person or property, and accordingly: (1) It shall be unlawful for the owner or keeper of any animal to allow the animal to go on the property of any other person or any public right-of-way, roadway or street. (2) When allowed off the property of the owner or keeper, all animals must be accompanied by the owner or other responsible keeper and be restrained on a leash, rope, chain, or other substantial leading device held by the owner or keeper or be in a vehicle driven or parked from which the animal cannot escape. (Code 1975, § 3-16) Sec. 5-28. - Impoundment authorized; notice of impoundment and contents of notice. (a) All animals not kept or maintained in accordance with the previously outlined provisions of this article shall be subject to impoundment by the city and its agents and employees or by the county animal control officer in the Walker County Impoundment or in any other impoundment provided for the purpose by the city. (b) In addition, all animals found on the premises of any person other than the owner without permission of the owner of the premises upon which such animal is found and all animals found running loose in the city shall be subject to such impoundment. (c) Notice of the impoundment of any animal must be given immediately by United States mail or by telephone call to the owner as indicated on the registration records of the city or on any other identification tag found on the animal. Such notice is to be given by the county animal control officer, and such notice of impoundment shall contain a general description of the animal impounded, the kind of animal, the breed of animal if readily ascertainable, the color of the animal and the sex thereof. (Code 1975, § 3-17) Sec. 5-29. - Disposal of animal not claimed; method of disposal. (a) A registered animal shall be confined at the impoundment for a period of at least five (5) days from the date of mailing the notice to the owner or five (5) days from the date of notice being given by telephone. An animal that is not registered shall be confined at the impoundment for a period of at least three (3) days. (b) During the aforesaid period of time the owner of the animal may claim the same and such animal may be redeemed by the owner by the payment to the county control officer of such impoundment fee as is prescribed by the governing body of the county, the cost of feeding the animal during the period of confinement, and the cost of inoculation if such animal has not been inoculated within the preceding twelve-month period. (c) The county animal control officer may dispose of any animals not claimed and redeemed by the owner, as provided for herein, on the first day after the required impoundment period as provided in this section. (d) As methods of disposal, the county animal control officer may have the animal; (1) Placed in an adoptive home; (2) Sold; or (3) Destroyed in such a humane manner as the animal control officer may deem appropriate. (e) In the case of the sale of such animal, the animal control officer is hereby authorized to execute a bill of sale to any such purchaser which shall be sufficient to vest title to the animal in such purchaser. (Code 1975, § 3-18) Sec. 5-30. - Rabid animal. An animal that has rabies or shows signs of having rabies, and every animal bitten by another animal afflicted with rabies or that has been exposed to rabies shall be confined at once in a secure place by the owner or keeper of such animal. A person who knows or has reason to know that an animal is infected with rabies or has been exposed to rabies shall immediately upon learning of the infection or exposure notify the county animal control officer or the chief of police of the city as to the place where the animal is confined and shall surrender the animal to the county animal control officer or to the city, its agents or employees upon demand. (Code 1975, § 3-19) Sec. 5-31. - Animals biting people. (a) The owner or keeper of an animal that bites a person and a person bitten by an animal shall have a duty to report that occurrence to the chief of police of the city within twenty-four (24) hours from such occurrence. The owner or keeper of an animal that bites a person shall surrender said animal to the county animal control officer if the chief of police or assistant chief of police deems it necessary to impound the animal for a period of observation. (b) A physician who renders professional treatment to a person bitten by an animal shall report the fact that he has rendered professional treatment to the chief of police or assistant chief of police within twenty-four (24) hours of his first professional attendance of such person. The physician shall report the name, sex and address of the person bitten as well as the type and location of the bite. The physician shall give the name and address of the owner and/or keeper of the animal that inflicted the bite and any other facts that may assist the city and the county animal control officer in ascertaining the immunization status of the animal. (c) An animal that bites a person shall be confined securely for such period of time as may be deemed necessary by the chief of police, or in his absence the assistant chief of police of the city, but not less than ten (10) days. The owner of the animal shall bear the cost of confinement in such place of confinement as is deemed appropriate by the chief of police and the public health authorities of the county. The chief animal control officer of the county or such other public health official as may be designated by the city may consent to confinement on the owner's premises but only if the animal had a current rabies vaccination at the time the bite was inflicted. The premises where the home confinement is to occur shall be inspected and approved for such purpose by such official or officer. (d) A person who has custody of an animal that has bitten a person shall immediately notify the chief of police, and in his absence the assistant chief of police of the city, if the animal shows any signs of sickness, abnormal behavior, or if the animal escapes confinement. If the animal dies while it is in confinement, the person having custody of the animal shall notify the chief of police, assistant chief of police or county animal control officer and shall surrender the carcass of the animal to such officers. (Code 1975, § 3-20) Sec. 5-32. - Extermination of rabid animals. The authorities of the city and the county animal control officer and his duly authorized agents and employees are authorized to exterminate any rabid animal found within the city. (Code 1975, § 3-21) Sec. 5-33. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. 07/8, § 3, adopted Sept. 17, 2007, deleted § 5-33, which pertained to vicious animals; extermination of vicious animals and derived from Code 1975, § 3-22. Sec. 5-34. - Authority to go on private property. Employees and agents of the city and county animal control officers and persons under their control and supervision shall have the right to go upon private property within the city for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this chapter, provided it is necessary for such purpose. (Code 1975, § 3-23) Sec. 5-35. - Violations. Except where otherwise provided, any violation of the provisions of this article shall be an offense punishable in accordance with section 1-17. (Code 1975, § 3-30) Secs. 5-36—5-42. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - VICIOUS ANIMALS[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 07/8, § 5, adopted Sept. 17, 2007 amended the Code by adding Art. III, §§ 5-43—5-51. For purposes of classification and in order to facilitate indexing the editor has redesignated these sections as §§ 5-44—5-51.
Sec. 5-43. - Definition of vicious animal. Vicious animal is defined as follows: (1) Any animal which shall bite or in any other manner attack or attempt to attack any person within the city, except that any animal that bites, attacks or attempts to attack any person unlawfully upon its owner's or keeper's premises, or which is provoked to attack, shall not be deemed a vicious animal; or (2) The following breeds of dogs are hereby declared, by the nature of the breed, to be vicious animals: any Chow, Rotweiler, or "Pit Bull Terrier." "Pit Bull Terrier" means any Staffordshire Bull Terrier or American Staffordshire Terrier breed of dog, or any mixed breed of dog which contains, as an element of its breeding the breed of Staffordshire Bull Terrier or American Staffordshire Terrier as to be identifiable as partially of the breed of Staffordshire Bull Terrier or American Staffordshire Terrier. (Ord. No. 07/8, §§ 4, 5, 9-17-2007) Sec. 5-44. - Additional safeguard requirements for a vicious animal. In addition to the requirements set forth in article II of chapter 5, the following safeguard actions shall be taken by the owner of a vicious animal in recognition of the concern for the safety of the residents of the city: (1) An owner or keeper of a vicious animal must keep the animal inside his or her residence at all times unless the animal is directly placed and kept within a proper enclosure. A proper enclosure means a securely enclosed pen or other structure of adequate size to humanely confine the vicious animal. The enclosure must prevent the entry of young children and be designed to keep the vicious animal from escaping. The enclosure must have secure sides and a secure top attached to all sides. The sides must either be buried two (2) feet into the ground or sunken into a concrete pad. The gate to the enclosure shall be inward opening and shall be kept securely locked. (2) The enclosure shall be completely surrounded by a separate perimeter fence. The enclosure may not share common fencing with the perimeter fence. The perimeter fence shall be of sufficient height to prevent the vicious animal from escaping by jumping over the fence. The perimeter fence shall be sufficiently secured to prevent the vicious animal from escaping by crawling or digging under or knocking over the fence. If there is a gate in the fence, the gate shall be kept securely locked. (3) Except when being transported to a licensed veterinary facility, a vicious animal shall not be allowed off the property of the owner or keeper. Should transport for veterinary care be needed, the animal shall be securely and humanely confined within a vehicle. Movement of the animal from the residence of the owner to and from the transporting vehicle and to and from the veterinary facility shall be conducted with the animal securely leashed by a leash no longer than six (6) feet in length and muzzled by a muzzle or device constructed so as to prevent the animal from biting. (4) Except as may be allowed in this article, the owner or keeper of a vicious animal shall at all times keep the vicious animal within either the residence of the owner or keeper or the proper enclosure as set forth in this section. It shall be unlawful to permit the animal to be outside the residence or the proper enclosure of the owner or keeper unless the animal is properly muzzled by a muzzle or device constructed so as to prevent the animal from biting, and the animal is attended by the owner or keeper, who is capable of controlling the animal, and the animal is restrained by a secure collar and leash of sufficient strength to prevent escape. The leash shall be no longer than six (6) feet in length. The animal must be kept at least fifteen (15) feet within the perimeter boundaries of the property, unless the perimeter boundary is securely fenced. (5) The owner or keeper of a vicious animal must maintain at all times either a policy of insurance or a surety bond in a minimum amount of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) to cover claims for any personal injuries inflicted by the vicious animal, which policy or surety bond shall be issued by an insurer or surety, as the case may be, authorized to transact business in this state. A copy of the insurance policy or surety bond, and all renewals thereof, shall be provided by the owner or keeper to the animal control department. (6) The premises where a vicious animal is kept shall be posted with clearly visible signs warning that there is an animal on the premises that presents a danger to human beings. The signs shall include a symbol sufficient to convey without words the message that there is an animal on the premises that presents a danger to human beings. The signs shall be conspicuously displayed on each exterior side of the enclosure for each fifty (50) feet of the enclosure, with a minimum of two (2) signs, in addition to a sign on each ingress and egress point to the enclosure. The signs shall be a minimum of ten (10) inches tall and fourteen (14) inches long. In addition, signs shall be placed at each door to the house if the vicious animal is kept at any time in the house. The signs shall also comply with the requirements set forth by the Georgia Department of Natural Resources. A copy of the Department of Natural Resources' sign requirements are available from the animal control department. (7) The owner or keeper of a vicious animal shall, prior to placing the animal on the premises, have the animal micro-chip registered, at the owner's expense, and provide the registration number to the animal control department. The owner or keeper shall keep the micro-chip registration information updated, and provide the animal control department with the updated registration information. (Ord. No. 07/8, §§ 4, 5, 9-17-2007; Ord. No. 07/9, § 1, 10-8-2007; Ord. No. 18-05, §§ 1, 2, 2-12-2018) Sec. 5-45. - Owner notification requirements. The owner or keeper of a vicious animal shall report to the animal control department within twenty-four (24) hours of any of the following events: (1) Escape of the animal; (2) An attack on a human or domestic animal by the vicious animal; (3) Transfer of location of the animal; (4) Transfer of ownership of the animal; or (5) Death of the animal. (Ord. No. 07/8, §§ 4, 5, 9-17-2007) Sec. 5-46. - Impoundment of vicious animals. (a) A law enforcement officer or animal control officer shall immediately impound any animal the officer believes poses a threat to the public safety or any vicious animal as defined in this article which is not held, kept, or otherwise maintained according to the requirements of this article. At the time said vicious animal is impounded, the animal control officer shall provide the owner or keeper of said animal with a written citation to appear in the recorder's court regarding the violations of this article. (b) The owner or keeper of the animal shall be responsible for payment of all expenses associated with the impounding of the animal if it is determined by the recorder's court that the owner has violated any of the provisions of this article. (c) The recorder's court may order the city animal control department to euthanize an animal if the court determines that the animal is a vicious animal, the owner or keeper is guilty of violating one (1) or more provisions of this article, and the owner or keeper has either not timely exercised his appeal rights or has exhausted his appeal rights regarding the criminal conviction. (d) An animal control officer or any law enforcement officer may pursue a vicious animal onto private property to effect capture of the animal believed to be in violation of this article. Any law enforcement officer or animal control officer shall have the authority to enter onto private or public property for the purpose of ensuring compliance with the provisions of this article. (Ord. No. 07/8, §§ 4, 5, 9-17-2007; Ord. No. 18-01, § 1, 1-8-2018; Ord. No. 18-05, § 3, 2-12-2018) Sec. 5-47. - Registration of vicious animal. (a) It is unlawful for an owner or keeper to have or possess within the city limits a vicious animal without a certificate of registration issued by the animal control department in accordance with the provisions of this article. (b) The owner or keeper of a vicious animal must obtain a certificate of registration annually. (c) The animal control department shall issue a certificate of registration to the owner or keeper of a vicious animal if the animal control department finds sufficient evidence that the owner or keeper has complied with all of the provisions of this chapter, including those provisions regarding this article. (d) The owner or keeper of any vicious animal who brings a vicious animal into the city must satisfy all of the requirements of this article and register the vicious animal with the animal control department within ten (10) days of the arrival of the vicious animal in the city. (Ord. No. 07/8, §§ 4, 5, 9-17-2007) Sec. 5-48. - Maximum number of animals that may be kept on one residential property. No owner of a residential property in the city shall permit more than three (3) vicious animals to be kept or maintained upon any residential property. (Ord. No. 07/8, §§ 4, 5, 9-17-2007) Sec. 5-49. - Additional requirements of chapter 5 of the City Code of Ordinances. The regulations and requirements for vicious animals established by this article are in addition to the remaining requirements for all animals governed by chapter 5 of the City Code of Ordinances. Nothing contained in this article shall be deemed to relieve the owner or keeper of a vicious animal from compliance with the remaining provisions and regulations of chapter 5 of the City Code of Ordinances with respect to said vicious animal. In the event of a conflict between any regulations established by this article and the remaining regulations of chapter 5 of the City Code of Ordinances, the more stringent regulations shall govern. (Ord. No. 07/8, §§ 4, 5, 9-17-2007) Sec. 5-50. - Exemptions from vicious animal definition. (a) An animal that is being used by a law enforcement officer to carry out law enforcement duties shall not be considered a vicious animal within the meaning of this article or shall otherwise be in violation of this article. (b) An animal shall not be considered a vicious animal or otherwise in violation of this article if the injury inflicted by the animal was sustained by a person who, at the time, was committing a willful trespass or other tort, or committing or attempting to commit a crime, or was tormenting, abusing, or assaulting the animal, or had in the past been observed or reported to have tormented, abused, or assaulted the animal. (Ord. No. 07/8, §§ 4, 5, 9-17-2007) Sec. 5-51. - Violations. (a) The owner or keeper of a vicious animal that violates the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of high and aggravated nature. In addition to any confinement that might be imposed for a conviction under this article, for the first conviction a fine of not less than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00), for the second conviction a fine of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be imposed, and for a third or subsequent conviction a fine of not less than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) shall be imposed. (b) In addition, the maintenance of any vicious animal in noncompliance with the terms of this article shall also be deemed and declared a public nuisance and shall subject the owner or keeper to any and all penalties and remedies available under the laws of the State of Georgia and the ordinances of City of LaFayette relative to the abatement of a public nuisance. (Ord. No. 07/8, §§ 4, 5, 9-17-2007) Secs. 5-52—5-60. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - LIVESTOCK[4]
Footnotes: --- (4) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 02/05, §§ 1—7, adopted July 19, 2002 did not specify manner of codification, hence; inclusion of these provisions as Art. III, §§ 5-61—5-67 was at the discretion of the editor.
Sec. 5-61. - Definitions. For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein: Livestock means any domesticated animals of the type raised on a farm, and includes, but is not limited to, cattle, hogs, sheep, goats, horses, ponies, burros, llamas, or mules. The term person carries the same meaning as found in section 1-2. (Ord. No. 02/05, § 1, 7-19-2002) Sec. 5-62. - Restrictions. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, maintain or otherwise have livestock, either temporarily or permanently, on lots containing less than two (2) acres of permanent pasture land within the city. Said two (2) acres of permanent pasture land shall be measured so as to exclude any structures from the calculation of the required two (2) acre minimum. (b) Said restriction shall in no way affect the keeping of livestock for the limited and temporary purpose of licensed sales, including, but not limited to, auction sales. (c) Nothing in this section shall prohibit a show, carnival, fair, rodeo, or circus licensed by the city from displaying or using such animals in entertainment programs. (Ord. No. 02/05, § 2, 7-19-2002) Sec. 5-63. - Administration. It shall be the duty of the city manager, and such employees of the city as he may appoint, to administer and the animal control officer of the city to enforce the provisions of this article. The city manager and animal control officer of the city may enter upon private or public property to determine the presence of livestock thereon and to remove any such livestock existing thereon. (Ord. No. 02/05, § 3, 7-19-2002) Sec. 5-64. - Violations. (a) Whenever the city manager, or the animal control officer of the city, shall determine livestock to exist within the city in violation of this article, he shall issue a written notice to the owner or occupant of the premises on which the livestock is found specifying the violation of this article and requesting that the livestock be removed from the city within ten (10) days from the date the written notice is served as provided for in subsections (b) and (c) of this section. (b) Such written notice may be served personally, or by certified mail, on the owner of the land as shown on the most recent city ad valorem tax digest, or to the occupant if the owner is not in possession of the premises. (c) If it is not possible to serve notice to the owner by the above specified methods, the notice to him to remove the livestock may be given by posting such notice on the property where the livestock is found and, in addition, by posting such notice to a public bulletin board at the city hall. (Ord. No. 02/05, § 4, 7-19-2002) Sec. 5-65. - Removal. Ten (10) days after the date of service of the written notice requesting removal of the livestock from the city, the animal control officer of the city shall cause the livestock to be removed from the premises. Such livestock shall be disposed of in accordance with section 5-29. The owner and/or occupant of the premises from which the livestock is removed shall be liable to the city for any expenses incurred in removing and disposing of said livestock. (Ord. No. 02/05, § 5, 7-19-2002) Sec. 5-66. - Penalty. (a) Upon the failure, neglect, or refusal of any owner or occupant so notified to remove such livestock within the designated time given for such removal, the animal control officer of the city shall issue a citation for violation of this article. The citation and summons shall require the owner or occupant to appear in the municipal court of the city for violation of this article. Violation of this article may be punished by a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) and/or imprisonment of thirty (30) days. Each day following the expiration of the ten-day period provided for in the written notice served on the owner and/or occupier of the premises where livestock is found the owner or occupant fails to remove such livestock as set forth above shall be considered a separate offense. (b) The removal of the livestock from the premises prior to the expiration of the ten-day period provided for in subsection 5-64(a) shall be considered compliance with the provision of this article, and no further action shall be taken against the owner of the livestock or the owner or occupants of the premises. (Ord. No. 02/05, § 6, 7-19-2002) Sec. 5-67. - Liability. Neither the city, the city manager, or the city's agents or employees shall be liable for any loss or damage to the livestock while being removed or as a result of any subsequent sale or other disposition thereof. (Ord. No. 02/05, § 7, 7-19-2002)

div.head: Chapter 6 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Authority to adopt technical codes, § 5-23. Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 10; flood damage prevention, Ch. 11; health and sanitation, Ch. 12; planning, Ch. 17; utilities, Ch. 21. State Law reference— Buildings and housing. OCGA Title 8.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 6-1—6-15. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - BUILDING PERMIT REQUIREMENTS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Editor's note— The title to Article II has been changed from "Building Code," to its present title by the editor for classification purposes pursuant to the deletion of building code provisions therefrom. Cross reference— Georgia State Building Code adopted, § 6-121; schedule of permit fees, § 6-124.
Secs. 6-16, 6-17. - Reserved. Editor's note— An ordinance adopted Aug. 10, 1987, § 8, repealed the adoption and modifications of the building code set out in §§ 6-16 and 6-17, as derived from Code 1975, §§ 4-10 and 4-11. The city has adopted the Georgia State Building Code, as set out in § 6-121 of this chapter. Sec. 6-18. - Flood hazard provisions. (a) The building official shall review all building permit applications for new construction or substantial improvements to determine whether proposed building sites will be reasonably safe from flooding. If a proposed building site is in a location that has a flood hazard, any proposed new construction or substantial improvement, including prefabricated and mobile homes, must: (1) Be designed (or modified) and anchored to prevent flotation, collapse or lateral movement of the structure; (2) Use construction materials and utility equipment that are resistant to flood damage; and (3) Use construction methods and practices that will minimize flood damage. (b) The building official and city planning commission shall review subdivision proposals and other proposed new developments to assure that: (1) All such proposals are consistent with the need to minimize flood damage; (2) All public utilities and facilities, such as sewer, gas, electrical and water systems, are located, elevated and constructed to minimize or eliminate flood damage; and (3) Adequate drainage is provided so as to reduce exposure to flood hazards. (c) The building official shall require new or replacement water supply systems and sanitary sewage systems to be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of floodwaters into the systems and discharges from the systems into floodwaters, and require on-site waste disposal systems to be located so as to avoid impairment of them or contamination from them during flooding. (Code 1975, § 4-12) Cross reference— Flood damage prevention, Ch. 11; planning, Ch. 17. Sec. 6-19. - Health inspection. Before any building permit shall be issued for new construction which will not be connected to the city sewer system, the applicant shall furnish proof that the building site has been inspected and approved by the county health department. (Code 1975, § 4-13) Cross reference— Health and sanitation, Ch. 12. Sec. 6-20. - Water-saving installations required; exceptions. (a) Definitions. [As used in this section, the following words shall have the meaning ascribed thereto:] (1) Commercial means any type of building other than residential. (2) Construction means the erection of a new building or the alteration of an existing building in connection with its repair or renovation or in connection with making an addition to an existing building and shall include the replacement of a malfunctioning, unserviceable, or obsolete faucet, showerhead, toilet, or urinal in an existing building. (3) Residential means any building or unit of a building intended for occupancy as a dwelling but shall not include a hotel or motel. (b) Residential, prohibited installations. On or after July 1, 1991, no construction may be initiated within the city for any residential building of any type which: (1) Employs a gravity tank-type, flushometer-valve or flushometer-tank toilet that uses more than an average of one and six tenths (1.6) gallons of water per flush; provided, however, this paragraph shall not be applicable to one-piece toilets until July 1, 1992; (2) Employs a shower head that allows a flow of more than an average of two and one half (2.5) gallons of water per minute at sixty (60) pounds per square inch of pressure; (3) Employs a urinal that uses more than an average of one and zero tenths (1.0) gallons of water per flush; (4) Employs a lavatory faucet or lavatory replacement aerator that allows a flow or more than two and zero tenths (2.0) gallons of water per minute; or (5) Employs a kitchen faucet or kitchen replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than two and one half (2.5) gallons of water per minute. (c) Commercial, prohibited installations. On or after July 1, 1992, there shall be no construction of any commercial building initiated within the city for any commercial building of any type which does not meet the requirements of subparagraph (b)(1) through (5) of this section. (d) Repair, renovation or addition. The requirement of subsection (b) shall apply to any residential construction initiated after July 1, 1991, and to any commercial construction initiated after July 1, 1992, which involves the repair or renovation of or addition to any existing building when such repair or renovation of or addition to such existing building includes replacement of toilets or showers or both. (e) Exemptions. New construction and the repair or renovation of an existing building shall be exempt from the requirements of subsections (b), (c) and (d) when: (1) The repair or renovation of the existing building does not include the replacement of the plumbing or sewage system servicing toilets, faucets or shower heads within such existing buildings; or (2) When such plumbing or sewage system within such existing building, because of its capacity, design or installation would not function properly if the toilets, faucets or shower heads required by this section were installed; or (3) Such system is a well or gravity flow from a spring and is owned privately by an individual for use in such individual's personal residence; or (4) Units to be installed are: a. Specifically designed for use by the handicapped; b. Specifically designed to withstand unusual abuse or installation in a penal institution; or c. Toilets for juveniles. (f) Exemption application; inspection fee. The owner, or his agent, of a building undergoing new construction or repair or renovation who is entitled to an exemption as specified in subparagraph (e)(2), (3) or (4) of this section shall obtain the exemption by applying at city hall, City of Lafayette. A fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be charged for the inspection and issuance of such exemption. The building official shall review the application, and deny said application or issue the exemption. (g) Enforcement; penalty. (1) This section shall be enforced by the building official for the city. Citations for violations may be issued by said building official. (2) Any person, corporation, partnership or other entity violating this section shall be tried before the recorder's court of the city. Upon conviction, a violation of the section may be punished by a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) and or imprisonment not to exceed five (5) days. Such provisions did not specify manner of codification, but have been designated by the editor as § 6-20. Cross reference— Water conservation during drought, § 21-141 et seq. Sec. 6-21. - Covering openings of constructions. (a) Purpose and findings. (1) The purpose of this section is to protect against the pernicious effects which result from the placement of boards, including plywood or other wooden materials, over the doors, windows, or other coverings of constructions within the city. The pernicious effects sought to be remedied by this section include the reduction of property value caused by boarding of constructions, the spread of blight, the increase of crime associated with areas in and around such boarded constructions, and to preserve and promote the aesthetics of the city. The provisions of this section represent a balancing of the competing interests of property owners and occupants to protect the openings of constructions from naturally occurring damage and vandalism and the city's interest in protecting against decreases in property valuation, blight, and crime. (2) The city's governing authority finds that constructions boarded with plywood or other wood based materials have been linked with decreases in the property values to both the affected property and other properties within the vicinity, are linked to an increase in crimes such as vandalism, squatting, drug crimes, and in some cases, violent crimes, and otherwise contribute to the spread of blight within a community. The city's governing authority thus finds that it is best to prohibit the usage of such boarding materials on constructions within the city in order to protect the health, safety, and welfare of its citizenry. As used in this section, these terms have the following meanings: (b) Definitions . As used in this section, these terms have the following meanings: City means the City of Lafayette, Georgia. Construction means any building, dwelling, or other structure, or part thereof, used and occupied for human habitation or commercial, industrial, or business uses, or intended to be so used, and includes any outhouses, improvements, and appurtenances belonging thereto or usually enjoyed therewith and also includes any building or structure of any design. As used in this section, the term "construction" does not mean or include any building or structure located on a farm, or any agricultural facility or other building or structure used for the production, growing, raising, harvesting, storage, or processing of crops, livestock, poultry, or other farm products. Occupant means any person or persons who lease property from an owner as defined in this section or otherwise are in possession of a property and premises. Owner means the holder of the title in fee simple and every mortgagee of record, whether a person, firm, association, or corporation. (c) Permit required for covering openings of constructions. (1) Owners and occupants are prohibited from erecting, installing, placing, or maintaining any covering over doors, windows, or any other openings of any construction by any means other than the conventional methods used in the original building and design of the construction without first obtaining a valid permit in accordance with this section. (2) Any construction with boards, including plywood, or any other wood based material, or metal, or any other non-transparent covering any door, window, or other opening and existing at the time of adoption of this section will have sixty (60) days from the date of adoption to remove such boarding and submit an application to the city for a permit in accordance with this section. (3) Notwithstanding the permit requirement imposed by subsection (b)(1), above, a permit is not required to cover the opening of a construction for up to a maximum of thirty (30) days in the event of a temporary emergency situation, including, but not limited to, damage caused by vandalism, theft, or weather. In the event an emergency situation requires the opening of a construction to be covered for more than thirty (30) days, the owner or occupant or his/her authorized representative must obtain either a valid building permit for repair or a valid permit in accordance with this section. (d) Requirements for issuance of permit. (1) The city may issue a permit only upon satisfaction of the following conditions: a. Submission of a written application by the owner or occupant of the property or his authorized representative, including the following information: 1. Name, address and telephone number of the owner or occupant; 2. Name, address and telephone number of any local agent of the owner or occupant; 3. Tax parcel identification number of the premises on which the structure is situated; 4. Common address of the structure; and 5. Any other information as may be required by the city. b. Payment of the required fee by the owner or occupant or his/her authorized representative. c. Submission of a written statement or plan by the owner or occupant of the property or his authorized representative specifying: 1. Proposed length of time the owner or occupant expects the covering to continue; 2. Proposed plan to cover the opening of the construction, including a detailed description regarding the manner and materials; 3. Proposed maintenance plan detailing the monitoring and maintenance of the structure and premises in conformance with this section. (2) Following the issuance of a permit under this section, the city may conduct an inspection of the construction to ensure that its opening is covered in accordance with the plan approved by the department. (e) Rights of owner or occupant to cover openings of construction under permit. (1) A permit issued under this section may authorize an owner or occupant to place a clear and transparent protective material, to be comprised of poly (methyl methacrylate) or polycarbonate or like material, over a door, window, or any other opening of a construction to secure the construction. The use of wooden boards, plywood, other wood based material, metal, or any other non-transparent material to cover or secure any door, window, or other opening of a construction is prohibited within the city. (2) The opening of a construction may be covered or secured under subsection (d)(1), above, for a maximum period of six (6) months. An owner or occupant desiring to continue to use protective material on a construction beyond the six-month maximum term must submit a renewal application to the city prior to thirty (30) days of the expiration of the original permit upon payment of necessary fees. A new permit must be obtained if the original permit is not renewed before thirty (30) days of the expiration of the original permit, a copy of which must be posted on any construction which is covered or secured under this section. (3) The covering or securing of doors, windows, or other openings of any building or structure or any means of securing such openings, other than by the conventional method used in the original construction and design of the building or structure, must be according to the specifications approved under the permit. (4) Notwithstanding the provisions of subsections (d)(1) through (3), above, in the case of an emergency, as described in subsection (b)(3), an opening of a construction may be covered or secured by wooden boards, plywood, or other wood based material for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days, after which time a permit must be obtained under this section and the boarding must be removed to be covered or secured in compliance with subsections (d)(1) through (3) of this section. However, any boarding used by an owner or occupant in the event of an emergency must be painted with a minimum of two (2) coats of exterior paint which is of a color compatible with the exterior color of the building or structure. (f) Enforcement, violations, and penalties. (1) This section is to be enforced, including the determination of any violations and administration of any penalties, as provided under the procedures set forth in the city's Blighted and Derelict Property Ordinance as codified in Chapter 6, Article XI, sections 6-218 through 6-228.
