Sec. 6-91. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Mobile home means a movable or portable dwelling over thirty-two (32) feet in length and over eight (8) feet wide, constructed to be towed on its own chassis, connected to utilities and designed without a permanent foundation for year-round occupancy, which can consist of one (1) or more components that can be retracted for towing purposes and subsequently expanded for additional capacity, or of two (2) or more units separately towable but designed to be joined into an integral unit. Mobile home toter is a term used by the mobile home industry to denote the vehicle used to tow a mobile home. For vehicles manufactured prior to the 1979 model year, a ten-foot toter is a truck measuring approximately ten (10) feet from the forward edge of the front bumper to the center of the trailer hitch ball, and a fifteen-foot toter measures approximately fifteen (15) feet between these two (2) points and is a two and one-half ton truck. For vehicles manufactured in the 1979 model year and subsequent model years, a ten-foot toter is a truck with a wheel base of seventy-seven (77) inches or more and a manufacturer's GVW rating of sixteen thousand (16,000) pounds or more and approximately ten (10) feet between the forward edge of the front bumper and the center of the trailer hitch ball and a fifteen-foot toter is a truck with a wheel base of one hundred sixteen (116) inches or more and a manufacturer's GVW rating of twenty thousand (20,000) pounds or more and approximately fifteen (15) feet between the forward edge of the front bumper and the center of the trailer hitch ball. Modular home means a house composed of two (2) sections of reinforced concrete or reinforced concrete block, each section being no more than fourteen (14) feet wide and capable of assembly into a complete house. Person means a "person" as defined in OCGA section 32-1-3, as well as the operator of a permitted vehicle or load. Portable building means a building not to exceed one hundred forty-four (144) inches in width composed of one (1) section completely preassembled with roof, floor and all outside walls to be used for a purpose other than a dwelling. Sectional house means a preassembled section, not more than fourteen (14) feet wide, composed of a floor, roof and outside walls which does not have a towable chassis, but is designed to be loaded on a trailer or dolly and transported to a site where it is placed on a permanent foundation so that, when attached to one (1) or more other sections, it becomes a dwelling. (Ord. of 12-10-79, § 1) Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. Sec. 6-92. - General restrictions on issuance of permits. (a) No permit shall be issued to an automobile carrier over sixty (60) feet long or double bottom or twin trailers, regardless of length. (b) No permit shall be issued for transporting a load in excess of fifty-five (55) feet in length and of the type load otherwise excepted from such general length limitation by the provisions of OCGA section 32-6-24, if such a load is capable of being sawed, separated, rearranged or otherwise dismantled so as to make inapplicable the provisions of OCGA section 32-6-24. (c) No permit shall be issued if the issuance of the permit in any way jeopardizes federal funds appropriated to this state under the provisions of Title 23 of the U.S. Code. (d) No single trip permit or approved route permit shall be issued authorizing in excess of one (1) allowable travel day, which must be for a day when that type of permitted load is authorized to travel, as specified in this article. (Ord. of 12-10-79, § 2) Sec. 6-93. - Conditions attached to issuance of permits. In addition to compliance with any other conditions imposed on the issuance of a particular permit, any person receiving a permit from the city thereby certifies that he will comply or has complied (as applicable) with the following conditions governing the operation of the permitted vehicle or load. When intentional, or due to gross negligence, a violation of any of the following conditions is unlawful and punishable as a misdemeanor and may be considered as evidence supporting action to suspend, revoke or deny a permit: (1) Federal and state laws, regulations, city ordinances. The permittee will comply or has complied with the applicable laws and regulations of the United States and of this state and city, including, but not limited to, those of the U. S. Interstate Commerce Commission, the state public service commission, the state department of public safety, the state department of revenue and OCGA Title 32. (2) Movement of vehicle, load. Unless otherwise shown on the permit or further limited by specific rules provided in this article, the permittee will ensure that the movement of a permitted vehicle or load will take place only on Monday through Saturday, from thirty (30) minutes after sunrise to thirty (30) minutes before sunset, Eastern Standard Time or Eastern Daylight Saving Time, whichever is in effect for the period of year during which the movement occurs. Provided further, he will make sure that no permitted vehicle or load will be moved during foggy weather, during snow or icy conditions or during the following legal holidays: New Year's Day, Memorial Day, July 4th, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day, and December 25th. (3) Route of travel. The permittee will not operate the permitted load or vehicle over any public road or street in the city other than those described or allowed in the permit, provided that he will comply with the load limitations of any bridge or which limitation has been established by the posting of an embargo sign on any public road in the state and the city. (4) Distance between vehicles. The operator of a permitted vehicle and load shall maintain fifty-foot intervals between each vehicle load. In addition, when the normal flow of traffic becomes impeded, such vehicle or load shall move off the traveled portion of the public road until such traffic congestion has been cleared. Normal movement may then be resumed until another traffic congestion occurs. (5) Escorts. The permittee will comply with the requirements of section 6-95. (6) Marking of vehicle and load. The permittee will comply with the requirements of sections 6-94—6-96. (7) Liability insurance and other security. The permittee has in effect and shall maintain during the existence of the permit public liability and property damage insurance in at least the following amounts: public liability, three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) each accident; one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) each person injured; total property damage, fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00). However, nothing in this section shall prevent the city from requiring any additional undertaking or security as may be deemed necessary to compensate the city for any injury to any public road therein, including a bridge. Upon request the person receiving a permit shall furnish the city the number of the policy of insurance required in this section as well as the address of the insurance company. Nothing contained in this section shall be construed so as to make the city liable for any damage to a public road or bridge or to persons or private property caused by a permitted load or vehicle, or its escort vehicle. The person receiving the permit thereby promises to hold the city harmless from such claims and to recompense the city or a political subdivision for any expenditures made by the city or other political subdivision for any expenditures made by the city or other political subdivision to repair damages caused by the permitted vehicle or load to a public road of the state highway system, of a county road system or of a municipal street system, as applicable. (8) Leased vehicles. The permittee will ensure that the operator of a leased vehicle carries on his person written proof of the identity of the lessee. (9) Single-trip permit. The permittee will not allow the single-trip permit to be used other than for the movement by the particular vehicle for which the permit was issued. Further, he will not allow the single-trip permit to be transmitted again by facsimile machine, retyping or reproducing. (Ord. of 12-10-79, § 3) Sec. 6-94. - Special conditions attached to certain permits. (a) Houses. In addition to the conditions set forth in section 6-93, a person receiving a permit for the movement of a house certifies that he will or has complied, as applicable, with the following conditions: (1) He will use the following minimum equipment for moving the house: a tandem truck, one (1) set of tandem dollies in good condition, and one (1) extra skidder or wrecker in good condition or capable of moving the whole load in case of a breakdown; (2) He has measured the house and has, prior to applying for the permit, checked the route stated in this application for permit to ensure obstacle clearance and necessary places periodically to pull off of the road for the purpose of preventing unnecessary traffic congestion; (3) Before moving the house, all masonry will be removed from a masonry-veneered house; (4) All mailboxes, highway signs and other movable obstacles to the move of the house shall be removed as the house approaches such an obstacle and reerected immediately after the house passes such obstacle in equal or better condition than it was prior to removal; (5) The movement of the house will be confined to the route stated in the application, and in no case will exceed the total distance of three (3) miles in city streets; and (6) A house will be moved only on Mondays through Thursdays between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 5:00 a.m. Application for the movement of a house shall be made at least twenty-four (24) hours before the time of movement applied for. (b) Modular homes. The special conditions stated in subsection (a) above, other than the conditions of subsection (a)(6), likewise apply to the movement of a modular home. In addition, before a permit will be issued for a move of a modular home, the applicant for a permit must have provided the city with a plan of the home, certified by a professional engineer to be able to withstand the movement applied for. If the construction plan of such modular home filed with the application for a permit has been changed prior to movement, a new application for a permit must be filed. (c) Mobile homes, modular homes, sectional houses, portable buildings in excess of ten feet wide. In addition to the conditions set forth in section 6-93, a person, by accepting a permit for the movement of a mobile home, modular home or sectional house in excess of ten (10) feet wide up to a maximum of fourteen (14) feet wide, or a portable building in excess of ten (10) feet wide up to and including twelve (12) feet wide, agrees that he will or has complied with or he understands, as applicable, the following conditions: (1) Approval shall be obtained for a specific route for each movement and this movement will follow the approved route stated on the permit. Routes submitted for travel on a street or road with a single travel lane in each direction of travel with lane width less than twelve (12) feet wide and each shoulder five (5) feet wide or routes with bridges with less than twenty-eight (28) feet between curbs will not normally be approved for travel unless there is no alternative. Since certain obstructions may exist on the approved route which occasionally restrict the clear shoulder or pavement width, the driver of the towing vehicle shall be responsible for exercising additional caution at such locations. (2) Unless otherwise shown on the permit, the movement of a mobile home, modular home or sectional house in excess of twelve (12) feet wide will take place only on Tuesdays through Thursdays between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 2:30 p.m., Eastern Standard Time or Eastern Daylight Saving Time, whichever is in effect for the period of the year during which the movement occurs. (3) Unless otherwise shown on the permit, the movement of a mobile home, modular home, sectional house or portable building in excess of ten (10) feet wide, up to and including twelve (12) feet wide, will take place only on Mondays through Saturdays, from thirty (30) minutes after sunrise to thirty (30) minutes before sunset. (4) Signs, escorts and flags shall be provided, as required by subsequent sections of this article. (5) For mobile homes, modular homes, sectional houses or portable buildings, in excess of ten (10) feet wide, ensure that the load does not exceed a maximum speed of twenty-five (25) miles-per-hour. The preceding is the maximum authorized speed under any condition. The driver shall be responsible for driving at a speed that is prudent and safe for the conditions. (6) For mobile homes, modular homes and sectional houses in excess of twelve (12) feet wide, using a towing vehicle no smaller than a fifteen-foot mobile home toter, and not exceeding a total overall combination length of eighty-five (85) feet with all axles of the mobile home or trailer or dolly transporting a modular home or sectional house equipped with properly functioning brakes. Brakes of the towing vehicle shall be in accordance with OCGA sections 40-8-50—40-8-54, and the towing vehicle shall have a current state inspection sticker or the equivalent from the state of license. (7) Mobile homes, modular homes or sectional houses up to and including twelve (12) feet wide will not be permitted with an overall length, including the towing vehicle, in excess of eighty-three (83) feet, and shall have a towing vehicle no smaller than a ten-foot mobile home toter. Mobile homes manufactured prior to August 30, 1977, may be permitted with an overall length, including the ten-foot towing vehicle, up to and including eighty-eight (88) feet, when approved by the city. Mobile homes up to and including twelve (12) feet wide will be permitted when the towing vehicle is no smaller than what is commonly referred to as a fifteen-foot mobile home toter. Brakes of all towing vehicles shall be in accordance with OCGA sections 40-8-50—40-8-54, and the towing vehicle shall have a current state inspection sticker or the equivalent from the state of license. Brakes on mobile homes up to and including twelve (12) feet wide shall be in accordance with state law as a minimum, but in no case will less than one-half of the axles be equipped with properly functioning brakes. Brakes on mobile homes or trailers or dollies transporting modular homes or sectional houses up to and including twelve (12) feet wide shall be in accordance with OCGA sections 40-8-50—40-8-54. (8) In addition to the weather conditions mentioned in section 6-93, mobile homes, modular homes or sectional houses in excess of twelve (12) feet wide will not travel when it is raining or when the ground wind exceeds twenty-five (25) miles per hour. When such conditions exist, the driver shall proceed to the first area where the load can be safely removed from the roadway. (9) All necessary safety precautions shall be employed in crossing narrow bridges, including flagging other traffic, to permit safe crossing. (10) Within twenty-four (24) hours the permittee shall notify the city police department, on form SR13, of any accident occurring on a public road regardless of the amount of damage. This report shall include, as part of the information, the specific size of the mobile home, modular home, sectional house or portable building. When audits of records indicate that this provision has not been complied with, the mobile home, modular home, sectional house or portable building permits of the offending company may be revoked. (11) All persons driving a vehicle pulling a mobile home, modular home, sectional house or portable building shall have a class 5 Georgia driver's license or his home state's equivalent license. (12) In addition to complying with all applicable federal and state laws and regulations, comply with applicable county and municipal ordinances when traveling off the state highway system. (13) In addition to the signs required by section 6-96, mobile homes, modular homes and sectional houses in excess of twelve (12) feet wide up to and including fourteen (14) feet wide must have signs stating the permitted load width (e.g., "14 FEET WIDE"). These signs shall be of the same size and color as the "OVERSIZE LOAD" signs and shall be located on both the front and rear upper portion of the mobile home, modular home or sectional house. (Ord. of 12-10-79, § 4) Sec. 6-95. - Escorts of permitted vehicles or loads. (a) Equipment. An escort vehicle shall be an automobile or pickup truck and shall be equipped with a revolving amber light at least eight (8) inches in diameter, located on top of the vehicle. The light shall have a minimum candlepower of thirty-five thousand (35,000) and shall rotate so as to provide at least eighty (80) revolutions per minute. The operator shall have obtained a permit from the state department of public safety for the use of the light as required by the department under state law. Escort vehicles and the vehicle transporting the permitted load will also be equipped with two-way radios, in good working order, so that the driver will have constant radio contact with the driver of the permitted load and other escorts of the same load. The rear escort vehicle driver will advise the driver of the load and the front escort, when applicable, as to the traffic conditions behind the movement. When four (4) or more vehicles overtake and follow an overdimensional vehicle, the escort vehicles and the permitted load shall pull over and allow the traffic to pass. The driver of the front and rear escort vehicles shall maintain sufficient separation between their vehicles and the permitted load so as to provide adequate warning of the presence of the overdimensional load. Escort vehicles will have current state inspection stickers or the equivalent from the state of license. (b) Signs. A sign shall be mounted on the front of the escort vehicle (for a front escort) and to the rear of the escort vehicle (for a rear escort). Such sign shall contain the wording "OVERSIZE LOAD" for overlength and overwidth movements. The letters shall be black on an orange or yellow backboard and shall be at least eight (8) inches high and four (4) inches wide. The backboard shall be at least one (1) foot high and six (6) feet wide. (c) When escorts required: (1) As a condition to the issuance of a permit, the city, when it deems it necessary in the interest of public safety, in any case may require the use of a front or rear escort, or both. (2) It shall be an unlawful act punishable as a misdemeanor for any person to operate upon a public street or road of the city any equipment exempted from permit requirements by the provisions of OCGA section 32-6-24 or section 32-6-25 when such exempted equipment is wider than one (1) lane of such public road and the operator of such exempted equipment has not provided both front and rear escorts therefor. (3) Otherwise, the following escort requirements apply: a. Boats over twelve (12) feet wide, front and rear escorts; b. Heavy equipment: 1. Over seventy-five (75) feet long, rear escort or, in lieu thereof, a revolving amber light located on the rearmost point of the load. The amber light must conform with the requirements of subsection (a) above, including the securing of a permit for its use from the state department of public safety. 2. Over twelve (12) feet wide, front and rear escorts. c. House, front and rear escorts, the front escort being a police car. d. Mobile home, modular home, portable building, sectional house, for each unit up to and including twelve (12) feet wide and seventy-five (75) feet overall length, no escorts. For each unit up to and including twelve (12) feet wide and longer than seventy-five (75) feet overall length, not to exceed a maximum of eighty-eight (88) feet overall length, a rear escort or, in lieu thereof, a revolving amber light located on both rear corners of the load. The amber light must conform with the requirements of subsection (a) above, including the securing of a permit for their use from the state department of public safety. For each mobile home or modular home or sectional house unit in excess of twelve (12) feet wide, not to exceed a maximum of fourteen (14) feet wide and eighty-five (85) feet overall length, the city may require both front and rear escort vehicles. e. Poles, logs and other loads exempt from general length limitations by the provisions of OCGA section 32-6-24, longer than seventy-five (75) feet, rear escort or, in lieu thereof, a revolving amber light must conform with the requirements of subsection (a) above, including the securing of a permit for its use from the state department of public safety. (Ord. of 12-10-79, § 5) Sec. 6-96. - Marking of oversize vehicles or loads. A sign of the same type required for an escort vehicle under the provisions of section 6-95(b) shall be mounted on both the front and rear of a load with eight (8) feet in width. Such signs shall be removed when an oversize load is no longer being transported by a vehicle that is no wider than eight (8) feet. In addition, a square red flag, eighteen (18) inches on a side, shall be displayed at the corners of both sides of such overwidth vehicle or load, at both the front and rear thereof. (Ord. of 12-10-79, § 6) Sec. 6-97. - Application for permits. (a) Address of office of permits and enforcement. Written applications for a permit required by this article should be addressed to: Clerk of City of Lafayette, P. O. Box 89, LaFayette, Georgia 30728. (b) Procedure: (1) Application for single-trip permit. An application for a single-trip permit may be made by telephone, by letter or in person, giving the applicable information required. The permit fee shall be transmitted to the city clerk prior to the issuance of the permit. Such payment may be made by company check, cash, money order or by certified or cashier's check. A personal check will not be accepted. Checks and money orders shall be made payable to the order of city. (2) Issuance of single-trip permit. The city clerk, as requested in the application, may use any of the following methods to transmit a single-trip permit to the applicant: by mail, Western Union telegram or presentation in person. (3) Fees for permits: a. Movement of houses—The fee for a housemoving permit shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00). b. All other permits—The fee for all other permits provided by this article shall be as set from time to time and a schedule of such fees is on file in the city clerk's office. c. The fees provided for above are for the purpose of helping to defray the expenses of enforcing the limitations set forth in this article and are to be used for public street maintenance purposes. d. Other fees—In addition to the fees required above, the permittee or applicant shall be responsible for payment to the city for all expenses incurred by the city in providing a police escort, the movement of utility lines, and any other similar expenses incurred by the city in connection with use of the city streets in the manner authorized by the permit. The city, through its city clerk, may require a reasonable advance deposit from the applicant for this purpose prior to issuing a permit. Sec. 6-151. - Purpose. In order to provide for the health, safety, and welfare of the public and a healthy economic climate within the city and surrounding communities, it is essential that the quality of the public drinking water be assured. The ability of natural systems to filter stormwater runoff can be threatened by unrestricted development. Land disturbing activities associated with development can increase erosion and sedimentation that threatens the storage capacity of reservoirs. In addition, stormwater runoff, particularly from impervious surfaces, can introduce toxins, nutrients and sediment into drinking water supplies, making water treatment more complicated and expensive and rendering waters unusable for recreation. Industrial land uses that involve the manufacture, use, transport, and storage of hazardous or toxic waste materials result in the potential risk of contamination of nearby public drinking water supplies. The purpose of this article is to establish measures to protect the quality and quantity of the present and future water supply of the city; to minimize the transport of pollutants and sediment to the water supply; and to maintain the yield of the water supply watershed. This article shall apply to all existing and proposed water supply watersheds in the city. (Ord. No. 01-1, § I, 1-8-2001) Sec. 6-152. - Definitions. Buffer means a natural or enhanced vegetated area with no or limited minor land disturbances, such as trails and picnic areas, located adjacent to reservoirs or perennial streams within a water supply watershed. Corridor means all land within the buffer areas established adjacent to reservoirs or perennial streams within a water supply watershed and within other setback areas specified in section 21-164 of this article. Impervious surface means a manmade structure or surface that prevents infiltration of stormwater into the ground below the structure or surface. Examples are buildings, roads, driveways, parking lots, decks, swimming pools, or patios. Large water supply watershed means a watershed equal to or greater than one hundred (100) square miles of land within the drainage basin upstream of a governmentally owned public drinking water supply intake. Perennial stream means a stream that flows throughout the whole year as indicated on a USGS quad map. Reservoir boundary means the edge of a water supply reservoir defined by its normal pool level. Small water supply watershed means a watershed that contains less than one hundred (100) square miles of land within the drainage basin upstream of a governmentally owned public drinking water supply intake. Utility means public or private water or sewer piping systems, water or sewer pumping stations, electric power lines, fuel pipelines, telephone lines, roads, driveways, bridges, river/lake access facilities, stormwater systems and railroads or other utilities identified by a local government. Water supply reservoir means a governmentally owned impoundment of water for the primary purpose of providing drinking water to one (1) or more governmentally owned public drinking water systems. This excludes the multipurpose reservoirs owned by the U. S. Army Corp of Engineers. Water supply watershed means the area upstream of a governmentally owned public drinking water intake. (Ord. No. 01-1, § II, 1-8-2001; Ord. No. 01-6, § I, 6-11-2001) Sec. 6-153. - Establishment of a water supply watershed district. The Dry Creek Water Supply Watershed District is hereby designated and shall comprise the land that drains to the city public water supply intake. The boundary of the overlay is defined by the ridgeline of the watershed and the boundary of a radius of seven (7) miles upstream of the public water supply intake or reservoir. This overlay shall be further delineated and defined on the Water Supply Watershed Protection District Overlay Map of the city LaFayette ("map"). The map is hereby incorporated into and made part of this article by reference. The following water supply watershed district is hereby defined and the boundary shall be identified on the map. Dry Creek is a small water supply watershed. An intake for the city is located on this creek. This water supply watershed does not contain a reservoir. (Ord. No. 01-1, § III, 1-8-2001) Sec. 6-154. - Protection criteria. The following regulations shall apply to the Dry Creek water supply watershed identified on the map as a small water supply watershed. (1) The corridors of all perennial streams within a seven-mile radius upstream of a governmentally owned intake or water supply reservoir must be protected by the following criteria. a. A buffer shall be maintained for a distance of one hundred (100) feet on both sides of the stream as measured from the stream banks. b. No impervious surface shall be constructed within a one hundred fifty-foot setback area on both sides of the stream as measured from the stream banks. c. Septic tanks and septic tank drain fields are prohibited in the one hundred fifty-foot setback area as described in subsection (1)b. above. (2) The corridors of all perennial streams outside a seven-mile radius upstream of a governmentally owned public drinking water supply intake or water supply reservoir must be protected by the following criteria. a. A buffer shall be maintained for a distance of fifty (50) feet on both sides of the stream as measured from the stream banks. b. No impervious surface shall be constructed within a seventy-five-foot setback area on both sides of the stream as measured from the stream banks. c. Septic tanks and septic tank drain fields are prohibited in the seventy-five-foot setback area as described in subsection (2)b. above. (3) The impervious surface area, including all public and private structures, utilities, or facilities, of the entire water supply watershed shall be limited to twenty-five (25) percent, or existing use, whichever is greater. (4) New facilities which handle hazardous material of the types listed in Section 312 of the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act of 1976 (excluding underground storage tanks) and amounts of ten thousand (10,000) pounds on any one (1) day or more shall perform their operations on impervious surfaces and in conformance with any applicable federal spill prevention requirements or the requirements of the Standard Fire Prevention Code. (Ord. No. 01-1, § IV, 1-8-2001) Sec. 6-155. - Exemptions. The following uses shall be exempted: (1) Land uses existing prior to the adoption of this article. (2) Mining activities permitted by the Department of Natural Resources under the Surface Mining Act. (3) Utilities from the stream corridor buffer and setback area provisions in accordance with the following conditions if the utilities to be located in the buffer or setback areas cannot feasibly be located outside of these areas: a. The utilities shall be located as far from the stream bank as reasonably possible. b. The installation and maintenance of the utilities shall be such to protect the integrity of the buffer and setback areas as best as reasonably possible. c. The utilities shall not impair the quality of the drinking water system. (4) Specific forestry and agricultural activities in the stream corridor buffer and setback areas in accordance with the following conditions: a. The activity shall be consistent with the best management practices established by the Georgia Forestry Commission or Georgia Department of Agriculture. b. The activity shall not impair the quality of the drinking water system. (Ord. No. 01-1, § V, 1-8-2001) Sec. 6-156. - Administration and enforcement.
