(Ord. No. 07/6, Art. 3, § A, 8-14-2007) Sec. 11-17. - Permit procedures. Application for a development permit shall be made to the building official or engineer on forms furnished by the community prior to any development activities, and may include, but not be limited to the following: plans in duplicate drawn to scale showing the elevations of the area in question and the nature, location, dimensions, of existing or proposed structures, earthen fill placement, storage of materials or equipment, and drainage facilities. Specifically, the following information is required: (1) Application stage. a. Elevation in relation to mean sea level (or highest adjacent grade) of the lowest floor, including basement, of all proposed structures; b. Elevation in relation to mean sea level to which any nonresidential structure will be floodproofed; c. Design certification from a registered professional engineer or architect that any proposed nonresidential floodproofed structure will meet the floodproofing criteria of subsection 11-27(2); d. Description of the extent to which any watercourse will be altered or relocated as a result of a proposed development, and; (2) Construction stage. For all new construction and substantial improvements, the permit holder shall provide to the administrator an as-built certification of the regulatory floor elevation or floodproofing level immediately after the lowest floor or floodproofing is completed. Any lowest floor certification made relative to mean sea level shall be prepared by or under the direct supervision of a registered land surveyor or professional engineer and certified by same. When floodproofing is utilized for nonresidential structures, said certification shall be prepared by or under the direct supervision of a professional engineer or architect and certified by same. Any work undertaken prior to submission of these certifications shall be at the permit holder's risk. The building official or city engineer shall review the above referenced certification data submitted. Deficiencies detected by such review shall be corrected by the permit holder immediately and prior to further progressive work being allowed to proceed. Failure to submit certification or failure to make said corrections required hereby, shall be cause to issue a stop-work order for the project. (Ord. No. 07/6, Art. 3, § B, 8-14-2007) Sec. 11-18. - Duties and responsibilities of the administrator. Duties of the building official or city engineer shall include, but shall not be limited to: (1) Review proposed development to assure that the permit requirements of this chapter have been satisfied. (2) Review proposed development to assure that all necessary permits have been received from governmental agencies from which approval is required by federal or state law, including section 404 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act Amendments of 1972, 33 U.S.C. 1334. Require that copies of such permits be provided and maintained on file. (3) Review all permit applications to determine whether proposed building sites will be reasonably safe from flooding. (4) When base flood elevation data or floodway data have not been provided in accordance with section 11-3, then the building official or city engineer shall obtain, review and reasonably utilize any base flood elevation and floodway data available from a federal, state or other sources in order to administer the provisions of article III. (5) Review and record the actual elevation in relation to mean sea level (or highest adjacent grade) of the lowest floor, including basement, of all new or substantially improved structures in accordance with subsection 11-17(2). (6) Review and record the actual elevation, in relation to mean sea level to which any new or substantially improved structures have been floodproofed, in accordance with subsection 11-17(2). (7) When floodproofing is utilized for a structure, the building official or city engineer shall obtain certification of design criteria from a registered professional engineer or architect in accordance with subsection 11-17(1)c and 11-27(2) or subsection 11-29(2). (8) Make substantial damage determinations following a flood event or any other event that causes damage to structures in flood hazard areas. (9) Notify adjacent communities and the Georgia Department of Natural Resources prior to any alteration or relocation of a watercourse and submit evidence of such notification to the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA). (10) For any altered or relocated watercourse, submit engineering data/analysis within six (6) months to the FEMA to ensure accuracy of community flood maps through the letter of map revision process. Assure flood carrying capacity of any altered or relocated watercourse is maintained. (11) Where interpretation is needed as to the exact location of boundaries of the areas of special flood hazard (for example, where there appears to be a conflict between a mapped boundary and actual field conditions) the building official or city engineer shall make the necessary interpretation. Any person contesting the location of the boundary shall be given a reasonable opportunity to appeal the interpretation as provided in this chapter. (12) All records pertaining to the provisions of this chapter shall be maintained in the office of the building official or city engineer and shall be open for public inspection. (Ord. No. 07/6, Art. 3, § C, 8-14-2007) Secs. 11-19—11-25. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - PROVISIONS FOR FLOOD HAZARD REDUCTION
Sec. 11-26. - General standards. In all areas of special flood hazard the following provisions are required: (1) New construction and substantial improvements of existing structures shall be anchored to prevent flotation, collapse or lateral movement of the structure; (2) New construction and substantial improvements of existing structures shall be constructed with materials and utility equipment resistant to flood damage; (3) New construction or substantial improvements of existing structures shall be constructed by methods and practices that minimize flood damage; (4) Elevated buildings—All new construction or substantial improvements of existing structures that include any fully enclosed area located below the lowest floor formed by foundation and other exterior walls shall be designed so as to be an unfinished or flood resistant enclosure. The enclosure shall be designed to equalize hydrostatic flood forces on exterior walls by allowing for the automatic entry and exit of floodwater. a. Designs for complying with this requirement must either be certified by a professional engineer or architect or meet the following minimum criteria: 1. Provide a minimum of two (2) openings having a total net area of not less than one (1) square inch for every square foot of enclosed area subject to flooding; 2. The bottom of all openings shall be no higher than one (1) foot above grade; and, 3. Openings may be equipped with screens, louvers, valves or other coverings or devices provided they permit the automatic flow of floodwater in both direction. b. So as not to violate the "lowest floor" criteria of this chapter, the unfinished or flood resistant enclosure shall only be used for parking of vehicles, limited storage of maintenance equipment used in connection with the premises, or entry to the elevated area, and c. The interior portion of such enclosed area shall not be partitioned or finished into separate rooms. (5) All heating and air conditioning equipment and components (including ductwork), all electrical, ventilation, plumbing, and other service facilities shall be designed and/or located so as to prevent water from entering or accumulating within the components during conditions of flooding. (6) Manufactured homes shall be anchored to prevent flotation, collapse, or lateral movement. Methods of anchoring may include, but are not limited to, use of over-the-top or frame ties to ground anchors. This standard shall be in addition to and consistent with applicable state requirements for resisting wind forces. (7) New and replacement water supply systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of floodwaters into the system; (8) New and replacement sanitary sewage systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of floodwaters into the systems and discharges from the systems into floodwaters; (9) On-site waste disposal systems shall be located and constructed to avoid impairment to them or contamination from them during flooding, and; (10) Any alteration, repair, reconstruction or improvement to a structure, which is not compliant with the provisions of this chapter, shall be undertaken only if the nonconformity is not furthered, extended or replaced. (Ord. No. 07/6, Art. 4, § A, 8-14-2007) Sec. 11-27. - Specific standards. In all areas of special flood hazard the following provisions are required: (1) New construction and/or substantial improvements. Where base flood elevation data are available, new construction and/or substantial improvement of any structure or manufactured home shall have the lowest floor, including basement, elevated no lower than one (1) foot above the base flood elevation. Should solid foundation perimeter walls be used to elevate a structure, openings sufficient to facilitate equalization of flood hydrostatic forces on both sides of exterior walls shall be provided in accordance with standards of subsection 11-26(4), "elevated buildings". a. All heating and air conditioning equipment and components (including ductwork), all electrical, ventilation, plumbing, and other service facilities shall be elevated at or above one (1) foot above the base flood elevation. (2) Nonresidential construction. New construction and/or the substantial improvement of any structure located in A1-30, AE, or AH zones, may be floodproofed in lieu of elevation. The structure, together with attendant utility and sanitary facilities, must be designed to be water tight to one (1) foot above the base flood elevation, with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water, and structural components having the capability of resisting hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loads and the effect of buoyancy. A registered professional engineer or architect shall certify that the design and methods of construction are in accordance with accepted standards of practice for meeting the provisions above, and shall provide such certification to the official as set forth above and in subsection 11-18(6). (3) Standards for manufactured homes and recreational vehicles. Where base flood elevation data are available: a. All manufactured homes placed and/or substantially improved on: (1) individual lots or parcels, (2) in new and/or substantially improved manufactured home parks or subdivisions, (3) in expansions to existing manufactured home parks or subdivisions, or (4) on a site in an existing manufactured home park or subdivision where a manufactured home has incurred "substantial damage" as the result of a flood, must have the lowest floor including basement, elevated no lower than one (1) foot above the base flood elevation. b. Manufactured homes placed and/or substantially improved in an existing manufactured home park or subdivision may be elevated so that either: 1. The lowest floor of the manufactured home is elevated no lower than one (1) foot above the level of the base flood elevation, or 2. The manufactured home chassis is elevated and supported by reinforced piers (or other foundation elements of at least an equivalent strength) of no less than thirty-six (36) inches in height above grade. c. All manufactured homes must be securely anchored to an adequately anchored foundation system to resist flotation, collapse and lateral movement. (Ref. subsection 11-26(6) above) d. All recreational vehicles placed on sites must either: 1. Be on the site for fewer than one hundred eighty (180) consecutive days. 2. Be fully licensed and ready for highway use, (a recreational vehicle is ready for highway use if it is licensed, on its wheels or jacking system, attached to the site only by quick disconnect type utilities and security devices, and has no permanently attached structures or additions), or 3. The recreational vehicle must meet all the requirements for "new construction", including the anchoring and elevation requirements of subsection (3)a, c, above. (4) Floodway. Located within areas of special flood hazard established in section 11-3, are areas designated as floodway. A floodway may be an extremely hazardous area due to velocity floodwaters, debris or erosion potential. In addition, the area must remain free of encroachment in order to allow for the discharge of the base flood without increased flood heights. Therefore, the following provisions shall apply: a. Encroachments are prohibited, including earthen fill, new construction, substantial improvements or other development within the regulatory floodway. Development may be permitted however, provided it is demonstrated through hydrologic and hydraulic analyses performed in accordance with standard engineering practice that the encroachment shall not result in any increase in flood levels or floodway widths during a base flood discharge. A registered professional engineer must provide supporting technical data and certification thereof. b. Only if subsection (4)a above is satisfied, then any new construction or substantial improvement shall comply with all other applicable flood hazard reduction provisions of article III. (Ord. No. 07/6, Art. 4, § B, 8-14-2007) Sec. 11-28. - Building standards for streams without established base flood elevations and/or floodway (A-zones). Located within the areas of special flood hazard established in section 11-3, where streams exist but no base flood data have been provided (A-zones), or where base flood data have been provided but a floodway has not been delineated, the following provisions apply: (1) When base flood elevation data or floodway data have not been provided in accordance with section 11-3, then the building official or city engineer shall obtain, review, and reasonably utilize any scientific or historic base flood elevation and floodway data available from a federal, state, or other source, in order to administer the provisions of article III. Only if data are not available from these sources, then the following provisions (2) and (3) shall apply: (2) No encroachments, including structures or fill material, shall be located within an area equal to the width of the stream or twenty (20) feet, whichever is greater, measured from the top of the stream bank, unless certification by a registered professional engineer is provided demonstrating that such encroachment shall not result in more than a one-foot increase in flood levels during the occurrence of the base flood discharge. (3) In special flood hazard areas without base flood elevation data, new construction and substantial improvements of existing structures shall have the lowest floor of the lowest enclosed area (including basement) elevated no less than three (3) feet above the highest adjacent grade at the building site. (NOTE: Require the lowest floor to be elevated one (1) foot above the estimated base flood elevation in A-zone areas where a limited detail study has been completed). Openings sufficient to facilitate the unimpeded movements of floodwaters shall be provided in accordance with standards of subsection 11-26(4) "elevated buildings". a. All heating and air conditioning equipment and components (including ductwork), all electrical, ventilation, plumbing, and other service facilities shall be elevated no less than three (3) feet above the highest adjacent grade at the building site. The building official or city engineer shall certify the lowest floor elevation level and the record shall become a permanent part of the permit file. (Ord. No. 07/6, Art. 4, § C, 8-14-2007) Sec. 11-29. - Standards for areas of shallow flooding (AO zones). Areas of special flood hazard established in section 11-3, may include designated "AO" shallow flooding areas. These areas have base flood depths of one (1) to three (3) feet above ground, with no clearly defined channel. The following provisions apply: (1) All new construction and substantial improvements of residential and nonresidential structures shall have the lowest floor, including basement, elevated to the flood depth number specified on the flood insurance rate map (FIRM), above the highest adjacent grade. If no flood depth number is specified, the lowest floor, including basement, shall be elevated at least three feet (3) above the highest adjacent grade. Openings sufficient to facilitate the unimpeded movements of flood waters shall be provided in accordance with standards of subsection 11-26(4), "elevated buildings". The building official or city engineer shall certify the lowest floor elevation level and the record shall become a permanent part of the permit file. (2) New construction or the substantial improvement of a nonresidential structure may be floodproofed in lieu of elevation. The structure, together with attendant utility and sanitary facilities, must be designed to be water tight to the specified FIRM flood level plus one (1) foot, above highest adjacent grade, with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water, and structural components having the capability of resisting hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loads and the effect of buoyancy. A registered professional engineer or architect shall certify that the design and methods of construction are in accordance with accepted standards of practice for meeting the provisions above, and shall provide such certification to the official as set forth above and as required in subsections 11-17(1)c and 11-17(2). (3) Drainage paths shall be provided to guide floodwater around and away from any proposed structure. (Ord. No. 07/6, Art. 4, § D, 8-14-2007) Sec. 11-30. - Standards for subdivisions. (a) All subdivision and/or development proposals shall be consistent with the need to minimize flood damage; (b) All subdivision and/or development proposals shall have public utilities and facilities such as sewer, gas, electrical and water systems located and constructed to minimize flood damage; (c) All subdivision and/or development proposals shall have adequate drainage provided to reduce exposure to flood hazards, and; (d) For subdivisions and/or developments greater than fifty (50) lots or five (5) acres, whichever is less, base flood elevation data shall be provided for subdivision and all other proposed development, including manufactured home parks and subdivisions. Any changes or revisions to the flood data adopted herein and shown on the FIRM shall be submitted to FEMA for review as a conditional letter of map revision (CLOMR) or conditional letter of map amendment (CLOMA), whichever is applicable. Upon completion of the project, the developer is responsible for submitting the "as-built" data to FEMA in order to obtain the final LOMR. (Ord. No. 07/6, Art. 4, § E, 8-14-2007) Sec. 11-31. - Standards for critical facilities. (a) Critical facilities shall not be located in the one hundred-year floodplain or the five hundred-year floodplain. (b) All ingress and egress from any critical facility must be protected to the five hundred-year flood elevation. (Ord. No. 07/6, Art. 4, § F, 8-14-2007) Secs. 11-32—11-44. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - VARIANCE PROCEDURES
Sec. 11-45. - Variance procedures. (a) The board of zoning appeals as established by the City of LaFayette shall hear and decide requests for appeals or variance from the requirements of this chapter. (b) The board shall hear and decide appeals when it is alleged an error in any requirement, decision, or determination is made by the building official or city engineer in the enforcement or administration of this chapter. (c) Any person aggrieved by the decision of the board of zoning appeals may appeal such decision to the Superior Court of Walker County Georgia, as provided in Section 5-4-1 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. (d) Variances may be issued for the repair or rehabilitation of historic structures upon a determination that the proposed repair or rehabilitation will not preclude the structure's continued designation as a historic structure and the variance is the minimum to preserve the historic character and design of the structure. (e) Variances may be issued for development necessary for the conduct of a functionally dependent use, provided the criteria of this article are met, no reasonable alternative exists, and the development is protected by methods that minimize flood damage during the base flood and create no additional threats to public safety. (f) Variances shall not be issued within any designated floodway if any increase in flood levels during the base flood discharge would result. (g) In reviewing such requests, the board of zoning appeals shall consider all technical evaluations, relevant factors, and all standards specified in this and other sections of this chapter. (h) Conditions for variances: (1) A variance shall be issued only when there is: a. A finding of good and sufficient cause, b. A determination that failure to grant the variance would result in exceptional hardship, and; c. A determination that the granting of a variance will not result in increased flood heights, additional threats to public safety, extraordinary public expense, create nuisance, cause fraud on or victimization of the public, or conflict with existing local laws or ordinances. (2) The provisions of this chapter are minimum standards for flood loss reduction; therefore any deviation from the standards must be weighed carefully. Variances shall only be issued upon a determination that the variance is the minimum necessary, considering the flood hazard, to afford relief; and, in the instance of an historic structure, a determination that the variance is the minimum necessary so as not to destroy the historic character and design of the building. (3) Any applicant to whom a variance is granted shall be given written notice specifying the difference between the base flood elevation and the elevation of the proposed lowest floor and stating that the cost of flood insurance will be commensurate with the increased risk to life and property resulting from the reduced lowest floor elevation. (4) The building official or city engineer shall maintain the records of all appeal actions and report any variances to the Federal Emergency Management Agency upon request. (i) Upon consideration of the factors listed above and the purposes of this chapter, the board of zoning appeals may attach such conditions to the granting of variances as it deems necessary to further the purposes of this chapter. (Ord. No. 07/6, Art. 5, 8-14-2007)

div.head: Chapter 12 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Animals, Ch. 5; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; zoning, App. A.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 18-06, § 1, adopted Apr. 9, 2018, repealed former Art. I, §§ 12-1—12-12, and enacted a new Art. I as set out herein. Former Art. I pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1975, §§ 37-10—37-13, 37-20—37-26; Ord. No. 00-9, § 1, 7-10-2000; Ord. No. 04-16, § 1, 12-13-2004.
Sec. 12-1. - Purpose. The purpose of this article is to promote the health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of LaFayette, to protect against the degradation of the aesthetics of real property within the city, and to prevent the pollution of the city's land, waters, and air. In furtherance of this purpose, this article sets forth the city's expectations for the care and maintenance of real property within the city. This legislation is necessary to control and reduce the pollution of the land, water, and atmosphere of the city and to prevent the degradation of the quality of life and value of property within the city. (Ord. No. 18-06, § 1, 4-9-2018) Sec. 12-2. - Definitions. (a) For the purpose of this article, the below terms are defined as follows: (1) Dwelling means any building or structure, including a mobile home, having a roof supported by columns or by walls and which is designed for the shelter, support, or enclosure of persons, animals, or property of any kind and designed or used for residential occupancy by one (1) or more families or individuals. (2) Junk means old or discarded articles that are useless or of little to no value in their present state, including, but not limited to, any unused or unusable: a. Glass, plastics, or metals; b. Building materials not located on a building site subject to a valid city issued building permit; c. Carpet, rugs, or any other interior flooring coverings; d. Motor vehicle components or parts, including tires and wheels; e. Lawnmowers, weed eaters, chainsaws, leaf blowers, and other yard equipment; f. Home appliances, whether minor or major, including, but not limited to, air conditioners, dishwashers, clothes dryers, washing machines, ovens and stoves, microwave ovens, induction cookers, refrigerators, or freezers; g. Household electrical devices, including, but not limited to, computers, monitors, televisions, and stereo equipment; and h. Child outdoor play toys or play houses. (3) Occupant means any person or persons who lease property from an owner as defined in this section or otherwise are in possession of real property. (4) Owner means a person, as defined in this section, holding the title to real property in fee simple and every mortgagee of record. (5) Person means an individual human being, firm, association, corporation, limited liability company, partnership, or any other legally recognized entity. (6) Real property means land and any improvements attached to it and includes any developed lot or parcel of land occupied by any dwelling or place of business as well as all undeveloped land. (7) Refuse means garbage, rubbish, leaves, brush, and refuse as those terms are generally defined except that dead animals and fowl, body wastes, hot ashes, rocks, concrete, bricks, and similar materials are expressly excluded therefrom and shall not be stored therewith. (8) Refuse container means a strong, durable, rodent and insect proof container made of plastic, metal, or like material, having a capacity of not less than twenty (20) nor more than thirty-two (32) gallons, except that this maximum capacity does not apply to larger containers which the city handles mechanically. (Ord. No. 18-06, § 1, 4-9-2018) Sec. 12-3. - Duties of owners and occupiers of real property. (a) All real property must be maintained by its owner or occupant in a clean and sanitary condition and must be kept clear of all junk, refuse, standing water which may lead to the breeding of mosquitos, and any other noxious material of any kind. (1) The following are illustrative examples of potential violations of this subsection:
(b) All landscaped or lawn areas of real property containing any grass, weeds, shrubs, plants, trees, or other vegetation must be maintained by its owner or occupant in such a condition that the maximum height of any grass or weeds does not exceed twelve (12) inches in height and all other vegetation is kept trimmed and cut so as to prevent overgrowth. (1) The following is an illustrative visual example of permissible yard care:
(2) The following is an illustrative example of impermissible yard care:
(c) Since access to potable water and proper treatment of sewage waste is essential to prevent hazards to human health and the creation of a public nuisance, every owner or occupier of real property who inhabits a dwelling thereon must, at all times, maintain an active connection from the dwelling to: (1) A source of potable water; and (2) A septic tank, when allowed by the LaFayette City Code, a private sewage disposal system complying with the provisions of Chapter 21, Article V of the LaFayette City Code, or the city's sewer system. (d) Every owner or occupier of real property must, to the greatest extent practicable, properly store refuse while awaiting collection. In accordance with this requirement, such owners and occupiers must: (1) Store refuse within an appropriate refuse container while awaiting collection for disposal by the city which will collect refuse for disposal under the supervision of such officer as the city council designates, such collection to be made regularly and in accordance with an announced schedule. (2) Limit the amount of refuse placed in a refuse container at any one (1) time to seventy-five (75) pounds or less. (3) Drain refuse of all free liquids prior to storage in a refuse container. (4) Trim or cut all organic refuse, such as tree trimmings, hedge clippings, and similar materials to a length not to exceed four (4) feet and securely tie such refuse in individual bundles weighing not more than seventy-five (75) pounds each and being not more than two (2) feet thick before being deposited for collection. (5) Place refuse containers, at the time scheduled by the city for collection, on or within six (6) feet of the alley line in such a position as not to intrude upon the traveled portion of the alley if alleys are used by city refuse collectors or place refuse containers adjacent to and back of the curb, or adjacent to and back of the ditch or street line if there is no curb if streets are used by the city refuse collectors. (6) Remove refuse containers, as soon as practicable after the refuse is collected, to a space within, or to the rear of, the property and away from the street line until the next scheduled time for collection. (7) Place refuse only in the refuse container owned by or assigned to him or her and not in any other garbage can or container owned by assigned to any other person or entity, except that refuse may be disposed of in any garbage container placed by the city on its commercial square area located on each side of Main Street or a city park or recreation area for the purpose of collection of small amounts of liter. In furtherance of this subsection, no unauthorized person shall enter, go through, or in any other manner disturb any refuse container that is owned by or is assigned to any other person or entity. (Ord. No. 18-06, § 1, 4-9-2018) Sec. 12-4. - Burning. (a) Unpermitted burning is prohibited. To protect against the pollution of the atmosphere by smoke, fly ash, products of complete or incomplete combustion, and other emissions into the atmosphere which cause damage to the comfort, health, safety, and welfare of the people and property within the city, no person shall burn any building, barn, outbuilding, or structure of any kind or openly burn any substance, material, good, or product, whether natural or manufactured, including, but not limited to, any refuse or junk, unless a valid permit is first obtained in accordance with subsection (b) of this section. (b) Burning permits; application, issuance by fire department, conditions. (1) Any person desiring to conduct an open burn must first obtain a burning permit from the city's fire department, which is responsible for the intake and evaluation of burning permit applications and is vested with the authority and discretion to determine whether a burning permit will be issued to an applicant. (2) Application for burning permits may be made in person at the fire department or by telephone. (3) The fire chief, or his or her designee, has the discretion to select the date and time when burning will be permitted based on consideration of the prevailing weather conditions, air pollution levels, and fire hazard conditions. Provided, there shall be no burning on Sunday and no burning earlier than 9:30 a.m. (4) The permit must contain the day and time so chosen for the limited burning, must specify what materials are permitted to be burned, and must be signed and dated by the fire chief or his or her designee. (5) The applicant for the permit must be present and have the permit in his or her possession at all times during any burning permitted under this section. (Ord. No. 18-06, § 1, 4-9-2018) Sec. 12-5. - Enforcement. This section may be enforced by the city manager or his or her designee, the city building official or his or her designee, or any law enforcement officer with jurisdiction within the city. (Ord. No. 18-06, § 1, 4-9-2018) Sec. 12-6. - Violations. Any violation of the provisions of this article is an offense punishable by the Municipal Court of the City of LaFayette. In the case of a violation of the burning provisions of this article, the municipal court of the city may levy an additional fine to be determined by computing the total cost to the city for providing firefighting equipment and firemen in connection with the fighting or putting out of any fire in violation of this article may be imposed by the recorder. (Ord. No. 18-06, § 1, 4-9-2018) Secs. 12-7—12-15. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - RESERVED
Secs. 12-16—12-35. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. 18-06, § 3, adopted Apr. 9, 2018, repealed Art. II, §§ 12-16—12-19, which pertained to burning and derived from Code 1975, §§ 37-10—37-13. ARTICLE III. - JUNK MOTOR VEHICLES[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- Cross reference— Junkyards prohibited, § 13-1; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 14. State Law reference— Municipal authority to adopt junked motor vehicle ordinances, OCGA § 36-60-4.
Sec. 12-36. - Definitions. For the purposes of this article, the following words, terms, and phrases have the following meanings: Enforcement officer means any law enforcement officer of the city and any codes enforcement officer of the city or his or her designee. Junk motor vehicle means, in addition to the plain meaning of the term, any motor vehicle, as defined in this article, including any and all of its parts whether attached to the motor vehicle or not, the condition of which is one or more of the following: (1) Abandoned; (2) Discarded; (3) Wholly or partially dismantled; (4) Wrecked; (5) Scrapped; (6) Ruined; (7) Missing material parts from the body of the vehicle, i.e., windshield, door, lights, hood, wheel, etc.; (8) Inoperable due to the absence of, or damage to, any key component, such as a motor, transmission, wheels, tires, or body parts, rendering the motor vehicle incapable of normal operation in the manner intended; or (9) lacking a current license tag or registration or failing to display a current tag as required by Georgia law. Motor vehicle means a vehicle having two (2) or more load-bearing wheels of a kind required to be registered under the laws of this state relating to motor vehicles designed primarily for operation upon the public streets, roads, and highways and driven by power other than muscular power. The term includes a trailer drawn by or attached to such a vehicle and also includes without limitation a low speed vehicle. Owner means the owner of the subject real property or premises as shown on the deed records of Walker County, Georgia, the occupant in possession including a tenant or lessee, and any person designated by the owner or occupant to manage the premises. When known to the enforcement officer, the term "owner" also includes the person to whom the motor vehicle is currently or was formerly titled or who last purchased a license tag or decal for the vehicle. Person means every natural person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, trust, or other form of recognized business entity in the State of Georgia, including governmental authorities, but excludes a federal agencies, the state and its agencies, counties, municipal corporations, and school districts. (Ord. No. 17-06, § 1, 11-13-2017) Editor's note— Ord. No. 17-06, § 1, adopted Nov. 13, 2017, repealed the former section and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1975, § 35-10; Ord. No. 99-6, § 1, 8-9-99. Sec. 12-37. - Nuisance; creation of nuisance unlawful; exceptions. (a) To preserve and promote public health, safety, and welfare, and to prevent the proliferation of unsightly nuisances; the parking, keeping, storing, depositing, or discarding of any junk motor vehicle on any real property within the city, whether public or private, is prohibited and constitutes a nuisance per se. (b) The intentional parking, keeping, storing, depositing, or discarding of any junk motor vehicle on any private or public real property, including any street, adjoining street right-of-way, or on property owned or leased by the city and designated for off-street parking, except in accordance with this article and the zoning and business regulations of the city, is unlawful. (c) Notwithstanding the provisions of subsections (a) and (b) of this section, it is not a nuisance or unlawful for a junk motor vehicle to be: (1) Stored on real property when it is within a completely enclosed building or structure, lawfully erected on the property, so that the junk motor vehicle is not visible from any other adjoining properties or from a public street right-of-way; or (2) Stored on real property in connection with a business of a licensed motor vehicle sales or service dealer, motor vehicle repair or mechanic shop, automobile paint shop, wrecker or towing service, impound yard, junkyard, or other commercial business operated in a lawful manner, located in other than a residential zoning district within the city, when the storage of the junk motor vehicle is necessary for the operation of the business or when the storage of the junk motor vehicle is appropriate because the business operates as a lawful storage place, repair facility, or depositary for junk motor vehicles. (Ord. No. 17-06, § 2, 11-13-2017) Editor's note— Ord. No. 17-06, § 2, adopted Nov. 13, 2017, repealed the former section and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1975, § 35-11. Sec. 12-38. - City manager to administer; any law enforcement officer of the city and the codes enforcement officer of the city or his or her designee to enforce. It shall be the duty of the city manager, and such employees of the city as he may appoint, to administer and the codes enforcement office of the city to enforce the provisions of this article. The city manager and codes enforcement officer of the city may enter upon private or public property to examine a junk motor vehicle, to obtain information as to the identity of such vehicle and to remove any such vehicle which shall finally be determined to constitute a public nuisance by the provisions of this article. (Code 1975, § 35-12; Ord. No. 99-6, § 2, 8-9-99; Ord. No. 17-06, § 3, 11-13-2017) Sec. 12-39. - Intentional violations; punishment of violators. (a) The enforcement officer has the authority and discretion to issue a citation to any person found to be in violation of the provisions of section 12-37 of this article. The citation may either be personally served on the owner or mailed to the owner via certified United States mail, return receipt requested, at the last address of record of the owner. (b) The citation will require the owner accused of violating section 12-37 to appear before the city's municipal court. Following a trial on the allegations contained in the citation, any owner found in violation of section 12-37 by the municipal court may be fined or incarcerated, or both. The owner may also be required to remove and properly dispose of the junk motor vehicle, at the owner's expense, within a deadline determined by the municipal court. (c) In the event of noncompliance by the owner with the municipal court's order of removal, the city, including any agent, employee, or private person retained by agreement or contract with the city, is authorized to enter upon the real property where the junk motor vehicle is located and cause its removal via towing or whatever means may be necessary. After removal of the vehicle by the city, the city is authorized to dispose of the vehicle by any means allowed by law, including, but not limited to, delivery of the vehicle to an impound yard. Any junk motor vehicle removed by the city in accordance with this subsection is deemed a derelict motor vehicle and may be disposed of under O.C.G.A. § 40-11-9. (d) If the city causes the removal or disposal, or both, of the junk motor vehicle under subsection (c) hereof due to an owner's noncompliance with a municipal court order, the owner is required to pay restitution to the city for all costs incurred by the city. And, such costs are may be collected by the city in the same manner as taxes and levies are collected. (Ord. No. 17-06, § 4, 11-13-2017) Editor's note— Ord. No. 17-06, § 4, adopted Nov. 13, 2017, repealed the former section and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1975, § 35-13; Ord. No. 99-6, § 3, 8-9-99. Secs. 12-40—12-60. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. 17-06, § 5, adopted Nov. 13, 2017, repealed §§ 12-40—12-45, which pertained to nuisances and derived from Code 1975, §§ 35-14—35-16, 35-18, 35-19; Ord. No. 99-6, §§ 4—7, 8-9-99. ARTICLE IV. - NOISES[4]
Footnotes: --- (4) --- Cross reference— Advertising, Ch. 3.
Sec. 12-61. - Loud and unnecessary noises prohibited. The creation of any unreasonably loud, disturbing and unnecessary noises in the city is prohibited, and it shall be unlawful for any person to cause, make or contribute to creating any loud, disturbing or unnecessary noise, and noises of such character, intensity and duration as to be detrimental to the life or health of any individual, or such noises as unduly disturb the quiet and peace of the citizens of the city. (Code 1975, § 36-10) Sec. 12-62. - Acts declared to he unnecessary noises. The following acts, among others, are declared to be loud, disturbing and unnecessary noises in violation of section 12-61, but said enumerations shall not be deemed to be exclusive, namely: (1) Advertising. The use or mechanical loudspeakers or amplifiers on trucks, airplanes or other vehicles for advertising or other purposes except where specific license is received from the proper city officials. (2) Attracting attention. The use of any drum, loudspeaker, or other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention by creation of noise to any performance, show or sale or display or advertisement of merchandise. (3) Blowing horns, etc. The sounding of any horn or signal device on any automobile, motorcycle, bus or other vehicle while not in motion, except as a danger signal if another vehicle is approaching apparently out of control, or if in motion only as a danger signal, the creation by means of any such signal device of any unreasonably loud or harsh sound; and the sounding of such device for an unnecessary and unreasonable period of time. (4) Building operations. The erection (including excavation), demolition, alteration or repair of any building, in a residential or business district other than between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. on weekdays, except in case of urgent necessity in the interest of public safety and then only with a permit from the proper city officials, which permit may be renewed for a period of three (3) days or less while the emergency continues. (5) Business noises in residential sections. The operation of any garage, filling station, auto repair business, taxi business, plant, store, factory or other place of business, between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. in such manner as to create loud and disturbing noises of such frequency or volume as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort, peace or repose of persons in any dwelling, hotel, boardinghouse or other type of residence. (6) Compressed air device. The use of any mechanical device operated by compressed air unless the noise created thereby is effectively muffled and reduced. (7) Exhaust discharge. The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine, or motor vehicle, except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud or explosive noises therefrom. (8) Keeping of animals. The keeping of any animal or bird which, by causing frequent or long continued noise, shall disturb the comfort and repose of any person in the vicinity. (9) Loading or unloading operations. The creation of a loud and excessive noise in connection with loading or unloading any vehicle, or repairing any vehicle, or opening and destroying bales, boxes, crates and containers. (10) Noises near schools, churches, etc. The creation of any excessive noise on any street adjacent to any school, institution of learning, library or sanitarium, or court while the same are in session, or adjacent to any hospital or any church during services, which unreasonably interferes with the work or worship at such institution, provided conspicuous signs are displayed in such streets indicating that the same is a school, hospital, church, library, sanitarium or court street. (11) Peddlers, hawkers, etc. The shouting, loud-talking, crying and soliciting of peddlers, hawkers, taxi drivers, solicitors and vendors, which disturbs the quiet and peace of the neighborhood. (12) Playing of radio, phonograph, etc. The playing of any radio, phonograph or any musical instrument in such a manner or with such volume, particularly during the hours between 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any dwelling, hotel or other type residence. (13) Sounding of bell or gong. The sounding of any bell or gong attached to any building or premises which disturbs the quiet or repose of persons in the vicinity thereof. (14) Sounding of steam whistles. The blowing of any steam whistle attached to any stationary boiler except to give notice of the time to begin or stop work, or as a warning of danger. (15) Use of vehicles. The operation of any automobile, motorcycle or vehicle so out of repair, so loaded, or in such manner, or the repair of any such vehicle in such manner, as to create loud or unnecessary grating, grinding, rattling, riveting or other loud or disturbing noises. (Code 1975, § 36-11) Sec. 12-63. - Authority of council to permit exceptions. Upon application, duly filed with the mayor and council, the mayor and council in their discretion may grant such permits allowing speaking, singing or blowing of instruments for such period of time and in such volume as they deem proper. (Code 1975, § 36-12)

div.head: Chapter 13 - LICENSES, PERMITS AND MISCELLANEOUS BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Authority to regulate businesses and occupations, § 5-20. Cross reference— Noises, § 12-61 et seq.; motel-hotel excise tax, § 13.5-1 et seq.; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 19; utilities, Ch. 21; zoning, App. A. State Law reference— Business and occupational taxes, OCGA § 48-13-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 13-1. - Junkyards prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a vehicle junkyard within the city limits of the city, except as specifically provided by the Zoning Ordinance of LaFayette, Georgia. (Code 1975, § 8-10; Ord. No. 99-7, § 4, 9-13-99) Cross reference— Junk motor vehicles, § 12-36 et seq. Sec. 13-2. - Newspapers, distribution to carriers prohibited on streets. It shall be unlawful for any person who acts as a distributor of newspapers, whether weekly or daily, to distribute the same to its carriers on any street, sidewalk or alley within the corporate limits of the city. (Code 1975, § 8-11) Secs. 13-3—13-15. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PRIVILEGE LICENSES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Charter reference— Licenses and occupational taxes, §§ 4-19, 5-20. State Law reference— Business and occupational taxes, OCGA, § 48-13-1 et seq.
Sec. 13-16. - License required, date payable, table of fees. Every person, whether a resident of the city or not, engaging in or about to engage in any business, trade, calling or profession within the corporate limits of the city from whom any license is required by this chapter shall pay to the city treasurer on or before March fifteenth of each year such license fee as is prescribed by the license fee schedule which is on file in the office of the city clerk. (Code 1975, § 15-10) Sec. 13-17. - Penalty for late licenses; refusal to pay, punishable offense. (a) Failure to pay when due any license fee required by section 13-16 shall subject such payment to a penalty tax in the amount of ten (10) percent of the license fee per month. (b) Willful refusal of any part to pay any license fee required by section 13-16 shall be an offense punishable by the recorder's court of the city. (Code 1975, § 15-11) Sec. 13-18. - Licenses nontransferable. No license shall be transferred from one (1) person to another. (Code 1975, § 15-12) Sec. 13-19. - Levy and execution upon default. Upon default of payment of any license fee chargeable and required to be paid under this chapter, an execution shall issue against the person making such default, and such execution shall be issued and enforced as provided for by the Charter of the city. (Code 1975, § 15-13) Sec. 13-20. - Chief of police authorized to collect delinquent fees. The chief of police is authorized to collect delinquent privilege license fees. (Code 1975, § 15-14) Sec. 13-21. - Decal, required on specified items; nontransferable. Every taxi, truck, vending machine, music machine and any other item that is required by the city to have a stamp shall have affixed to itself a decal issued by the city. The decal shall be affixed in such a manner as to make it impossible for the decal to be transferred to another item of any kind or character. (Code 1975, § 15-20) Sec. 13-22. - Cafes; food permit prerequisite to license. No license for cafes or any business serving food shall be issued until a valid food service permit is obtained from the county health department. (Code 1975, § 15-21) Secs. 13-23—13-35. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - INSURERS
Sec. 13-36. - Insurer license fees. (a) There is hereby levied for the year 1995 and for each year thereafter an annual license fee upon each insurer doing business within the city in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00). For each separate business location in excess of one (1) not covered by section 13-37, which is operating on behalf of such insurers within the city, there is hereby levied a license fee in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00). (b) For the purpose of this article, the term "insurer" means a company which is authorized to transact business in any of the classes of insurance designated in OCGA section 33-3-5. (Ord. of 11-14-83(1), § 1; Ord. of 2-11-86(1), § 1; Ord. of 11-14-94, § 1) Sec. 13-37. - License fee for insurers insuring certain risks at additional business locations. For each separate business location, not otherwise subject to a license fee under this article, operated and maintained by a business organization which is engaged in the business of lending money or transacting sales involving term financing and in connection with such loans or sales, offers, solicits or takes application for insurance through a licensed agent of an insurer for insurance such insurer shall pay an additional license fee of seventeen dollars and fifty cents ($17.50) per location for the year 1995 and for each year thereafter. (Ord. of 11-14-83(1), § 2; Ord. of 11-14-94, § 2) Sec. 13-38. - Insurance agency license fees; independent insurance agencies, brokers, etc., not otherwise licensed. There is hereby levied for the year 1995 and for each year thereafter an annual license fee upon independent agencies and brokers for each separate business location from which an insurance business is conducted and which is not subject to the company license fee imposed by section 13-36, in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each such location within the city. (Ord. of 11-14-83(1), § 1; Ord. of 2-11-86(1), § 3; Ord. of 11-14-94, § 3) Sec. 13-39. - Gross premiums tax imposed on insurers. There is hereby levied for the year 1995 and for each year thereafter an annual tax based solely upon gross premiums upon each insurer writing life, accident and sickness insurance within the city in an amount equal to one (1) percent of the gross direct premiums received during the preceding calendar year in accordance with OCGA section 33-8-8.1. "Gross direct premiums" as used in this section shall mean gross direct premiums as used in OCGA section 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fees imposed by section 13-36. (Ord. of 11-14-83(1), § 4; Ord. of 11-14-94, § 4) Sec. 13-40. - Gross premiums tax; all other insurers. There is hereby levied for the year 1995 and for each year thereafter an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer transacting business in the class of insurance designated in subsection 1 of OCGA § 33-3-5, doing business within the State of Georgia in an amount equal to two and one-half (2.5) percent of the gross direct premiums received during the preceding calendar year in accordance with OCGA § 33-8-8.2. "Gross direct premiums" as used in this section shall mean gross direct premiums as used in OCGA § 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fees imposed by section 13-36 hereof. (Ord. of 11-14-83(1), § 5; Ord. of 11-14-94, § 4) Sec. 13-41. - Due date for license fees. License fees imposed in sections 13-36, 13-37 and 13-38, shall be due and payable on the first day of 1995 and on the first day of each subsequent year. (Ord. of 11-14-83(1), § 6; Ord. of 11-14-94, § 6) Sec. 13-42. - Administrative provisions. The city clerk is hereby directed to forward a duly certified copy of the ordinance from which this article derives to the state insurance commissioner within forty-five days of its enactment. (Ord. of 11-14-83(1), § 7; Ord. of 11-14-94, § 7) Secs. 13-43—13-50. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Peddlers and itinerant trades, OCGA Title 43, Ch. 72
Sec. 13-51. - Peddler and solicitor defined. For the purpose of this article, the terms "solicitor" and "peddler" have the meanings ascribed below: Peddler shall mean any person traveling from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, carrying, conveying or transporting goods, wares, merchandise, meats, fish, vegetables, fruits, garden truck, farm products or provisions, offering and exposing the same for sale, or making sales and delivering articles to purchasers, or who without traveling from place to place shall sell or offer the same for sale from a wagon, automotive vehicle, railroad car, or other vehicle or conveyance. Anyone who solicits orders and, as a separate transaction, makes deliveries to purchasers shall be deemed a peddler. Solicitor shall mean any individual traveling from place to place, from house to house or from street to street attempting to take orders for sale of goods, wares, merchandise or personal property of any nature whatsoever for future delivery or for services to be furnished or performed in the future. Such definition shall include any person who, for himself or for another person, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, tent, railroad boxcar, boat, hotel room, lodginghouse, apartment, shop or any other place within the city for the sole purpose of exhibiting samples and taking orders for future delivery. Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. Sec. 13-52. - Permit required. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of peddler or solicitor within the corporate limits of the city without first obtaining a permit therefor from the city manager. (Code 1975, § 9-11) Sec. 13-53. - Application for permit. Applicants for peddler's or solicitor's permits must file with the city clerk a sworn application, in duplicate, which shall give the following information: (1) Name and description of applicant. (2) Address, legal and local. (3) A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods to be sold. (4) If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the exact relationship. (5) The length of time for which the right to do business is desired. (6) If a vehicle is to be used, a description of the same, together with license number or other means of identification. (7) A photograph of the applicant, taken within sixty (60) days immediately prior to the date of the filing of the application, which picture shall be two (2) inches by two (2) inches showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner. (8) The fingerprints of the applicant and the names of at least two (2) reliable property owners of this county who will certify as to the applicant's good character and business responsibility, or, in lieu of the names of references, any other available evidence as to the good character and business responsibility of the applicant as will enable an investigator to properly evaluate such character and business responsibility. (9) A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor or violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor. (Code 1975, § 9-12) Secs. 13-54—13-70. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - CHARITABLE SOLICITORS[4]
Footnotes: --- (4) --- State Law reference— Regulation of professional fund raising, OCGA § 43-17-1 et seq.
Sec. 13-71. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Charitable means and includes the words patriotic, philanthropic, social service, welfare, benevolent, educational, civic or fraternal, either actual or purported. Person means any individual, firm, co-partnership, corporation, company, association, or joint stock organization or league, church, religious sect, religious denomination, society and includes any trustee, receiver, assignee, agent or other similar representative thereof. Promoter means any person who promotes, manages, supervises, organizes or attempts to promote, manage, supervise, or organize a campaign or solicitation. Religious and religion does not mean and include the word "charitable" but these terms are to be given their commonly accepted definitions. Solicit and solicitation means the request, directly or indirectly, of money, credit, property, financial assistance or other things of value on the plea of representation that such money, credit, property, financial assistance or other thing of value will be used for a charitable or religious purpose as those purposes are defined in this article. These words shall also mean and include the following methods of securing money, credit, property, financial assistance or other things of value on the plea or representation that it will be used for a charitable or religious purpose: (1) Any oral or written request; (2) The distribution, circulation, mailing, posting or publication of any handbill, written advertisement or publication; (3) The making of any announcement to the press, over the radio, by telephone or telegraph concerning an appeal, assemblage, athletic or sports event, bazaar, benefit, campaign, contest, dance, drive, entertainment, exhibition, exposition, party, performance, picnic, sale or social gathering which the public is requested to patronize or to which the public is requested to make a contribution for any charitable or religious purpose connected therewith; (4) The sale of, offer or attempt to sell, any advertisement, advertising space, book, card, chance, coupon, device, magazine, membership, merchandise, subscription, ticket or other thing in connection with which any appeal is made for any charitable or religious purpose, or where the name of any charitable or religious person is used or referred to in any such appeal as an inducement or reason for making any such sale, or when or where in connection with any such sale, any statement is made that the whole or any part of the proceeds from any such sale, or when or where in connection with any such sale, any statement is made that the whole or any part of the proceeds from any such sale will go or be donated to any charitable or religious purpose. Solicitation shall be deemed completed when made, whether or not the person making the same receives any contribution or makes any sale referred to in this section. Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. Sec. 13-72. - Solicitation permit required. No person shall solicit contributions within the city without a permit from the city manager authorizing such solicitation. However, the provisions of this section shall not apply to any established persons organized and operating exclusively for religious or charitable purposes and not operated for the pecuniary profit of any person if the solicitations by such established person are conducted among the members thereof by other members or officers thereof, voluntarily and without remuneration for the making of such solicitations, or if the solicitations are in the form of collections or contributions at the regular assemblies or services of any such established person. (Code 1975, § 10-11) Sec. 13-73. - Application for permit. An application for a permit to solicit shall be made to the city manager upon forms provided by the city. The application required in this article shall contain the following information, or in lieu thereof, a detailed statement of the reason or reasons why such information cannot be furnished: (1) The name and address or headquarters of the person applying; (2) The purpose of the solicitation; (3) The name and address of the person or persons who will be in direct charge of conducting the solicitation and the names of all promoters connected or to be connected with the proposed solicitations; (4) An outline of the method or methods to be used in conducting the solicitations; (5) The time when such solicitations shall be made, giving the preferred dates for the beginning and ending of such solicitation; (6) The amount of any wages, fees, commissions, expenses or emoluments to be expended or paid to any person in connection with such solicitations, and the names and addresses of all such persons; (7) A full statement of the character and extent of the charitable work being done by the applicant within the city; (8) Such other information as may be reasonably necessary and required by the city manager in order for the city manager to determine the kind and character of the proposed solicitation and whether such solicitation is in the interest of, and not inimical to, the public welfare. (Code 1975, § 10-12) Sec. 13-74. - Investigation of application. The city manager shall examine all applications filed under this article and shall make, or cause to be made, such further investigation as he deems necessary for him to perform his duties hereunder. Upon request by the city manager any applicant shall make available for inspection by the city manager, or any person designated by him as his representative, all of the applicant's books, records and papers at any reasonable time. (Code 1975, § 10-13) Sec. 13-75. - Standard for issuance of permit. The city manager shall issue the permit provided for in this article whenever he shall find the following facts to exist: (1) That all of the statements made in the application are true; (2) That the applicant has a good character and reputation for honesty and integrity, or if the applicant is not an individual, that every person responsible for such organization is of good character and has a reputation for honesty and integrity; (3) That the control and supervision of the solicitation will be under responsible and reliable persons; (4) That the applicant has not engaged in any fraudulent transaction or enterprise; (5) That the solicitation is promoted solely by a desire to finance the charitable cause described in the application and will not be conducted primarily for private profit. (Code 1975, § 10-14) Sec. 13-76. - Use of fictitious name. No person shall directly or indirectly solicit contributions for any purpose by misrepresentation of his name, occupation, financial condition, social condition or residence, and no person shall make or perpetrate any other misstatement, deception or fraud in connection with any solicitation of any contribution for any purpose in the city, or in any application or report filed under this article. (Code 1975, § 10-15) Secs. 13-77—13-90. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - PAWNBROKERS[5]
Footnotes: --- (5) --- State Law reference— Municipal authority to regulate and license pawnbrokers, OCGA § 44-12-136.
Sec. 13-91. - Records; information required. Any pawnbroker operating a business in the city shall keep a book in which shall be legibly written, in ink or type and in the English language, at the time of each loan, purchase or receipt of personal property, an accurate account and description of the goods, articles or thing pawned, purchased or received, the amount of money loaned or advanced thereon or paid therefor, the date, the time including both day and hour of pawning, purchasing or receiving such goods, articles or thing, and the name, residence and description of the person pawning, selling or delivering such goods, articles or thing, and no entry made in such book shall be erased, obliterated or defaced. The book so kept for this purpose shall be used for this purpose only. (Code 1975, § 12-10) Sec. 13-92. - Copies of records, delivery to chief of police. Every pawnbroker shall deliver to the chief of police on Wednesday of each week before the hour of 11:00 a.m. a correct copy of all entries made in the book required by section 13-91 during the immediately preceding seven-day period. (Code 1975, § 12-11) Sec. 13-93. - Records to be open to inspection. The book required by section 13-91, as well as every article or thing pawned, pledged, sold or deposited, shall, at all reasonable times and specifically including all hours during which the business is open, be open to the inspection of any police office of the city. (Code 1975, § 12-12) Sec. 13-94. - Identification of persons offering property; records required. If a pawnbroker does not know the person offering to sell or pawn personal property, he shall make inquiry to learn the true identity of such person, and he shall require the production of his draft registration card, if any, his social security card, if any, and his driver's license, if any, and he shall note in the book or register kept by the pawnbroker as required by section 13-91 the draft board, if any, with which such person is registered, the address and social security number of such person, the driver's license number and any other information be obtained as to the identity of such person. This information shall be kept in addition to the description required by the provisions of section 13-91. (Code 1975, § 12-13) Sec. 13-95. - Pawned property, segregation for ten days. The pawnbroker shall keep any article or thing pawned or sold separate and apart from other goods or articles or things for a period of ten (10) days after receipt of same in order that such articles can be readily identified and easily inspected by the officers of the police department. (Code 1975, § 12-14) Sec. 13-96. - Pawned property; required holding period. It shall be unlawful for any pawnbroker to deliver to the person who pawned, pledged, sold or delivered the same, any goods, article or thing, or to deliver the same to any other person or to sell or otherwise dispose of the same for a period of twenty-four (24) hours from the date of receiving such goods, article or thing, or for an additional period of seventy-two (72) hours if requested by a police officer to retain the same. (Code 1975, § 12-15) Sec. 13-97. - Persons offering property, certain persons restricted. No pawnbroker shall take in pawn, pledge or as security, or purchase, any article from any person under eighteen (18) years of age, or from any person appearing to be intoxicated or known to be an habitual drunkard, nor from anyone appearing to be under the influence of any drug or controlled substance or known to be a drug addict of any type whatsoever, nor from any person known to such pawnbroker to be a thief or to have been convicted of larceny, burglary, or any felony without first notifying the police department of the city. (Code 1975, § 12-16) Sec. 13-98. - Return of pawned property to owner. If any person is found to be the owner of stolen property which has been pawned, pledged or sold to a pawnbroker, such property shall be returned to the owner thereof without the payment of the amount advanced by the pawnbroker or any costs or charges of any kind which the pawnbroker may have placed upon the same. (Code 1975, § 12-17) Sec. 13-99. - Violation, revocation of privilege license. Violation of any of the terms and conditions of this article shall be grounds for revocation of the city privilege license for any pawnbroker or pawn shop. (Code 1975, § 12-18) Secs. 13-100—13-110. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - WRECKERS[6]
Footnotes: --- (6) --- Editor's note— Codification of §§ 1—9 of nonamendatory Ordinance No. 3-88, adopted Feb. 8, 1988, as Article VII, §§ 13-111—13-119, has been at the editor's discretion. Cross reference— Junk motor vehicles, § 12-36 et seq.; automobile junkyards prohibited, § 13-1; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 14; vehicles for hire, Ch. 22.
Sec. 13-111. - "Wrecker" defined. The term "wrecker" as used in this article, means an automotive vehicle with hoisting apparatus and equipment for towing or hauling wrecked or disabled automobiles or other vehicles. The term "wrecker" also includes any vehicle otherwise equipped and used for the purpose of towing or hauling wrecked or disabled automobiles or vehicles. (Ord. No. 3-88, § 1, 2-8-88) Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. Sec. 13-112. - Operation of wrecker; compliance with article required. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation, either as principal, agent or employee, to use or operate upon any of the streets of the city, any wrecker or towing car without complying with this article. (Ord. No. 3-88, § 2, 2-8-88) Sec. 13-113. - Responsibility of wrecker operators. (a) The wrecker operators shall be responsible to the owner of the vehicle being towed for all damage done during towing and storage of any vehicles entrusted to them under this article. (b) Wrecker operators shall fully cooperate with all duly authorized law enforcement officers in the protection of any evidence or in any investigation arising out of a wreck or seizure of a vehicle by any officials. (c) It shall be the responsibility of the wrecker operator, prior to leaving the scene of any collision, to clean the pavement of all debris of the collision, including all glass. (d) The wrecker operators shall not release any vehicle placed on hold from storage unless authorized by the officer who placed the hold on the vehicle, or the highest ranking officer on duty. (Ord. No. 3-88, § 3, 2-8-88) Cross reference— Impoundment and enforcement, § 14-106 et seq. Sec. 13-114. - Required information to be printed on side of wrecker. It shall be unlawful for any person, partnership, firm, association or corporation, either as principal, agent or employee, to operate or cause to be operated within the city any wrecker as defined herein unless said wrecker shall have lettered in permanent paint on each side in plain view the following information: the name of the person, partnership, firm, association or corporation owning and causing its wrecker to operate on the streets of the city, the address from which the wrecker is operating and the telephone number. This lettering shall be in contrasting color to the color of the wrecker and shall be at least two and one-half (2½) inches in height. Temporary or removable magnetic signs shall not be permitted. (Ord. No. 3-88, § 4, 2-8-88) Sec. 13-115. - Call to scene of accident by certain persons only. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any wrecker, or his agent, representative or employee to go to any place where an accident has occurred unless called by the driver or the owner of the disabled vehicle or by the owner's authorized representative, or by the police department dispatcher. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any wrecker, or his agent, representative or employee, to go to the place of a wreck by reason of information received by police radio. (Ord. No. 3-88, § 5, 2-8-88) Sec. 13-116. - Solicitation of towing work along city streets, etc., prohibited. It shall be unlawful to drive along any city street or bridge and solicit towing work. Solicitation of towing work by the operator or an occupant of a wrecker while parked on any city street or bridge is also prohibited. A wrecker operator shall not proceed to the scene of a disabled vehicle without having been requested or notified to do so, as provided in section 13-115. (Ord. No. 3-88, § 6, 2-8-88) Sec. 13-117. - Procedures for city police officers and employees. (a) A schedule shall be set up on a rotating basis of all qualified wrecker services operating within the city, which wrecker service shall be used as hereinafter provided, except in an extreme emergency where persons are trapped or pinned in or under vehicles, or in burning vehicles, or in danger of drowning by submersion, or where traffic is blocked to prevent the normal flow of vehicles, in which event, and only in which event, said police officer shall be authorized to call the nearest, most qualified wrecker service, to prevent serious injury or death. (b) The police officer or lawfully authorized officer shall determine whether or not a wrecker is needed, and if a wrecker is needed, shall ascertain if the owner or operator is in a condition to make a preference known what wrecker service the owner or operator desires called, and shall call the preferred service desired by the owner or operator of the vehicle. No police or other authorized officer when on official duty shall recommend to any person the wrecker service company to be called or employed. (c) In the event the owner or operator is unable, due to injury or due to physical or mental impairment, to make a choice, or does not have any preference, then said police officer or other authorized officer shall call the wrecker service on said schedule. (d) In the event the dispatcher is unable to reach or if for any reason the wrecker service on schedule is unable to furnish the service, then the next succeeding wrecker service, which shall be the service that was listed next on the schedule, shall be called to provide the needed wrecker service. (e) Except in extreme emergencies, the police officer or other authorized officer shall await the arrival of the wrecker and shall in the meantime make the scene of the accident safe for other vehicles, using the road in the vicinity thereof, giving warnings and directing traffic. (Ord. No. 3-88, § 7, 2-8-88) Sec. 13-118. - Responsibility for payment. All charges and fees for towing and storage of the vehicle shall be at the expense of the owner of the vehicle, and against the vehicle itself, as provided by state law. (Ord. No. 3-88, § 8, 2-8-88) Sec. 13-119. - Penalties for violation of this article. Any person, partnership, firm, association or corporation that violates any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction in recorder's court, be fined one hundred dollars ($100.00) or imprisoned for thirty (30) days, or both. Each unlawful violation shall constitute a separate offense hereunder. The chief of police or his delegate shall have authority to issue citations for violations of this article. (Ord. No. 3-88, § 9, 2-8-88) Sec. 13-120. - Removal for violations; period. Violations of this article shall result in the violator being removed from the wrecker service call list. Removal shall not be for a period of more than six (6) months from the date of removal. Repeated violations could result in permanent removal from the wrecker call list. Any violator removed from the wrecker service call list will be afforded a hearing before the director of public safety upon a request made by the violator within three (3) work days from notice of removal when the violator takes exception to being removed from the wrecker service call list. The decision of the director of public safety shall be final. (Ord. No. 99-12, § 1, 12-13-99) Sec. 13-121. - Insurance. A wrecker service must at all times maintain a comprehensive form of automobile and general liability insurance, including death to said service's employees and all others, and claims for property damage and/or all claims which may arise out of or as a result of services performed at the request of the department of public safety. Owners of said wrecker services shall indemnify the city, its agents, servants and employees, for all claims and damages arising from services performed by the wrecker service. Each wrecker service listed on the wrecker service call list shall possess at all times the following minimum amounts of insurance:
(Ord. No. 99-12, § 1, 12-13-99) Sec. 13-122. - Towed vehicle storage area. Each wrecker service which has an area for storage within the city shall comply with the standards set forth in the ordinances of the city pertaining to junk yards. In the event any participating wrecker service does not have adequate storage space, said wrecker service shall store its towed vehicles at a location outside the city or at a location within the city meeting established criteria. No vehicle shall be stored at a wrecker service location within the city, which is not a licensed junk yard, more than sixty (60) days and no more than ten (10) vehicles shall be stored at any wrecker service location, which is not a licensed junk yard. (Ord. No. 99-12, § 1, 12-13-99) Secs. 13-123—13-130. - Reserved. ARTICLE VIII. - GAME ROOMS, BILLIARD AND POOL ROOMS, AMUSEMENT DEVICES, ETC.[7]
Footnotes: --- (7) --- Editor's note— An ordinance adopted May 12, 1989, §§ 1—12, enacted provisions pertaining to license and regulation of game rooms, pool and billiard rooms, mechanical and coin-operated amusement devices. Such provisions have been designated herein as Art. VIII, §§ 13-131—13-142 by the editor. For the specific derivation of each section, the user's attention is directed to the history note parenthetically enclosed following the section.
Sec. 13-131. - Billiard rooms, operation subject to state law and this article. The operation of a billiard room within the corporate limits of the City of LaFayette shall be subject to all of the laws of the State of Georgia pertaining to the same as codified in Title 43, Chapter 8, O.C.G.A., except as may hereinafter be amplified by the subsequent provisions of this article. (Ord. of 5-12-89, § 1) Sec. 13-132. - Definitions. As used in this article, the term: Billiard room shall mean the same as defined in O.C.G.A. section 43-8-1; Billiards shall mean the same as defined in O.C.G.A. section 43-8-1; Game room means any public place or business establishment where a person is permitted to play and/or operate a mechanical amusement device and/or a coin-operated amusement device as defined herein, but which does not contain any billiard table or billiard tables of any type whatsoever.
