Mechanical amusement device and coin-operated amusement device mean each machine which, upon the insertion of a coin, trade-token or slug, operates or may be operated as a game or contest of skill or amusement of any kind or description, and which contains no automatic pay-off device for the return of money or trade-tokens or slugs, or which makes no provision whatsoever for the return of money to the player. A "mechanical amusement device" and "coin-operated amusement device" is hereby further defined as any machine, apparatus, or contrivance which is used or which may be used as a game of skill and amusement wherein or whereby the player initiates, employs or directs any force generated by the machine. Additionally, the term "mechanical amusement device" and the term "coin-operated amusement device" is further defined to be and include any machine, apparatus or contrivance which, upon the insertion of a coin, trade-token or slug, operates or may be operated as a game or contest of skill or amusement, including but not limited to, pinball machines and video game machines. The term "mechanical amusement device" and the term "coin-operated amusement device" shall not for the purposes of this article include a machine vending recorded music or a period of radio or television entertainment in return for the insertion or deposit therein of a coin, trade-tokens or slugs and shall not include what is sometimes referred to as a jukebox. (Ord. of 5-12-89, § 2) Sec. 13-133. - Applicability of article; license fee for excluded establishments. (a) Except as provided in subsections (b) and (c) of this section, this article shall be applicable to all billiard rooms and all game rooms and all combination billiard room/game room business establishments which are operated within the corporate limits of the city. (b) No provision of this article shall apply to a place of business that is an eating establishment as defined by the terms of Section 4-103 of this Code, so long as such eating establishment is operating in accord with the regulations set forth in Division 4 of Chapter 4 (otherwise known as the City of LaFayette Malt Beverage/Wine by the Drink Ordinance) and has on the premises no more than four (4) billiard tables, pool tables, mechanical amusement devices, coin-operated amusement devices or any combination thereof. (c) Except for the annual licensing fee provided in this subsection, this article shall not apply to business places which do not contain any billiard tables and/or pool tables but which do contain mechanical amusement devices and/or coin-operated amusement devices, so long as the combined gross revenues per month from such devices are less than twenty-five (25) percent of the total monthly gross revenues of such place or business. Businesses which operate in any combination no more than two (2) such devices shall pay an annual licensing fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). Businesses which have within the premises in any combination more than two (2) such devices shall pay an annual licensing fee of fifty dollars ($50.00), which shall cover the licensing of the first two (2) devices, and an additional fifteen dollars ($15.00) for each device beyond the first two (2). The annual licensing fee required by this subsection shall be in addition to, and does not exclude, any other fees that may be required by this Code. (Ord. of 5-12-89, § 3; Ord. No. 12-01, 1-18-2012) Sec. 13-134. - Business license required, when. Any place of business which shall have any billiard table, pool table, mechanical amusement device, or coin-operated amusement device as defined herein, in addition to any other business licenses required of such establishment, must purchase and exhibit in the place of business a city business license to operate such billiard room, game room or combination billiard room/game room. (Ord. of 5-12-89, § 9) Sec. 13-135. - License fee. The annual business license for each such billiard room, game room or combination billiard room/game room shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00) which shall cover the establishment and the first two (2) such devices or tables located therein. In addition to the aforesaid annual license, such business establishment must pay an additional annual business license license fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) for each such table and/or such device located within the establishment, exclusive of the first two (2) tables or devices. (Ord. of 5-12-89, § 10) Sec. 13-136. - Unobstructed visibility of interior required. No person who operates a billiard room, game room, or combination billiard room/game room shall permit screens, curtains, blinds, partitions, or other obstructions to be used to prevent a clear view of the interior of the business establishment. No partitions forming rooms, stalls, or other enclosures shall be permitted which would inhibit, obstruct or interfere with such clear view of the interior of the business establishment. However, this shall not be construed to prohibit the maintenance of washrooms and toilet rooms for proper purposes nor the maintenance of closets for storage purposes exclusively. (Ord. of 5-12-89, § 8) Sec. 13-137. - Full-time supervision required. All billiard rooms, all game rooms and all combination billiard room/game room business establishments must have full-time supervision at all times that the place of business is open. Such supervision must be an attendant who is present at all times and is at least twenty-one (21) years of age. (Ord. of 5-12-89, § 4) Sec. 13-138. - Persons under twelve years of age not admitted; exceptions. It shall be unlawful for any person who has not reached the age of twelve (12) years to be permitted in any billiard room, game room, or combination billiard room/game room for any purpose, unless such minor is accompanied by a parent or guardian or by an adult who has in his possession written consent of a parent or guardian of the minor to be with said adult and to enter such billiard room, game room, or combination billiard room/game room and operate and play billiards, the various amusement devices, mechanical amusement devices and/or coin-operated amusement devices in such business establishment. (Ord. of 5-12-89, § 7) Sec. 13-139. - Prohibited acts, items and substances. Any business establishment that has therein any billiard table, pool table, mechanical amusement device, and/or other coin-operated amusement device is hereby prohibited from having therein or allowing therein or on the premises of such business establishments any of the following acts, action, behavior, conduct, goods, or items, to wit: (1) No gambling and/or betting of any type whatsoever shall be conducted either in the building or on the premises where such business is conducted. (2) No beer, wine or alcoholic beverage of any type whatsoever shall be sold, offered for sale, consumed, stored, displayed, and/or brought into any such place of business or on the premises of such business establishment. (3) No person shall be allowed to have in his or her possession or to sell, use, drink, consume, inhale or intake in any manner whatsoever while in the business establishment or while on the premises of the business establishment any of the following: a. Marijuana; b. Any controlled substance, as defined in Chapter 13 of Title 16, O.C.G.A., listed and contained in Schedules I, II, III, IV, and V as found in O.C.G.A. sections 16-13-25, 16-13-26, 16-13-27, 16-13-28 and 16-13-29; c. Any dangerous drug as defined in O.C.G.A. section 16-13-71; d. Model glue as defined in O.C.G.A. section 16-13-90; e. Any imitation controlled substance as defined in O.C.G.A. section 16-13-21. (4) No person shall be allowed within such business establishment who is under the influence of beer, wine, or any alcoholic beverage or under the influence of any of the drugs and/or substances listed or referred to in subparagraph (3), above. (Ord. of 5-12-89, § 5) Sec. 13-140. - Times when closed to operation. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to operate a billiard room or a game room or any combination billiard room/game room between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. or to permit any person to remain in such billiard room and/or game room between such prohibited hours, except regular employees performing necessary labor on the premises. Additionally, it shall be unlawful for any billiard room and any game room or any combination billiard room/game room to be operated or to be open on Sunday of any week of any year. (Ord. of 5-12-89, § 6) Sec. 13-141. - Gambling devices prohibited. Nothing in this article shall in any way be construed to authorize, license or permit any gambling devices whatsoever, or any device or mechanism that has been judicially determined to be a gambling device, or in any way contrary to the laws of the State of Georgia. (Ord. of 5-12-89, § 12) Sec. 13-142. - License subject to revocation for violation. The business license of any billiard room, game room or combination billiard room/game room licensed under this article shall be subject to revocation for violation of any of the terms or provisions of this article or for violation of any of the laws of the State of Georgia pertaining to (1) billiard rooms, (2) gambling, (3) pinball machines, (4) coin-operated amusement devices, (5) the use of, sale of or possession of beer, wine or alcoholic beverages, or (6) controlled substances, marijuana, dangerous drugs, or imitation controlled substances. (Ord. of 5-12-89, § 11) Secs. 13-143—13-150. - Reserved. ARTICLE IX. - OCCUPATION TAXES, ADMINISTRATIVE FEES AND REGULATORY FEES[8]
Footnotes: --- (8) --- Editor's note— Section 1 of Ord. No. 98-1, adopted June 8, 1998, repealed former Art. IX, §§ 13-151—13-168 in its entirety, and added a new Art. IX, §§ 13-151—13-167 as herein set out. Former Art. IX pertained to similar subject matter and derived from § 1 of an ordinance adopted Jan. 9, 1997. Cross reference— Taxation, Ch. 20.
Sec. 13-151. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases shall, for the purposes of this chapter, have the following meaning: Administrative fee is the component of the occupation tax which approximates the reasonable cost of handling and processing the occupation tax. City means the City of LaFayette, Georgia. Employee is any individual whose work is performed under the direction and supervision of the employer and whose employer withholds FICA, federal income tax, or state income tax from such individual's compensation or whose employer issues to such individual for purposes of documenting compensation a form I.R.S. W-2 but not a form I.R.S. 1099. Location or office shall include any structure or vehicle where a business, profession, or occupation is conducted, but shall not include a temporary or construction work site located in the city for the purpose of serving a single customer or project or a vehicle used for sales or delivery by a business or practitioner of a profession or occupation which has a location or office. Occupation tax means a tax levied for revenue purposes on persons, partnerships, corporations or other entities for engaging in an occupation, profession or business in the city. Occupation tax certificate means a document issued by the city acknowledging payment of the occupation tax and administrative fee. Practitioners of professions and occupations are those individuals listed in O.C.G.A. section 48-13-9(C)(1)—(22) but does not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business if such business pays an occupation tax. A list of said practitioners of professions and occupations shall be as follows: Architects Chiropractors Dentists Embalmers Engineers (civil, mechanical, hydraulic or electrical) Funeral directors Land surveyors Landscape architects Lawyers Marriage and family therapists, social workers and professional counselors Motor vehicle dealers as defined in paragraph (1) of O.C.G.A. section 10-1-622 Optometrists Osteopaths licensed under Chapter 34 of Title 43 O.C.G.A. Physicians licensed under Chapter 34 of Title 43 O.C.G.A. Podiatrists Practitioners of physiotherapy Psychologists Public accountants Veterinarians Owners or operators of bona fide coin operated amusement machines, as defined in O.C.G.A. section 48-17-1, and owners or operators of businesses where bona fide coin operated amusement machines are available for commercial use and play by the public, provided that such amusement machines have affixed current stickers showing payment of annual permit fees, in accordances with O.C.G.A. section 48-17-9. Merchants or dealers as defined in O.C.G.A. section 48-5-354 as to their deliveries to businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations in areas zoned for commercial use. Any other business, profession, or occupation for which state licensure or registration is required by state law, unless the state law regulating such business, profession, or occupation specifically allows for regulation by local governments. (Ord. No. 98-1, § 1, 6-8-98; Ord. No. 02-07, § 1, 7-8-2002) Sec. 13-152. - Administrative fee. A nonprorated, nonrefundable administrative fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) is required on all occupation tax accounts for the initial registration, annual renewal or reopening of such accounts. (Ord. No. 98-1, § 1, 6-8-98) Sec. 13-153. - Regulatory fee. (a) Business and individuals engaging in the occupations or business set forth below must pay a nonrefundable regulatory fee in accordance with the rate set forth as follows: Carnivals ..... 1,000.00 Taxicab and limousine operators ..... 100.00 Tattoo artists ..... 100.00 Pawnbrokers ..... 100.00 Newspaper vending boxes ..... 100.00 Massage parlors ..... 500.00 Businesses which provide appearance bonds ..... 250.00 Fortunetellers ..... 500.00 Escort services ..... 500.00 (b) Every business, individual and location subject to payment of a regulatory fee levied by this article shall display a current regulatory fee certificate in a conspicuous place at the location for which such certificate was issued. If the taxpayer does not have a permanent location within the city, the regulatory fee certificate or an unaltered duplicate of such certificate shall be shown to the building official, his/her deputies, any police officer or city clerk upon request. (Ord. No. 98-1, § 1, 6-8-98) Sec. 13-154. - Occupation tax levied; limitations. (a) An occupation tax based upon number of employees 1 [] in the state is levied upon businesses with one (1) or more locations or offices within the corporate limits of the city and, pursuant to O.C.G.A. section 48-13-7, upon out-of-state businesses with no location or office in the city but with employees or agents engaging in substantial efforts to solicit business or serve customers or clients in the State of Georgia in accordance with the following schedule:
(b) The city shall not require the payment of more than one (1) occupation tax for each location of a business [or practitioner.] (c) A business which is subject to an occupation tax by another local government and claiming an exemption from or limitation to the occupation tax imposed by this article shall submit documentation as to current payment of the occupation tax to the other local government and the basis of such tax. (1) If a business with no location or office in Georgia provides to the city proof of payment of a local business or occupation tax in another state which purports to tax the business's sales or services in this state, then the business shall be exempt from this occupation tax. (2) A business with no location or office in Georgia shall only be required to pay occupation tax to the local government in Georgia where the largest dollar volume of business is done or service is performed by such business. This limitation shall only apply when the business has provided to the city satisfactory proof as to the applicability of this subsection. (3) A business which has locations in Georgia subject to occupation tax by more than one (1) local government in Georgia shall only be subject to occupation tax by the city for the number of employees who are employed within the corporate limits of the city. This limitation shall only apply when the business has provided to the city satisfactory proof of current payment of the occupation tax of the other local government(s). (4) If an employee works for the same business in more than one (1) municipal corporation or county and the business submits proof of this, the employee shall be counted as an employee in the city only if the city is the jurisdiction where such employee works for the longest period of time within the calendar year. (d) If a business commences business in the city on or after July 1 in any year, the occupation tax for the remaining portion of the year shall be fifty (50) percent of the tax imposed for the entire year. The administrative fee shall not be reduced. (e) If a business does not know how many employees which are the basis of this occupation tax will be employed by the business during the current calendar year, then the business shall file a return estimating the number of employees which are the basis of this occupation tax. If such estimate is not accurate, then no later than December 31 the business shall file an amended return indicating the actual number of employees during the previous calendar year. Any overpayment of the occupation tax may be credited to the business' account for future tax liability, offset against other amounts due and owing to the city for any reason or paid to the business at the discretion of the city clerk. (f) Real estate brokers shall be subject to occupation tax pursuant to this article only if they maintain a principal or branch office in the city. (Ord. No. 98-1, § 1, 6-8-98) Footnotes: --- () --- An employee who works forty (40) hours or more weekly shall be considered a full-time employee and that the average weekly hours of employees who work less than forty (40) hours weekly shall be added and such sum shall be divided by forty (40) to produce full-time position equivalents.
Sec. 13-155. - Occupation tax certificate. Every business and location subject to payment of the occupation tax levied by this article shall display a current occupation tax certificate in a conspicuous place at the location for which such certificate was issued. If the taxpayer does not have a permanent location within the city, the occupation tax certificate shall be shown to the building official, his/her deputies, any police officer or city clerk upon request. (Ord. No. 98-1, § 1, 6-8-98) Sec. 13-156. - Exemptions. (a) No occupation tax shall be levied on the following: (1) Any practitioners of professions and occupations as defined by section 13-151(g) herein provided; (2) Those businesses regulated by the Georgia Public Service Commission; (3) Those electrical service businesses organized under Chapter 3 of Title 46 of the Official Code of Georgia; (4) Any farm operation for the production from or on the land of agricultural products, but not including any agribusiness; (5) Nonprofit, agricultural product cooperation marketing associations pursuant to O.C.G.A. section 2-10-105; (6) Motor common carriers pursuant to O.C.G.A. section 46-7-15; (7) Person purchasing guano, meats, meal, flour, bran, cottonseed, or cottonseed meal or hulls in carload lots for distribution among the purchasers for use and not sale pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-5-355; (8) Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-5-356 for persons selling or introducing into the city agricultural products or livestock, including animal products, raised in this state when the sale and introduction are made by the producer of the product and the sale is made within ninety (90) days of the introduction of the product into the city; (9) Depository institutions pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93; (10) Any business where the levy of such occupation tax is prohibited by the laws of the State of Georgia or the United States; or (11) Businesses that rent or lease real estate, excluding hotels and motels, consisting of two (2) or less rental units. (b) The exemptions and limitations contained in this article shall not be construed to repeal or otherwise affect in any way any franchise fees, business taxes or other fees or taxes otherwise allowed by law. (Ord. No. 98-1, § 1, 6-8-98) Sec. 13-157. - Evidence of state registration when required. Each person who is licensed under Title 43 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated by the Examining Boards of the Secretary of State's Office shall provide evidence of proper and current state licensure before any city occupation tax certificate or regulatory fee certificate may be issued. (Ord. No. 98-1, § 1, 6-8-98) Sec. 13-158. - Evidence of qualification required if applicable. (a) Any business required to obtain health permits, bonds, certificates of qualification, certificates of competency or any other regulatory matter shall first, before the issuance of an occupation tax certificate or a regulatory fee certificate, show evidence of such qualification. (b) Any business required to submit an annual application for continuance of the business shall do so before the registration is issued. (Ord. No. 98-1, § 1, 6-8-98) Sec. 13-159. - Filing returns; other information required or requested. (a) On or before November 1 of each year, an individual, or business subject to this occupation tax ordinance shall file with the city clerk on a form approved by and available from the city a signed return attesting to the number of employees of such business during the calendar year. (b) Individuals and businesses doing business in the city shall submit to the city clerk or make available within thirty (30) days such information as may be required or requested by the city to determine the applicability and amount of the occupation tax or regulatory fee or to facilitate levying or collection of the occupation tax and/or regulatory fee(s). (Ord. No. 98-1, § 1, 6-8-98) Sec. 13-160. - Confidentiality. Information provided by an individual or business to the city for the purpose of determining the applicability and amount of the occupation tax or levying or collecting the occupation tax is confidential and exempt from disclosure under Article 4 of Chapter 18 of Title 50 of the Official Code of Georgia. Such information may be provided to the governing authority of another local government for occupation tax purposes or pursuant to court order or for the purpose of collecting occupation tax or prosecution for failure or refusal to pay occupation tax. (Ord. No. 98-1, § 1, 6-8-98) Sec. 13-161. - Date due; penalty. (a) Any occupation tax or regulatory fee due pursuant to this article shall be due and payable annually on January 1. In the event that any person commences business or initially engages in a regulated activity in the city after January 1 in any year, the tax and/or fee shall be due and payable on the date of the commencement of the business or regulated activity. (b) Any individual or business subject to any occupation tax or regulatory fee imposed by this article which is unpaid for ninety (90) days after the date on which payment was due shall be subject to a penalty of ten (10) percent of the tax or fee due. (Ord. No. 98-1, § 1, 6-8-98) Sec. 13-162. - Enforcement; violations. (a) It is the duty of the city clerk to administer and enforce the provisions of this article, to perform all functions necessary to administer and enforce this article and to summon violators of this article to appear before the municipal court. The city clerk may issue executions against individuals and businesses for taxes and fees which are due and owing. (b) The city clerk shall issue executions against individuals and businesses for taxes and fees which are due and owing. Such executions shall bear interest at the rate authorized by O.C.G.A. section 48-2-40 or, if such statute should be repealed, one (1) percent per month. The lien shall cover the property of the individual or business liable for payment of the delinquent occupation tax or regulatory fee and become fixed as of the date and time the occupation tax or regulatory fee became delinquent. The execution shall be levied by city clerk of the city upon property of the delinquent tax or fee payer located in the city and sufficient property shall be advertised and sold to pay the amount of the execution, including penalty, interest and costs. All other proceedings in relation thereto shall be as provided by the Code and Charter of the city and the laws of Georgia. The defendants at execution shall have the rights of defense, by affidavit of illegality of the tax or otherwise as provided by the Charter of the city and the laws of Georgia in regard to tax executions. (c) When a nulla bona entry has been entered upon an execution, the person against whom the entry is made shall not be allowed or entitled to have or collect any fees or charges whatever for services rendered after the entry of the nulla bona. If, at any time after the nulla bona entry has been made, the person against whom the execution issues pays the tax in full together with all interest and costs accrued on the tax, the person may collect any fees and charges due to such person as if such person had never defaulted in the payment of the tax. (d) Individuals and businesses who fail or refuse to pay any occupation tax or regulatory fee charged pursuant to this article shall be subject to a fine up to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). (e) Individuals and businesses who fail or refuse to make a timely or truthful tax return or make available truthful and accurate information the city requests or requires for determining applicability or amount of occupation tax or regulatory fee, or for levying or collecting such occupation tax or regulatory fee shall be subject to suspension or revocation of the right to conduct business within the city, as provided in section 13-163 hereof. (f) All persons subject to the occupation tax or regulatory fee imposed by this article shall be required to file for and pay such tax or fee. For failure to do so, any persons, officers or agents soliciting for or obtaining such person business shall be subject to the same penalty as other persons or businesses who fail to obtain make a return for or pay the applicable occupation tax or regulatory fee. (Ord. No. 98-1, § 1, 6-8-98) Sec. 13-163. - License suspension or revocation. (a) No license issued under this article shall be suspended or revoked except for due cause as defined hereunder, and only after a hearing before the mayor and council of the city upon a prior written notice to the licensee at the address shown on the license of the time, place and purpose of such hearing and a statement of the reason the license would be suspended or revoked. Three (3) days notice prior to the hearing shall be deemed reasonable, but shorter or longer periods of notice shall be authorized as the mayor and council may deem the circumstances justify. (b) "Due cause" for the suspension or revocation of such license shall consist of the following, to-wit: (1) A licensee engages in any fraudulent business transaction which is made punishable by the laws of this state; (2) Violation of any laws, ordinances or resolutions regarding such business or violation of regulations made pursuant to authority granted by the purpose of regulating such business; (3) A licensee supplies false information to the building official, his/her deputies, any police officer or the city clerk, regardless of when the false information is discovered; (4) The licensee has failed to obtain or has suffered the expiration, suspension or revocation of any paper or document by any officer, agency, authority or department of the city, state, any other state or the United States under authority of any law, ordinance or resolution of the city, state, any other state or the United States regulating such business; (5) The licensee violates any provisions of the zoning ordinances of the city; or (6) The licensee has failed to comply with any provision of this article. (c) The violation of the provisions of this article by any person may be enjoined by instituting appropriate proceeding for injunction in the courts of competent jurisdiction in this state. Such action may be maintained notwithstanding that other adequate remedies exist at law. Such actions may be instituted in the name of the governing authority of this city or in the name of the city. (Ord. No. 98-1, § 1, 6-8-98) Sec. 13-164. - Public hearing. After January 1, 1998, the city shall conduct at least one (1) public hearing before adopting any ordinance or resolution which will increase the occupation tax rate specified in section 13-154. (Ord. No. 98-1, § 1, 6-8-98) Sec. 13-165. - Prior ordinance. To the extent that any occupation taxes or regulatory fees are owed pursuant to an ordinance passed prior to this one, such amounts remain due and owing and the provisions of that prior ordinance will remain in effect with respect to such unpaid occupation taxes or regulatory fees until such time as they are paid in full. (Ord. No. 98-1, § 1, 6-8-98) Sec. 13-166. - Severability. In the event any portion of this article shall be declared or adjudged invalid or unconstitutional, it is the intention of the city council of the city that such adjudication shall in no matter affect the other sections, sentences, clauses or phrases of this article which shall remain in full force and effect as if the invalid or unconstitutional section, sentence, clause or phrase were not originally part of the article. (Ord. No. 98-1, § 1, 6-8-98) Sec. 13-167. - Amendability. The provisions of this article may be amended from time to time by the mayor and council of the city. (Ord. No. 98-1, § 1, 6-8-98)

div.head: Chapter 13.5 - MOTEL-HOTEL EXCISE TAX[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 15-01, adopted Feb. 9, 2015, repealed former Ch. 13.5, §§ 13.5-1—13.5-11, and enacted a new Ch. 13.5 as set out herein. Former Ch. 13.5 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 14-2, 1-13-2014. Charter reference— Power to regulate and license, § 5-20. Cross reference— Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 13; taxation, Ch. 20. State Law reference— Excise tax on rooms, lodgings, and accommodations, OCGA § 48-13-50 et seq.
Sec. 13.5-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases shall, for the purposes of this chapter and except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning, be defined as follows: City means the City of LaFayette and the incorporated territory of the City of LaFayette wherein the city government is empowered to impose this tax by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq. City clerk means the duly appointed city clerk of the city or his/her designee. Due date means the twentieth day after the close of the monthly period for which the tax is to be computed. Estimated tax liability means the lodging provider's prospective tax liability based upon the average monthly tax remittance in the prior fiscal year, as adjusted for change in tax rate or substantial change in circumstances due to damage to the hotel. Folio means primary documentation produced by a hotel that demonstrates interaction between the lodging provider and the occupant, and which, at a minimum, reflects the name and address given by the occupant, the date(s) of occupancy, the amount of rent charged for each date together with the amounts of applicable excise tax, and the method(s) of payment. Guest room means accommodations occupied, or intended, arranged, or designed for transient occupancy, by one (1) or more occupants for the purpose of living quarters or residential use. Hotel means any facility or any portion of a facility, including any lodging house, rooming house, dormitory, motel, motor hotel, automobile or trailer court, truckstop, tourist cabin, campground, lodge, inn, timeshare or other condominium, apartment community, public club, or private club, containing guest accommodations and which is occupied, or is intended or designed for occupancy, by paying guests, whether rent is paid in money, goods, labor, or otherwise. It does not include any hospital, asylum, sanitarium, orphanage, jail, prison, or other facility in which human beings are housed and detained under legal restraint. Lodging provider means any person operating a hotel in the city including, but not limited to, the owner or proprietor of such premises, lessee, sub-lessee, lender in possession, licensee or any other person operating such hotel; and who is subject to the taxation imposed for furnishing for value to the public any rooms, lodgings, or accommodations. Monthly period means the calendar months of any year. Occupancy means the use or possession, or the right to the use or possession of any guest room in a hotel or the right to the use or possession of the furnishings or to the services and accommodations accompanying the use and possession of the guest room. Occupant means any person who, for a consideration, uses, possesses, or has the right to use or possess any guest room in a hotel under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license to use or other agreement, or otherwise. Permanent resident means any occupant who, as of a given date, has or shall have occupied or has or shall have the right of occupancy of any guest room in a hotel for not less than thirty (30) continuous days next preceding such date. Person means any individual, firm, partnership, joint adventure, association, social club, fraternal organization, joint stock company, corporation, cooperative, estate, trust, receiver, trustee, syndicate, or any other group or combination acting as a unit, the plural as well as the singular number; excepting the United States, the State of Georgia and any instrumentality of either thereof upon which the city is without power to impose the tax. Rent means the consideration received for occupancy valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits, and property or services of any kind or nature, and also the amount for which credit is allowed by the lodging provider to the occupant, without any deduction therefrom whatsoever. Tax means the tax on occupants imposed by this chapter, as provided for by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq., specifically O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(b)(2). (Ord. No. 15-01, 2-9-2015) Sec. 13.5-2. - Tax rate. There shall be paid for every occupancy of a guest room in a hotel in the city a tax at the rate of eight (8) percent of the amount of rent unless an exemption is provided under section 13.5-4. (Ord. No. 15-01, 2-9-2015) Sec. 13.5-3. - Collection of tax by lodging provider. Every lodging provider furnishing guest rooms in a hotel in the city shall collect a tax of eight (8) percent on the amount of rent from the occupant unless an exception is provided under section 13.5-4. The lodging provider shall provide a receipt to each occupant, which receipt shall reflect both the amount of rent and the amounts of this and other tax applicable. This tax shall be due from the occupant, and shall be collected by the lodging provider at the same time that the rent is collected. The lodging provider shall be liable to the city for the full amount received or collected as tax, whether collected appropriately or inappropriately; and for any amount of tax that should have been collected, but was not. (1) Any person who receives or collects the tax or any consideration represented to be the tax from another person holds the amount so collected in trust for the benefit of the city and is liable to the city for the full amount collected, plus any applicable penalty and interest. (2) An individual who controls or supervises the collection of the tax from another person, or an individual who controls the accounting for or remittance of the tax, and who willfully fails to remit or cause to be remitted the tax is liable as a responsible individual for an amount equal to the tax not remitted or caused to be remitted, plus penalty and interest. The dissolution of a corporation, partnership or other business or fraternal association does not affect a responsible individual's liability under this subsection. Furthermore, the liability imposed by this subsection shall be in addition to any other penalty provided by law. (Ord. No. 15-01, 2-9-2015) Sec. 13.5-4. - Exceptions. No tax shall be collected from an occupant after becoming a permanent resident; or from an occupant who certifies in writing that he is staying in such accommodations as a result of his residence having been destroyed by fire or other casualty; or from the United States and the State of Georgia or any instrumentality of either thereof; or from any official or employee of the state, its units of local government or any other instrumentality of the state, when traveling on official business and presenting written substantiation thereof or paying by state or local government credit or debit card; or from a foreign sovereign enjoying exemption by treaty or consular convention, when presenting substantiation issued by the United States Department of State. Occupancy provided without charge in money or otherwise is not subject to this tax. (Ord. No. 15-01, 2-9-2015) Sec. 13.5-5. - Registration of lodging provider; form and contents; execution; certificate of authority. Every person engaging or about to engage in business as a lodging provider in the city shall immediately register with the city clerk on a form provided by said official. Persons engaged in such business must so register not later than thirty (30) days after the date that this chapter becomes effective. Such registration shall set forth the name under which such person transacts business or intends to transact business, the location of his place(s) of business and such other information which would facilitate the administration of the tax as prescribed by the city clerk. The registration shall be signed by the owner if a natural person; in case of ownership by an association or partnership, by a member or partner; in case of ownership by a corporation, by an officer. The city clerk shall, after such registration, issue without charge a certificate of authority to each lodging provider to collect the tax from the occupant. A separate registration shall be required for each place of business of a lodging provider. Each certificate shall state the name and location of the business to which it is applicable. (Ord. No. 15-01, 2-9-2015) Sec. 13.5-6. - Determination generally; returns; payments. (a) Due date of taxes . All amounts of such tax shall be due and payable to the city clerk monthly on or before the twentieth day of the month next succeeding the respective monthly period. The tax shall become delinquent for any monthly period after the twentieth day of each succeeding month during which it remains unpaid. (b) Penalty and interest for failure to pay tax by due date . A lodging provider who fails to make any return or to pay the amount of tax as prescribed, shall be assessed a specific penalty to be added to the tax in the amount of five (5) percent or five dollars ($5.00), whichever is greater, if the failure is for one (1) month or less; and an additional five (5) percent or five dollars ($5.00), whichever is greater, for each additional month or fraction thereof in which such failure shall continue; provided, however, that the aggregate penalty for any single violation shall not exceed twenty-five (25) percent or twenty-five dollars ($25.00), whichever is greater. Delinquent amounts shall bear interest at the rate of one (1) percent per month, or fraction thereof, until paid. (c) Acceptance of delinquent return and remittance without imposing penalty and interest; authority; requirements . If the failure to make any return or to pay the amount of tax by the due date results from providential cause shown to the satisfaction of the governing authority of the city by affidavit attached to the return, and remittance is made within ten (10) days of the due date, such return may be accepted exclusive of penalty and interest. (d) Waiving of penalty and interest; authority . O.C.G.A. § 48-2-41, relating to the authority to waive interest, and O.C.G.A. § 48-2-43, relating to the authority to waive penalty, shall apply; provided, however, that the governing authority shall stand in lieu of the Georgia Commissioner of Revenue, and the city shall stand in lieu of the state. (e) Penalty for fraud . In the case of a false or fraudulent return, or of failure to file a return where willful intent exists to defraud the city of any tax due, a penalty of fifty (50) percent shall be assessed. (f) Return; remittance; time of filing; lodging providers required to file; contents. On or before the twentieth day of the month succeeding each monthly period, a return for the preceding monthly period together with appropriate remittance shall be filed with the city clerk. The return shall report the gross rent, taxable rent, exempt rent, amount of tax collected or otherwise due for the period, and such other information as may be required by the city clerk. However, if the estimated tax liability for any monthly period shall exceed two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for a lodging provider who, in the prior fiscal year remitted tax greater than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) in any three (3) consecutive months, such lodging provider shall file an estimated return and remit not less than fifty (50) percent of the estimated tax liability for the monthly period by the twentieth day of that same monthly period. The amount of tax so remitted shall be credited against the amount to be due with the regular return for the monthly period to be filed on the twentieth day of the succeeding month. (g) Extension of time of filing; authority; requirements; remittance; penalty and interest. The governing authority of the city may, for good cause, extend the time for making returns for not longer than thirty (30) days. No extension shall be valid unless granted in writing upon written application of the lodging provider. Such grant may not be applicable for longer period than twelve (12) consecutive months. A lodging provider granted an extension shall remit tax equaling not less than one hundred (100) percent of the tax paid for the corresponding period of the prior fiscal year; such remittance to be made on or before the date the tax would otherwise come due without the grant of extension. No penalty or interest shall be charged during the first ten (10) days of the extension period. Thereafter, interest shall be collected on the unpaid balance at the rate of one (1) percent per month. (h) Collection fee allowed lodging providers. Lodging providers collecting the tax shall be allowed a percentage of the tax due and accounted for and shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting and paying the amount due, if the amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. The rate of the deduction shall be three (3) percent of the amount due, but only if the amount due was not delinquent at the time of payment. (Ord. No. 15-01, 2-9-2015) Sec. 13.5-7. - Deficiency determinations. (a) Recomputation of tax; authority to make; basis of recomputation. If the city clerk is not satisfied with the return or returns of the tax or the amount of the tax required to be paid to the city by any lodging provider, he/she may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of any information within his/her possession or that may come into his/her possession. One (1) or more deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one (1) or more monthly periods. (b) Penalty and interest for failure to pay tax. Penalty and interest shall be assessed upon the amount of any determination, as provided by section 13.5-6. (c) Notice of determination; service of. The city clerk shall give to the lodging provider written notice of his determination. The notice may be served personally or by mail; if by mail, such service shall be addressed to the lodging provider at his address as it appears in the records of the city. Service by mail is complete when delivered by certified mail with a receipt signed by the addressee, or when made by statutory overnight delivery. (d) Time within which notice of deficiency determination to be mailed. Except in cases of failure to make a return or of fraud, every notice of deficiency determination shall be mailed within three (3) years after the twentieth day of the calendar month following the monthly period for which the amount is proposed to be determined, or within three (3) years after the return is filed, whichever period should last expire. (e) Appeal or protest of deficiency determination. The procedure for contesting a deficiency determination shall be as provided by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-380. (Ord. No. 15-01, 2-9-2015) Sec. 13.5-8. - Determination if no return made. (a) Estimate of gross receipts. If any lodging provider fails to make a return, the city clerk shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross receipts of the lodging provider, or as the case may be, of the amount of total rentals in the city which are subject to the tax. The estimate shall be made for the period or periods in respect to which the lodging provider failed to make the return and shall be based upon any information which is or may come into the possession of the city clerk. Written notice shall be given in the manner prescribed in section 13.5-7(c). (b) Penalty and interest for failure to pay tax. Penalty and interest shall be assessed upon the amount of any determination, as provided by section 13.5-6. (Ord. No. 15-01, 2-9-2015) Sec. 13.5-9. - Collection of tax by city. (a) Action for delinquent tax; time for. At any time within three (3) years after any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected becomes due and payable, and at any time within three (3) years after the delinquency of any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected, the city clerk may bring an action in a court of competent jurisdiction in the name of the city to collect the amount delinquent together with penalty, interest, court fees, filing fees, attorney's fees and other legal fees incident thereto. (b) Lodging provider selling or quitting business. If any lodging provider liable for any amount under this chapter sells out his business or quits his business, he shall make a final return and remittance within fifteen (15) days after the date of selling or quitting the business. (c) Duty of successors or assignees of lodging provider to withhold tax from purchase money. If any lodging provider liable for any amount of tax, interest or penalty under this chapter sells out his business or quits the business, his successors or assigns shall withhold sufficiently from the purchase price to cover such amount until the former owner produces from the city clerk either a receipt reflecting full payment or a certificate stating that no amount is due. (d) Liability for failure to withhold. If the purchaser of a business fails to withhold from the purchase price as required, he shall be personally liable for the payment of the amount required to be withheld by him to the extent of the purchase price. (e) Credit for tax, penalty or interest paid more than once or erroneously or illegally collected. Whenever the amount of any tax, penalty or interest has been paid more than once, or has been erroneously or illegally collected or received by the city, it may be refunded by the governing authority. If the lodging provider or person determines that he has overpaid or paid more than once, which fact has not been determined by the city clerk, such person shall have three (3) years from the date of payment to file a claim in writing stating the specific ground upon which the claim is founded. The claimant may request a hearing before the mayor and city council, or their designee, at which the claim and any other information available will be considered. The mayor and city council, or their designee, shall approve or disapprove the claim, and notify the claimant of its action. (Ord. No. 15-01, 2-9-2015) Sec. 13.5-10. - Administration of chapter; record keeping. (a) Authority of city clerk. The city clerk shall administer and enforce the provisions of this chapter for the collection of the tax. (b) Records required from lodging providers, etc.; form. Every lodging provider renting guest rooms in the city shall preserve, for a minimum of three (3) years, all folios, receipts, certificates of exemption and such other documents as the city clerk may prescribe, and in such form as he/she may require. Said records shall at all times be available for examination within the city. (c) Examination of records; audits. The city clerk or any person authorized in writing by him/her may examine the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any lodging provider renting guest rooms and any lodging provider liable for the tax, in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or if no return is made by the lodging provider, to ascertain and determine the amount required to be paid. Such examination shall be conducted at the place of the lodging provider, unless the city clerk shall stipulate another place within the city. (d) Authority to require reports; contents. In administration of the provisions of this chapter, the city clerk may require the filing of reports by any person or class of persons having in their possession or custody information relating to the rental of guest rooms which are subject to the tax. The reports shall be filed with the city clerk when required by said official, and shall set forth the rental charged for each occupancy, the date(s) of occupancy, the basis for exemption, or such other information as the city clerk may prescribe. (Ord. No. 15-01, 2-9-2015) Sec. 13.5-11. - Violations. Any lodging provider who fails, neglects or refuses to collect the tax as provided by section 13.5-3 shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), or confinement for a term not to exceed three (3) months, or both fine and confinement. Any lodging provider who fails or refuses to make any return as provided by section 13.5-6, to keep adequate records or to open them for inspection by the city, or to furnish other data reasonably requested by the governing authority shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), or confinement for a term not to exceed three (3) months, or both. Any lodging provider who makes a false or fraudulent return with intent to evade the tax shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), nor more than three hundred dollars ($300.00), or confinement for a term not to exceed three (3) months, or both. Each and every day during any portion of which any violation is committed, continued or permitted, shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punished accordingly. (Ord. No. 15-01, 2-9-2015)

div.head: Chapter 14 - MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Vehicles in cemeteries, §§ 7-3, 7-4; junk motor vehicles, § 12-36 et seq.; wreckers, § 13-111 et seq.; police, Ch. 18; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 19; vehicles for hire, Ch. 22. State Law reference— Motor vehicles and traffic generally, OCGA Title 40; municipal authority to regulate traffic on streets and highways under its jurisdiction, OCGA § 40-6-371.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 14-1. - Rules of the road adopted; amendment of Georgia Open Container Law; penalties. (a) Adoption by reference. Pursuant to Chapter 6 of Title 40 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, Code Sections 40-6-372 through 40-6-376, Code Sections 40-6-1 to 40-6-395, with the exception of Code Section 40-6-253, of that Chapter known as the Uniform Rules of the Road and the definitions contained in Code Section 40-1-1 are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of this municipality with like effect as cited herein. Said Code Sections being herein adopted by reference are adopted as currently in force and effect and as may be amended from time to time by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia. (1) Amendment. a. Code Section 40-6-253, otherwise known as the Georgia Open Container Law, shall be amended to read as follows: "No person shall possess an open container of any alcoholic beverage while a passenger in a vehicle in this municipality. An open container shall be considered to be in the possession of a passenger of a vehicle if the container is in the physical control of the passenger." "No person shall possess an open container of any alcoholic beverage in any parked vehicle within this municipality unless said container is located in a locked glove compartment, locked trunk, or other locked, non-passenger area of the vehicle. An open container found in a parked vehicle not in a locked glove compartment, locked trunk or other locked nonpassenger area of the vehicle shall be considered to be in the possession of the owner and/or operator of a vehicle if located in the passenger compartment of the vehicle." b. This section shall not apply to: 1. A passenger of a vehicle in which the driver is operating the vehicle pursuant to a contract to provide transportation for passengers and such driver holds a valid chauffeur's license pursuant to Georgia law or any other state; 2. A passenger of a bus in which the driver holds a valid chauffeur's license pursuant to Georgia law or any other state; or 3. A passenger of a self-contained motor home which is in excess of twenty-one (21) feet. (b) Penalties. Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this section shall be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or by imprisonment for not more than thirty (30) days or by both such fine and imprisonment. (Ord. of 8-12-91, §§ 1, 2) Editor's note— An ordinance adopted Aug. 12, 1991, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, its inclusion herein as superseding former provisions contained in § 14-1 was at the discretion of the editor. Said former provisions pertained to similar subject matter as the newly included superseding provisions and derived from the Code of 1975, §§ 30-10, 30-11; Ord. of 9-22-79. Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, Ch. 4. Sec. 14-2. - Vehicles and employees of department of sanitation to have right-of-way on streets. All employees and vehicles of the department of sanitation when engaged or used in performance of the services rendered by such department, shall have the right-of-way in the use of the streets, and are hereby given permission to use any part thereof in the operation of such vehicles in cleaning up and washing the streets of the city. (Code 1975, § 30-60) Cross reference— Health and sanitation, Ch. 12. Sec. 14-3. - Through streets designated; traffic must stop before crossing. (a) Generally. The city council shall alone have authority to designate streets or parts of streets as through streets. (b) Enumerated streets. The following streets are through streets for traffic, and all vehicles entering such streets from intersecting streets, or crossing such streets, shall be required to come to a full stop before entering or crossing such streets, and shall not enter or cross such streets, until the way is clear therefor, except when governed by a traffic light or sign: (1) North Main Street and South Main Street; (2) Cove Street and Patton Avenue, from the public square to Chattanooga Street; (3) Chattanooga Street; (4) Villanow Street. (Code 1975, § 30-61) Sec. 14-4. - Limitations on turning around. The driver of any vehicle shall not turn such vehicle so as to proceed in the opposite direction upon any street within a business district, or upon any street between intersections. Such turns may be made outside of a business district at intersections not controlled by a traffic signal. (Code 1975, § 30-62) Sec. 14-5. - Bicycle warning bell required; sirens and whistles prohibited. No person shall ride a bicycle unless it is equipped with a bell or other device suitable for giving a signal audible at a distance of one hundred (100) feet, except no bicycle shall be equipped with any siren or whistle. (Code 1975, § 30-63) Sec. 14-6. - Use of coasters, roller skates and similar devices restricted. (a) Definition. For purpose of this section, skates, coasters, sleds, skateboards and toy vehicles shall be deemed to mean and shall include all nonmotorized instruments used to transport a person or persons by means of wheels, rollers, runners, etc., propelled solely by the force of its rider or another person or persons, but shall not include bicycles. (b) Prohibited activities. No person shall use, operate or permit the use or operation of any skates, coasters, sleds, skateboards or other toy vehicles upon any street, sidewalk, highway or other public ways within the corporate limits of the city. (c) Penalty for violation. Every person convicted of any provision of this section shall be punished by a fine of not more than fifty dollars ($50.00) per violation. (Code 1975, § 30-64; Ord. of 7-9-90, §§ 1—3) Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 19. State Law reference— Municipal authority to regulate skates, coasters, sleds and other toy vehicles, OCGA § 40-6-371(a)(18). Sec. 14-7. - Permits for parades and processions. No procession (except funerals) or parade containing twenty-five (25) or more persons or five (5) or more vehicles, shall occupy, march or proceed along any street, except in accordance with a permit issued by the city manager or by the office of the chief of police at the city manager's direction. (Code 1975, § 30-65) Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 19. Sec. 14-8. - Railroad trains—Blocking streets prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any engineer or conductor or person in charge of any railroad train, cars or engine to obstruct any street crossing within the city for a longer period than five (5) minutes. (Code 1975, § 30-66) Sec. 14-9. - Same—Maximum speed limit. It shall be unlawful for any engineer, conductor or other person to run any railroad train, engine or car within the city limits at a speed greater than twenty-five (25) miles per hour. (Code 1975, § 30-67) Sec. 14-10. - Towing. No vehicle shall tow more than one (1) other vehicle, nor shall the connection between vehicles exceed sixteen (16) feet in length. (Code 1975, § 30-68) Sec. 14-11. - Driving past city or public utility employees working on streets. When approaching or driving past city employees or public utility employees who are working in the street or roadway, the maximum rate of speed shall be fifteen (15) miles per hour. (Code 1975, § 30-69) Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 19. Secs. 14-12—14-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - TRAFFIC CONTROL DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 14-31. - Speed limits generally. No person shall drive a motor vehicle of any sort whatever within the corporate limits of the city in excess of the posted maximum speed limits. (Code 1975, § 30-51) State Law reference— Municipal authority to alter or establish speed limits, OCGA §§ 40-6-183, 40-6-371(a)(10). Sec. 14-32. - Maximum speed in parks and school zones. No person shall drive a motor vehicle in parks in excess of fifteen (15) miles per hour nor on streets adjoining school property during school days in excess of twenty-five (25) miles per hour, nor within three hundred (300) feet on the approach to any street adjoining school property during school days in excess of fifteen (15) miles per hour. (Code 1975, § 30-52) Cross reference— Parks and recreation, Ch. 16. Sec. 14-33. - Speed zones. (a) Speed zones are hereby created on State Road 193 as follows: (1) From milepost 0.20 (intersection of State Route 1) to milepost 1.11 (intersection of Pine Street), a distance of 0.91 mile, the speed limit shall be twenty-five (25) miles per hour. (2) From milepost 1.11 (intersection of Pine Street) to milepost 1.20 (intersection of Cavender Street), a distance of 0.09 mile, the speed limit shall be thirty-five (35) miles per hour. (3) From milepost 1.20 (intersection of Cavender Street) to milepost 1.60 (west city limits), a distance of 0.40 mile, the speed limit shall be forty-five (45) miles per hour. (b) Signs will be erected by the state department of transportation. (Ord. of 9-22-79) Sec. 14-34. - Trucks—Purpose of regulations, definitions. (a) Purpose of sections 14-34 through 14-39. To reduce hazardous traffic conditions resulting from the use of the prohibited streets by trucks and combination of vehicles; to protect the safety of the public and their lives and property in the use of the prohibited streets; and to protect the prohibited streets from unusual wear and damage. (b) Definitions. For the purpose of sections 14-34 through 14-39, the following terms shall have the meanings given herein: (1) Truck: A motor driven vehicle designed or operated for the transportation of property, including raw materials, but the following trucks are specifically excluded from the operation of sections 14-34 through 14-39: a. All trucks which have only two (2) axles and which have a load capacity of no more than eight (8) tons; and b. All trucks which have a load capacity of no more than eight (8) tons. (2) Combination of vehicles: A semitrailer pulled by a truck tractor or a semitrailer and trailer pulled by a truck tractor operating in a truck tractor-semitrailer-trailer combination. (3) Semitrailer: A detachable load-bearing unit designed to be attached to a coupling on the rear of a truck tractor by which it is partly supported. (4) Trailer: A detachable load-carrying unit designed to be attached to a coupling at the rear of a semitrailer and capable of support and operation without the truck tractor. (5) Truck tractor: The noncargo-carrying power unit that operates in combination with a semitrailer or trailer. (Ord. No. 7-88, §§ 1, 2, 8-15-88; Ord. No. 15-03, § 1, 5-11-2015) Editor's note— Ordinance No. 7-88, §§ 1—5, adopted Aug. 15, 1988, was non-amendatory of the Code; treatment of the provisions thereof as superseding §§ 14-34 and 14-35 and inclusion as new §§ 14-34—14-36 has been at the editor's discretion. Former §§ 14-34 and 14-35, pertaining to prohibition of truck traffic on Foster Mill Boulevard, derived from Code 1975, § 30-50, as amended by Ord. of Feb. 9, 1976. Sec. 14-35. - Same—Designated prohibited streets. Those city streets to which sections 14-34 through 14-39 apply and which shall be referred to as prohibited streets are as follows: (1) All portions of Foster Mill Drive within the corporate limits of the city; (2) All portions of Jefferson Street which lie within the corporate limits of the city; (3) All portions of West North Main Street which lie within the corporate limits of the city; (4) All portions of Gordon Pond Road which lie within the corporate limits of the city; (5) All portions of Probasco Street which lie within the corporate limits of the city; (6) All portions of Warthen Street which lie within the corporate limits of the city; (7) All portions of East West Main Street; (8) All portions of Duke Street; (9) All portions of Hillsdale Road which lie within the corporate limits of the city; (10) All portions of Indiana Street; (11) All portions of North Chattanooga Street; (12) All portions of West Villanow Street; and (13) All portions of Grant Street; (14) All portions of Shinbone Ridge Road which lie within the corporate limits of the city; (15) All portions of West Culberson Street and Hickory Street which lie between Chattanooga Street and Second Avenue and all portions of Second Avenue; (16) All portions of Foster Boulevard which lie within the corporate limits of the city; (17) All portions of Patterson Road which lie within the corporate limits of the city. (Ord. No. 7-88, § 3, 8-15-88; Ord. No. 8-88, 9-12-88; Ord. of 7-9-90; Ord. of 1-13-92; Ord. No. 03-03, § 1, 3-11-2003; Ord. No. 15-03, § 2, 5-11-2015) Note— See the editor's note following § 14-34. Sec. 14-36. - Same—Application of prohibited street regulation; violations. (a) No truck or combination of vehicles shall be operated on or over a prohibited street, unless in accordance with the exceptions hereinafter set out: (1) Provided the same does not violate any state law, any truck or combination of vehicles may be operated over a prohibited street where the same is absolutely necessary to reach a destination point within the city for the conduct of business, provided that the same constitutes only crossing a prohibited street, or provided that streets other than prohibited streets are used until reaching the intersection of the prohibited street and the nonprohibited street nearest to the destination and leading directly to the destination. (2) Provided the same does not violate any state law, any truck or combination of vehicles may be operated over a prohibited street where necessary to leave a point of origin within the city for the conduct of business, provided it leaves such prohibited street at the nearest intersection of a nonprohibited street to such point of origin. (3) Provided the same does not violate any state law, any truck or combination of vehicles may be operated over a prohibited street listed herein if owned or operated by the city, public utilities, any contractor or materialman, while engaged in the repair, maintenance or construction of streets, street improvements or street utilities within the city. (4) An emergency vehicle may be operated on any street within the city. (b) Violations. Any violation of sections 14-34 through 14-36 shall be an offense punishable by the recorder's court of the city. (Ord. No. 7-88, §§ 4, 5, 8-15-88) Note— See the editor's note following §§ 14-34 and 14-37. Sec. 14-37. - Same—Parking restriction. No trucks shall be allowed to park on either side of South Main Street between the south side of Patton Avenue and the north side of West Main Street in the city. (Ord. of 2-9-76) Editor's note— The above section, concerning truck parking restrictions, has been redesignated from § 14-36 to § 14-37 in order to accommodate expansion of previous sections concerning trucks, at the discretion of the editor. Sec. 14-38. - Prohibition of oversized loads. (a) It shall be unlawful for any truck with an oversized load to travel upon Main Street, Business U. S. 27, within the corporate limits of the city and lying between its intersection on the north and south with the U. S Highway 27 By-Pass (Lyle Jones Parkway), except when either the Georgia or United States Department of Transportation specially permits the oversized load to travel upon Main Street within the corporate limits of the city, as aforesaid. An oversized load shall be any load: (1) Transported by a truck; and (2) Required to have a permit by the Georgia or United States Department of Transportation. (b) Any violation of this section shall be an offense punishable by the city municipal court. (Ord. No. 09/05, § 1, 9-14-2009) Sec. 14-39. - Truck routes. (a) The city clerk shall maintain on file an accurate map of the truck routes within the corporate limits of the city. Said map, as may be amended from time to time, is incorporated herein and made a part hereof by reference. The map shall be available for inspection by the public at the office of the city clerk. A copy of the map showing the truck routes within the corporate limits of the city adopted by this section is attached hereto as exhibit "A." (b) The city shall post and maintain signs designating and providing additional information regarding the truck routes within the corporate limits of the city. (Ord. No. 15-03, § 1, 5-11-2015)
Secs. 14-40—14-50. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - DEVICES
Sec. 14-51. - Erection of traffic-control devices, city manager to have complete authority. The erection and removal of all traffic-control lights, electric signal devices, signs, markers, buttons and other traffic-control devices shall be performed solely upon order of the city manager, unless contrary provision is made by this chapter. (Code 1975, § 30-20) Sec. 14-52. - School zone signs. It shall be the responsibility of the chief of police or any person designated by him to place and remove school zone signs. (Code 1975, § 30-21) Sec. 14-53. - Through streets, duty of superintendent of public works to erect stop signs. Whenever this chapter or any ordinance of this city designates and describes a through street, it shall be the duty of the superintendent of public works to place and maintain a stop sign or yield right-of-way sign on each and every intersection of such through street. (Code 1975, § 30-22) Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks. Ch. 19. Sec. 14-54. - Designation of crosswalks, safety zones and traffic lanes. The superintendent of streets is hereby authorized: (1) To designate and maintain crosswalks by means of appropriate devices, marks or lines upon the surface of the roadway; (2) To establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as he may deem necessary for the protection of pedestrians; (3) To make lanes for traffic on street pavements at such places as he may deem advisable. (Code 1975, § 30-23) Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 19. Sec. 14-55. - Play streets; use limited. (a) The city manager shall have the authority to declare any street or part thereof a play street and to place appropriate signs or devices indicating this fact. (b) No person shall drive a vehicle upon any play street except drivers of vehicles having business or residences within such closed area. At no time shall such driver's speed exceed five (5) miles per hour. (Code 1975, § 30-24) Secs. 14-56—14-70. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Municipal authority to regulate stopping, standing and parking, OCGA § 40-6-371(a)(1).
Sec. 14-71. - Standing or parking on one-way streets. The superintendent of streets when directed by the city manager is authorized to erect signs upon the left-hand side of any one-way street to prohibit the standing or parking of any vehicle, and when such signs are in place, no person shall stand or park a vehicle upon such left-hand side in violation of any such sign. (Code 1975, § 30-30) Sec. 14-72. - Standing or parking on one-way roadways. If a highway includes two (2) or more separate roadways and traffic is restricted to one (1) direction upon any such roadway, no person shall stand or park a vehicle upon the left side of such one-way roadway unless signs are erected to permit such standing or parking. The city manager is authorized to determine when standing or parking may be permitted upon the left-hand side of any such one-way roadway and to erect signs giving notice thereof. (Code 1975, § 30-31) Sec. 14-73. - Stopping, standing or parking near hazardous or congested places. (a) The city manager is hereby authorized to determine and designate by proper signs any place not exceeding one hundred (100) feet in length in which the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles would create an especially hazardous condition or would cause unusual delay to traffic. (b) When official signs are erected at hazardous or congested places as authorized herein no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in any such designated place. (Code 1975, § 30-32) Sec. 14-74. - No parking zone established. There shall be no parking on either side of Shattuck Industrial Boulevard from the point where the same is intersected by the main line of the Central of Georgia Railway Company to the point where the same intersects the east right-of-way line of Broomtown Road, also known as Georgia State Highway No. 337. (Ord. of 11-8-76) Sec. 14-74.1. - Provisions of OCGA Section 40-6-252 regarding parking, standing or driving of vehicles in private parking areas adopted by reference. Provisions of OCGA Section 40-6-252 shall be codified in this Code of Ordinances as follows: (1) The Official Code of Georgia Annotated, Section 40-6-252 provides in subsection (a) thereof that there shall be no parking, standing or driving any vehicle in private parking areas after there has been a request not to do so; and (2) Subsection (c) of the aforesaid Code Section provides that the governing authority of a municipal corporation may by ordinance adopt the provisions of subsection (a) thereof by reference; and (3) The City of LaFayette, Georgia is desirous of adopting the provisions of subsection (a) of the aforesaid Code Section and therefore, the City of LaFayette, Georgia hereby adopts all of the provisions of subsection (a) of Section 40-6-252 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. (4) Any person violating the provisions of this Section shall be subject to a monetary fine, as follows: a. Not to exceed fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first such violation; b. Not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the second such violation; and c. Not to exceed one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for the third or each subsequent violation. (Ord. of 9-10-92) Editor's note— An ordinance adopted Sept. 10, 1992, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, its inclusion herein as § 14-74.1 was at the discretion of the editor. Sec. 14-75. - City manager to designate curb loading zones; definitions. (a) Authorized. The city manager is hereby authorized to determine the location of passenger and freight curb loading zones and shall place and maintain appropriate signs indicating the same. (b) Definitions. (1) Passenger curb loading zone. A place adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading and unloading of passengers. (2) Freight curb loading zone. A place adjacent to a curb for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of freight or passengers. (Code 1975, § 30-33) Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. Sec. 14-76. - Passenger curb loading zone. No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers in any place marked as a passenger curb loading zone during hours when the regulations applicable to such curb loading zone are effective. (Code 1975, § 30-34) Sec. 14-77. - Freight curb loading zone. (a) No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or length of time other than for the expeditious unloading or loading of materials in any place marked as a freight curb loading zone during hours when the provisions applicable to such zones are in effect. (b) The driver of a passenger vehicle may stop temporarily at a place marked as a freight curb loading zone for the purpose of loading or unloading passengers. (Code 1975, § 30-35) Sec. 14-78. - City council, city manager to designate public carrier stands. The city manager, at the direction of the city council, shall represent the city in approving the location of bus stops and stands for other passenger common-carrier motor vehicles on such public streets, in such places and in such number as shall be determined to be of the greatest benefit and convenience to the public, and every such stop, taxicab stand, or other stand shall be designated by appropriate signs. (Code 1975, § 30-36) Cross reference— Vehicles for hire, Ch. 22. Sec. 14-79. - Parking within white lines required. It shall be unlawful for any person, in parking any vehicle on any street on which white lines indicate the proper parking area, to park the vehicle on or across the while lines, but every person shall park the vehicle within the white lines, leaving sufficient space for the parking of other vehicles in the adjoining spaces. (Code 1975, § 30-37) Sec. 14-80. - Parking prohibited on narrow streets. (a) The superintendent of streets, as directed by the city manager, is hereby authorized to erect signs indicating no parking upon any street when the width of the roadway does not exceed twenty (20) feet, or upon one (1) side of a street as indicated by such signs when the width of the roadway does not exceed thirty (30) feet. (b) When official signs prohibiting parking are erected upon narrow streets as authorized herein, no person shall park upon any such street in violation of any such sign. (Code 1975, § 30-38) Sec. 14-81. - Authority of city manager to prohibit and restrict parking. (a) The city manager shall have authority to designate those streets or parts of streets in the city upon which parking shall be prohibited, or time limits shall be established, or parking shall be otherwise restricted. (b) When signs are erected giving notice of such prohibition or restriction on parking, it shall be unlawful for any person to disobey the directions of such signs. (Code 1975, § 30-39) Sec. 14-82. - Unlawful to park facing traffic. It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle on the edge of a roadway so that such vehicle is headed in the opposite direction of lawful traffic movement. (Code 1975, § 30-39.2) Secs. 14-83—14-105. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - IMPOUNDMENT AND ENFORCEMENT
Sec. 14-106. - Chief of police authorized to establish vehicle pounds. The chief of police is hereby authorized to create a vehicle pound or pounds to which automobiles and other vehicles may be removed by police officers in the manner hereinafter provided. Such pound or pounds shall be located at such places as may be designated by the chief of police. (Code 1975, § 30-70) Sec. 14-107. - When vehicle may be impounded. Whenever any vehicle shall be found parked in any place within the city where parking is not permitted at that time, or whenever any vehicle shall be found parked in violation of the terms of this chapter or any other ordinance relating to traffic, such vehicle may be removed and conveyed by any member of the police department, to a vehicle pound. (Code 1975, § 30-71) Sec. 14-108. - Immediate record of impounding to be made. It shall be the duty of the officer impounding a vehicle to immediately report the fact of such impounding, together with any other information which will identify the vehicle, to the chief of police, who shall cause a permanent record to be made thereof. (Code 1975, § 30-72) Sec. 14-109. - Release of impounded vehicle. Any person claiming a vehicle impounded under this chapter shall produce evidence of his identity and ownership or right of possession to the chief of police and pay to such officer the fees for removal and storage, for which a receipt shall be given and an order issued to the officer in charge of the pound to discharge the vehicle and to deliver the same to such person. Thereupon, the impounded vehicle shall be surrendered by the officer in charge thereof, who shall take a receipt for such impounded vehicle. Such receipt shall definitely identify the vehicle and shall become a permanent record of the police department. (Code 1975, § 30-73) Sec. 14-110. - Protest and bond permissible. (a) In case protest is made against the payment of any impounding or storage fee, the chief of police may authorize the person in charge of the impounded vehicle to discharge the same upon the following terms and conditions. (b) Such person shall be charged with violation of this article or other traffic ordinance and required to make bond for his appearance and trial before the recorder.
