(a) No person shall cause any water or other liquids to be disposed of on the streets or sidewalks of the city without the written permission of the city council. (b) The terms of this section shall not be applicable to the members of the fire department or any officer, agent, or employee of the city in the performance of a designated municipal duty. (Code 1975, § 38-15) Sec. 19-7. - Sidewalks; cleanliness responsibility of abutting property owners, enforcement. It shall be the duty of all occupants of improved property and owners of vacant property, in front of which the sidewalks have been paved, to keep such sidewalks clean, and to do such sweeping and scraping as may be necessary to remove clay, dirt and trash therefrom, and to render the same passable, comfortable and sightly. In addition, it shall be the duty of the city manager, after five days' written notice to any such person of the necessity for cleaning such sidewalk, to have done such work as may be necessary to render such walk clean and to render a bill covering the cost of such cleaning to the owner or agent of such property in person, or if such person or agent be a nonresident, then by mail. Upon the nonpayment of such bill within ten (10) days after service of same as aforesaid, the city clerk shall issue an execution therefor against the owner of the abutting property and such execution shall be a lien upon such property and shall be collected as other executions issued by the city. (Code 1975, § 38-16) Cross reference— Health and sanitation, Ch. 12. Secs. 19-8—19-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - EXCAVATIONS
Sec. 19-21. - Permit required. It shall be unlawful for any person to dig or excavate in any public place within the city or install, repair or replace any of his property or equipment in such public place, or do any other work in or on any public place, which requires the removal or breaking of the surface or underpart of any such public place, unless and until such person shall have first secured, in the manner provided in this article, permission to do so. (Code 1975, § 38-20) Sec. 19-22. - Application. Each person desiring permission to dig or excavate in any public place shall file with the city manager a written or printed application, setting forth the character and location of such work to be done in any such public place, the probable number of square yards of surface to be removed and the probable date of beginning and the completion of the work. (Code 1975, § 38-21) Sec. 19-23. - Fees and deposits. If the applicant for the permit to excavate is authorized to perform the work himself, including replacing the street to its condition prior to the excavation, there shall be no charge for the issuance of the permit. If the city must fill and resurface the street or public way, the applicant shall deposit with the city at the time of application, a sum of money which shall be fixed by the city manager and shall be based on the cost per square yard of replacement plus ten (10) percent. (Code 1975, § 38-22) Sec. 19-24. - Grant or refusal. Each application, as referred to in section 19-22 shall be considered by the city manager, who shall then, without unreasonable delay, either grant or reject such application. Upon rejection of the application, the applicant shall have the right to present the matter to the city council, the order of which shall be final in such matter, and upon final rejection, the deposit of money referred to in section 19-23 shall be returned to the person who deposited the same. (Code 1975, § 38-23) Sec. 19-25. - Failure to complete or restore. Upon the failure of any person, whose application to dig or excavate shall have been granted and who shall have begun the work, to complete the same without delay, or upon the completion of such work, to restore the public place to the same or as good a condition as the same was before such work was done, or to comply with any reasonable rules or regulations of the superintendent of streets from time to time given to such person for the completion and restoration of such public place, such person shall upon conviction, in addition to other penalties, forfeit to the city any deposit of money so made with the city. (Code 1975, § 38-24) Sec. 19-26. - Restoration by city. Upon the failure of any person to make such repairs as herein required in the manner or in the time required, the city manager is empowered and authorized to cause such repairs to be made and such public place to be restored to its original condition, and the cost thereof, plus ten (10) percent thereof, shall be charged to and paid by such person who so failed to make such repairs, and such sum of money shall constitute and be a debt due from such person to the city. (Code 1975, § 38-25) Sec. 19-27. - Use or refund of deposit. The deposit of money made under section 19-23 shall stand as a guarantee and may be employed by the city for the replacement of such public place in as good condition as the same was immediately before the excavation or digging, and upon default of the person so making such deposit to restore immediately the public place to as good condition as the same was immediately before such excavation or digging was done by him, the city manager may employ the whole or any part of such deposit of money necessary for such restoration. Upon the restoration of the public place to such condition as the same was immediately before such digging or excavating, the city clerk shall, upon the certificate of the city manager, restore to the person so making such deposit such sum of money so deposited, or in case any part thereof is employed by the city for such restoration of such public place, upon such certificate, the city clerk shall refund such part of such sum of money so remaining. (Code 1975, § 38-26) Sec. 19-28. - Prompt work. All digging or excavating to be done, as provided in this article, shall be promptly started and completed without delay after permission shall have been granted, and such public place shall be, immediately upon the completion of such work, restored to the same or as good condition as the same was before such work was done thereon. Such work or restoration shall be at all times and in all respects in compliance with the orders and supervision of the superintendent of streets from time to time given to such person for such purpose. (Code 1975, § 38-27) Sec. 19-29. - Warning devices; posting permit. Upon the granting of an application for permission to dig or excavate in any public place, and in all other cases provided for in this chapter, it shall be the duty of the applicant, before beginning any such work, to enclose the place where such work is being done or otherwise afford adequate protection to street traffic. He shall post and keep posted at such place a placard showing that the work is being done under a permit granted by the city, with sufficient other information thereon to give ample warning to those using such public place that the same is out of repair or being repaired, and in addition thereto, he shall place sufficient markings at night by a red or amber light, to notify those having the right to use the same that such public place, or part thereof, is closed. (Code 1975, § 38-28) Sec. 19-30. - Decision of city council final. Any controversy between the person making a deposit in order to dig or excavate in any public place and the superintendent of streets or the city manager, respecting any of the duties to be performed by any of them, may be submitted to the city council by any of the parties, and when so submitted, the action of the city council thereon shall be binding on all the parties. (Code 1975, § 38-29) Secs. 19-31—19-45. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - OPENING AND CLOSING STREETS
Sec. 19-46. - Initiation of action to open or close street, by council motion, by petition; to be tabled until next meeting. (a) Any action to either open or close a street or alley or any portion thereof within the city limits shall be initiated either by the city council, upon its own motion, or by petition of all abutting property owners of the portion of the street or alley to be opened or closed, the petition to be filed with the city clerk and brought before the mayor and council at its next meeting, either regular or called. (b) At the meeting of the mayor and council, if such action is recommended by motion of any member of the city council, the same shall be read and tabled for action at the next regular meeting, or if such action is initiated by petition, the petition shall be read and tabled for action at the next regular meeting, and at the next regular meeting evidence shall be heard, if presented, and the determination of the city council made at such time and spread upon the minutes. The city council may table final determination until the next regular meeting, if it so desires, and if the same is so tabled, it shall not be necessary to republish the public notice provided in section 18-47. (Code 1975, § 38-30) Sec. 19-47. - Publication of notice in newspaper required. Between the time of the first reading of the motion or petition to open or close a street or alley or any portion thereof, and the next regular meeting of the city council, the clerk of the city shall cause to be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city a notice to the public of the proposed opening or closing of a street or alley or any portion thereof, and the time and place of the meeting at which a determination of such matter shall be made by the city council. Such public notice shall be published in such newspaper once a week for four (4) weeks immediately preceding the meeting at which said determination is to be made. (Code 1975, § 38-31) Sec. 19-48. - Assessment of cost of proceeding. The cost of any such proceeding, including all advertising costs, shall be borne by the city if the same is initiated upon motion of the city council, and the cost thereof shall be borne by the petitioner if the same is initiated by petition of abutting property owners, the cost to be paid to the city at the time of the filing of the petition. (Code 1975, § 38-32) Sec. 19-49. - Closing of street, not to be construed as abandonment. If any street or alley or portion thereof is closed under this procedure, the same shall not be considered abandoned, and any such action shall not be construed as an abandonment by the city. There shall be no abandonment of any street or portion thereof unless the city council shall specifically declare a street or any portion thereof "abandoned" in a properly passed resolution. (Code 1975, § 38-33) Sec. 19-50. - Closed street, city may sell or use for other purposes. The title to streets or alleys closed by such action shall remain in the city unless sold as herein provided for. The city may either use the property for public purposes; hold title thereto and reopen the same as a public street or alley, if the city council shall in the future determine to do the same; or may sell the property to the abutting property owners, the centerline of said street or alley to be the dividing line, at the fair and reasonable market value of the property at the time of such sale. (Code 1975, § 38-34) Secs. 19-51—19-65. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - CUTTING AND CONSTRUCTION
Sec. 19-66. - Permit required. It shall be unlawful for anyone to cut or construct a street or lane belonging to the city, or to cause the same to be cut or constructed without first obtaining a permit from the building inspector of the city. (Code 1975, § 38-40) Sec. 19-67. - Application, required information. Before any street or lane is cut or constructed in the city an application for a street permit must be made to the building inspector. The application must be in writing and must contain the following information: (1) The location of the street or lane including a legal description of the land where the street or lane is proposed; (2) The width of the street or lane and the length of the same; (3) The purpose of the street or lane; (4) The type of construction of the proposed street or lane including the type of pavement, width of pavement and type of base; (5) The name of the proposed street contractor or paving company; (6) The plans for the street or lane must show that proper drainage is provided; (7) If the street is to be a public street or a street to be accepted as a part of the system of city streets, the application must indicate when the proposed layout, cutting and construction of the street or lane is to commence, when the same should be completed and must give full assurance that the applicant is financially capable of paying for improvements and completing the same in accordance with the plans as contained in the application; (8) Whether or not the street or lane will be dedicated to the public; and (9) Whether or not the city will be requested to accept the street or lane into the system of city streets. (Code 1975, § 38-41) Sec. 19-68. - Public streets, no permit unless city requirement met. No permit for cutting or constructing any street or lane shall be issued for any street or lane which is to be dedicated to the public or is to become a part of the system of city streets unless the same meets all of the right-of-way requirements and paving and base requirements of the city. (Code 1975, § 38-42) Sec. 19-69. - Public street defined. For the purposes of this article any street or lane on which more than two (2) dwelling units or more than two (2) business establishments or more than two (2) manufacturing establishments or any combination of the aforesaid totaling more than two (2) shall be located shall be presumed to be a public street or lane. (Code 1975, § 38-43) Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. Sec. 19-70. - Building permits not to be issued on streets in violation of article. No building permit shall be issued for any construction for new dwellings or buildings or expansion of existing dwellings or buildings on any street or lane which exists in violation of this article or any portion hereof. (Code 1975, § 38-44) Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6. Sec. 19-71. - Appeal from denial of building permit or street permit, procedure. The denial of a street permit by the building inspector or the denial of a building permit by the building inspector due to violations of this article may be appealed directly to the mayor and council. Any such appeal must be in writing, must have attached thereto a copy of the application which has been previously filed with the building inspector, and must be delivered to the city clerk at the city hall not later than ten (10) days after the denial of the street permit or building permit. The appeal must state clearly the name and address of the appellant, and the telephone, if any, of the appellant. The mayor and council must conduct a public hearing on the appeal within forty-five (45) days from the date the appeal is filed with the city clerk, and the appellant must be notified in writing by the city clerk of the date, time and place of the hearing, it being sufficient for the purposes of this article that the notice be mailed to the appellant at the address given in the appeal by regular United States mail at least seven (7) days prior to the date set for the hearing. (Code 1975, § 38-45) Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6. Sec. 19-72. - Violations. The cutting or construction of any street or lane in violation of this article or any part hereof shall constitute an offense punishable by the recorder's court. (Code 1975, § 38-46) Sec. 19-73. - Injunctions against violations. In addition to any criminal penalty imposed under section 19-71, the cutting or constructing of any street or lane in violation of this article or any part hereof may be enjoined in the Superior Court of Walker County, Georgia. (Code 1975, § 38-47) Secs. 19-74—19-79. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - REGULATION OF TIMBER HARVESTING ACTIVITY
Sec. 19-80. - Title. This article is known as the "Regulation of Timber Harvesting Activity." (Ord. No. 18-04, § 1, 2-12-2018) Sec. 19-81. - Definitions. As used in this article, timber harvesting shall means the harvesting of standing timber for delivery as pulpwood, logs, poles, posts, or wood chips to any woodyard or processing plant located inside or outside this state. Such term shall not apply to landscaping or removal of dead or diseased trees from public or private property. (Ord. No. 18-04, § 1, 2-12-2018) Sec. 19-82. - Purpose and intent. It is the purpose and intent of this article to protect the public streets and roads of the city from damage, including erosion and deposits of sedimentation, that often occur from timber harvesting activities. This article is enacted pursuant to the authority of a municipal corporation to regulate streets or roads within its jurisdiction in accordance with O.C.G.A. Title 32. Nothing in this article is intended to preclude the city from imposing regulations on private land use activities relating to development, such as zoning, tree protection, landscaping, or streamside buffer regulations. (Ord. No. 18-04, § 1, 2-12-2018) Sec. 19-83. - Timber harvesting requirements and application process. (a) All timber harvesters harvesting timber in the City of LaFayette must comply with all relevant provisions of O.C.G.A. § 12-6-24 in order to use any public street or road(s) in the city for transporting harvested timber, other than a federal or state highway. (b) An appointment for ingress/egress inspection shall be scheduled forty-eight (48) hours in advance of the commencement of activity with the public works director to allow the public works director and the codes enforcement director or their designated agents to inspect the site prior to any activity at the proposed ingress/egress location. (c) The following minimum standards shall be met unless directed otherwise by the public works director or codes enforcement director or their respective designated agent: (1) Use geotextile underliner minimum twenty (20) feet wide under gravel pad. (2) Minimum drive width shall be twenty (20) feet. (3) Minimum thickness of six (6) inches constructed of one and one-half (1½) inches to three and one-half (3½) inches of coarse aggregate for a minimum drive length of fifty (50) feet. (4) The street or road, at each ingress/egress point, shall be posted with four (4) forty-eight-inch orange "Trucks Entering Highway" advance warning signs placed on the shoulder of the road at five hundred (500) feet and one thousand (1,000) feet intervals from both directions. Signs and posts shall conform to the current edition of the Manual for Uniform Traffic Control Devices. (5) All tree harvesting activities shall be performed in accordance with generally accepted forestry land management practices and/or agricultural operations, not incidental to development, on tracts zoned for or used for forestry, silvicultural, or agricultural purpose. (d) No harvester equipment or vehicle(s) may be parked on a public right-of-way or use the public right-of-way as a loading facility. (e) Once items (a) through (c)(4) have been accomplished and notification given to the public works director or his designated agent, the timber harvester must provide the following to the public works director: (1) Persons or firms conducting timber harvesting activities in the City of LaFayette shall furnish to the city, a surety bond in the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) in a form required by law and approved by the city attorney prior to beginning any timber harvesting activities or, at the option of the person or firm harvesting timber, a valid irrevocable letter of credit issued by a bank or savings and loan association, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 7-1-4, in the amount of and in lieu of such bond. A separate surety bond or letter of credit shall be required for each tract for which timber harvesting is to occur. In addition, a map of the area identifying the location of the tract to be harvested and the main point and any alternate points of ingress to such tract from a public road and, if different, any point of egress from such a tract to a public road. Said bond or letter of credit shall indemnify and protect the city from any damage to public street or road(s) or clean-up cost associated with any timber harvesting activity conducted. (2) Said bond(s) or letter(s) of credit shall be valid only for the calendar year in which it is issued. (3) Timber harvester shall submit a fully completed notice of timber harvesting activity, in the form approved by the Georgia Forestry Commission, as found on its website, along with all requested additional information and surety bond(s) or bank letter(s) of credit to the public works director, who along with the codes enforcement director, then shall review the documentation submitted and then the public works director shall notify the timber harvester of approval or denial to proceed with the timber harvesting process. It shall be the duty of the public works director to promptly provide a copy of every approved notice of timber harvesting activity to the Office of the Walker County Commissioner. Pursuant to the soil erosion, sedimentation and pollution control ordinance, section 18.5-7(d), a citation will be issued immediately by the public works director or codes enforcement director upon proof of any sediment entering onto a public street or road or sedimentation entering any waters of the state or United States. (Ord. No. 18-04, § 1, 2-12-2018) Sec. 19-84. - Liability for violation of this article. (a) Liability . (1) Violation of the notice requirements of this article shall result in the immediate issuance of a stop-work order by the public works director or codes enforcement director against the timber harvester, and issuance of a citation, returnable to the Municipal Court of LaFayette, Georgia. Upon conviction, a violator shall be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00). (2) Neither the approval of a plan under the provisions of this article, nor the compliance with provisions of this article shall relieve any person from the responsibility for damage to any person or property otherwise imposed by the law nor impose any liability upon the city for damages to any person or property. (3) No provision of this article shall permit any persons to violate the Georgia Erosion and Sedimentation Act of 1975, the Georgia Water Quality Control Act, any rules and regulations promulgated and approved thereunder, any local ordinance(s) enacted pursuant thereto, or to pollute any waters of the state or United States, as defined thereby. (Ord. No. 18-04, § 1, 2-12-2018) Secs. 19-85—19-89. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - UTILITY ACCOMMODATION POLICY AND ISSUANCE OF RIGHT-OF-WAY PERMITS
Sec. 19-90. - Declaration of findings, purpose, scope, definitions. (a) Intent and purpose. The City of LaFayette (the "city") is vitally concerned with the use, construction within, and occupancy of all rights-of-way in the city as such rights-of-way are a valuable and limited resource which must be utilized to promote the public health, safety, welfare, and economic development of the city and to protect public works infrastructure. Therefore, the city, under the authority of the Laws and Constitution of the State of Georgia including, but not limited to O.C.G.A. 32-4-92, has adopted this article for the purpose of regulating public and private entities which use the city rights-of-way. (b) Scope. The provisions of this chapter apply to all utilities and facilities occupying the rights-of-way as provided in this article. (c) Definitions. For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations, whether capitalized or lowercase, have the following meanings: Business day is defined as defined in O.C.G.A. 25-9-3(3). City means the City of LaFayette, Georgia. Codified ordinances means the LaFayette City Code. Construct means, but shall not be limited to, dig, bore, tunnel, trench, excavate, obstruct, install or remove facilities, other than landscaping or ornamental plantings, in, on, above, within, over, below, under, or through any part of the rights-of-way. Construct shall also include the act of opening or cutting into the surface of any paved or improved surface that is any part of the right-of-way. Construction means, but shall not be limited to, the act or process of digging, boring, tunneling, trenching, excavating, obstructing, installing or removing facilities, other than landscaping or ornamental plantings, in, on, above, within, over, below, under, along or through any part of the rights-of-way. Construction shall also include the act of opening, boring or cutting into the surface of any part of the right-of-way. Department means the City of LaFayette Public Works Department. Director means the Public Works Director of the City of LaFayette, Georgia, or his or her designee. Emergency means a condition that poses a clear and immediate danger to life, health, or safety of a person, or of significant damage or loss of real or personal property caused by such things as natural disasters, fire, subversive activities, and like events. Facility or facilities means any tangible thing, including, but not limited to, pipes, mains, conduits, cables, wires, poles, signs, towers, traffic control devices and other signals, and other equipment, appurtenances, appliances and future technology of any utility in, on, above, within, over, below, under, along or through any part of the rights-of-way in the city. Facilities representative(s) means the specifically identified agent(s)/employee(s) of a utility who are authorized to direct field activities of that utility and serve as official notice agent(s) for facilities-related information. Utility must ensure at least one (1) of its facilities representatives is available at all times to receive notice of, and immediately direct response to, facilities-related emergencies or situations; FCC means the Federal Communications Commission or any successor agency. Permit means an authorization which grants permission to conduct specific regulated activities in, on, above, within, over, below, under, along or through any public right-of-way, and which may be subject to conditions specified in a written agreement with the city or in a related provision of this Code of Ordinances. Right(s)-of-way means the surface and space in, on, above, within, over, below, under or through any real property in which the city has an interest in law or equity, whether held in fee, or other estate or interest, or as a trustee for the public, including, but not limited to, any public street, boulevard, road, highway, freeway, lane, alley, court, sidewalk, parkway, or any other place, area, or real property owned by or under the legal or equitable control of the city that, now or hereafter, is consistent with the purposes for which it was dedicated, may be used for the purposes of constructing, operating, repairing or replacing facilities. Service(s) means the offering of any service by a utility for a fee directly to the public, or to such classes of users as to be effectively available directly to the public, or alternatively, the provision of any service by a utility between two (2) or more points for a proprietary purpose to a class of users other than the general public. Service agreement means a valid license agreement, service agreement, franchise agreement, or operating agreement issued by the city or state pursuant to law and accepted by a utility or entered into by and between the city and a utility, which allows such utility to operate or provide service within the geographic limits of the city. Street or streets means the surface of, as well as the spaces above and below, any and all the streets, alleys, avenues, roads, bridges, tunnels and public places of the city within the corporate limits of the city, as the same now exist or may be hereafter extended or altered, and any location thereon, thereover or thereunder, and any portion thereof. Transfer means the disposal by the utility, directly or indirectly, by gift, assignment, sale, merger, consolidation, or otherwise, of more than fifty (50) percent at one (1) time of the ownership or controlling interest in the facility, or of more than fifty (50) percent cumulatively over the term of a written approval of registration of such interests to a corporation, partnership, limited partnership, trust, or association, or person or group of persons acting in concert. Unused facility or facilities means facilities located in the rights-of-way which have remained unused for twelve (12) months and for which the utility is unable to provide the city with a plan detailing the procedure by which the utility intends to begin actively using such facilities within the next twelve (12) months, or that it has a potential purchaser or user of the facilities who will be actively using the facilities within the next twelve (12) months, or, that the availability of such facilities is required by the utility to adequately and efficiently operate its facilities. Utility or utilities means all privately, publicly, or cooperatively owned systems for producing, transmitting, or distributing communication, data, information, telecommunication, cable television, video services, power, electricity, light, heat, gas, oil, crude products, water/sewer, steam, fire and police signals, traffic control devices, and street lighting systems, and housing or conduit for any of the foregoing, which directly or indirectly serve the public or any part thereof. The term "utility" may also be used to refer to the owner, operator, utility, service, contractor or subcontractor, or any agent thereof, of any above-described utility or utility facility. (Ord. No. 19-01, § 1, 1-14-2019) Sec. 19-91. - Utility registration. (a) Registration required. Each utility who occupies, uses or has facilities in the rights-of-way at the time of passage of this article, including by lease, sublease or assignment to operate facilities located in the rights-of-way, unless specifically exempted by state or federal law or this Code, must file a registration statement with the department within ninety (90) days of the effective date of this article. (b) Registration procedure. The registration information provided to the city must be on a form approved by the city and include, but not be limited to: (1) The name, legal status (i.e. partnership, corporation, etc.), street address, email address, and telephone and facsimile numbers of the utility filing the registration statement (the "registrant"). If the registrant is not the owner of the facility in the right-of-way, the registration must include the name, street address, email address if applicable, and telephone and facsimile numbers of the owner; The name, street address, email address and telephone and facsimile numbers of one (1) or more facilities representative(s). Current information regarding how to contact the facilities representative(s) in an emergency must be provided at the time of filing a registration and must be updated as necessary to assure accurate contact information is available to the city at all times. (2) A copy, if requested, of the utility's certificate of authority (or other acceptable evidence of authority to operate) from the Georgia Public Service Commission or the FCC and any other similar approvals, permits, or agreements. (3) A copy, if requested, of the utility's certificate of authority (or other acceptable evidence of authority to operate) from the Georgia Public Service Commission or the FCC and any other similar approvals, permits, or agreements. (4) A copy, if requested, of the service agreement or other legal instrument that authorizes the utility to use or occupy the right-of-way for the purpose described in the registration. (c) Incomplete registration. If a registration is incomplete, the director must promptly notify the registrant and must provide a reasonable period of time in which to complete the registration. When a registration is complete, the director will accept it and so notify the utility in writing. (d) Acceptance of the registration does not convey title in the rights-of-way. Acceptance of the registration is only the nonexclusive, limited right to occupy rights-of-way in the city for the limited purposes stated in the acceptance. Acceptance of the registration does not excuse a utility from obtaining permits required by city codes nor from obtaining appropriate access or pole attachment agreements before using the facilities of others, including the city. Acceptance of the registration does not excuse a utility from notifying the city of construction as required in this article. (e) Facilities in place without registration. Beginning one (1) year after the effective date of this article, any facilities or part of a facility found in a right-of-way for which registration is required but has not been obtained, unless specifically exempted by law, and for which no valid service agreement exists with the city, may be deemed to be a nuisance and an unauthorized use of the rights-of-way. The city may exercise any remedies or rights it has at law or in equity, including, but not limited to abating the nuisance; taking possession of the facilities, evicting the utility from the right-of-way; prosecuting the violator; or any other remedy provided by City codes or otherwise allowed in law or in equity. (Ord. No. 19-01, § 1, 1-14-2019) Sec. 19-92. - Construction permits. (a) Permit required. It is unlawful for any utility to excavate or to construct, install, maintain, renew, remove or relocate facilities in, on, above, within, over, below, under, along or through the public roads of the city without a utility permit from the department of public works in accordance with the terms of this article. (b) Permit procedure. Utility permits must be obtained from the director (or such other person as the city manager may designate) upon application made on forms prescribed by the department of public works. The written application must include the following: (1) The name and address of the utility; (2) The nature, extent, and location of any work proposed to be done, along with satisfactory plans as attachments showing in detail the location of the proposed facility or operations as described in the permit application. The plans must show the size or capacity of facilities to be installed; their relationship to street features such as right-of-way lines, pavement edge, structures, etc., horizontal and vertical clearance to critical elements of the roadway and any other information necessary to evaluate the impact on the street and its operation; (3) The name and address of the person or firm who is to do such work; (4) The name, street address, email address and telephone and facsimile numbers of one (1) or more facilities representative(s); (5) The projected dates for the work to be started and completed; (6) An indemnity bond or other acceptable security in an amount to be set by the city to pay any damages to any part of the city road system or other city property or to any city employee or member of the public caused by activity or work of the utility performed under authority of the permit issued; (7) A copy, if requested, of the registrant's certificate of authority (or other acceptable evidence of authority to operate) from the Georgia Public Service Commission or the FCC and any other similar approvals, permits, or agreements; and (8) A copy, if requested, of the service agreement or other legal instrument that authorizes the utility to use or occupy the right-of-way for the purpose described in the application. (c) Permit fees. Fees will be determined by resolution of the mayor and council, as from time to time amended. A fee schedule will be available at the offices of the director and the city manager and open for public inspection and copying, without charge. (d) Issuance of permit. If the director determines the applicant has satisfied the following requirements, the director may issue a permit. (1) Whether issuing of the approval will be consistent with this article; (2) Whether applicant has submitted a complete application and has secured all certificates and other authorizations required by law in order to construct facilities in the manner proposed by the applicant; and (3) The impact on safety, visual quality of the streets, traffic flow, and other users of the right-of-way and the difficulty and length of time of the project, construction or maintenance. (e) Emergency situations. (1) Each utility must, as soon as reasonably practicable, notify the director of any event regarding its facilities which it considers to be an emergency. The utility may proceed to take whatever actions are necessary in order to respond to the emergency. A utility who engages in an emergency excavation must take all reasonable precautions to avoid or minimize damage to any existing facilities. (2) In the event that the city becomes aware of an emergency regarding utility facilities, the city may attempt to contact the affected utility or facilities representative. The city may take whatever action it deems necessary in order to respond to the emergency, including cut or move any of the wires, cables, amplifiers, appliances, or other parts of the facilities. The city does not incur any liability to the utility for such emergency actions, and the cost of such must be paid by each utility affected by the emergency. (f) Effective period of permit. (1) Each permit must have a set commencement and expiration date based on information provided in the applicant's permit application. (2) The permit must remain in place until construction is completed or until its stated expiration date, unless the utility is in default. The director may give written notice of default to a utility if it is determined that a utility has: a. Violated any provision or requirement of the issuance or acceptance of a permit application or any law of the city, state, or federal government; b. Attempted to evade any provision or requirement of this chapter; c. Practiced any fraud or deceit upon the city; or d. Made a material misrepresentation or omission of fact in its permit application. (g) Cancellation for cause. If a utility fails to cure a default within twenty (20) business days after notice is provided to the utility by the city, then the default is a material breach and the city may exercise any remedies or rights it has at law or in equity to terminate the permit. If the director determines there is cause or reason to terminate, the following procedure will be followed: (1) City will serve a utility with a written notice of the reason or cause for proposed termination and shall allow a utility a minimum of fifteen (15) calendar days to cure its breach. (2) If the utility fails to cure within fifteen (15) calendar days, the city may declare the permit terminated. (h) Expiration of permit. If work is not begun within six (6) months of the date of issuance, the permit will automatically expire. (Ord. No. 19-01, § 1, 1-14-2019) Sec. 19-93. - Required minimum standards. (a) Utility accommodation manual adopted. The 2016 GDOT Utility Accommodation Policy and Standards Manual, including all references contained to codes, rules, regulations, schedules, forms and appendix items, except appendix B (permit forms and supporting documents), promulgated by the State of Georgia Department of Transportation, as may be amended from time to time, is hereby adopted by reference and incorporated in this article as if fully set forth in this article, subject to the amendments and modification contained in this article. A copy of the manual will be maintained in the offices of the director or his or her designee and open for public inspection and copying. Copies of the manual are also available on the Georgia Department of Transportation's website. Any conflicts between the provisions of this article and the manual will be resolved in favor of the manual. References to state personnel, agencies, and fees will be interpreted, where required, as meaning the City of LaFayette municipal equivalents. (b) Protection of traffic and roadway. Unless specifically stated in the permit, no utility may occupy city rights-of-way unless sufficient space is available so that the free flow and safety of traffic and other capacity considerations are not unduly impaired and the installation does not prevent the department from reasonably maintaining the streets, structures, traffic control devices and other appurtenant facilities, and further provided that maintenance and operations of the facilities do not jeopardize the traffic, street structure, other users of the right-of-way or the right-of-way itself. (c) Grading. If the grades or lines of any street within the city right-of-way are changed at any time by the city or by federal or state highway authorities during the term of the permit and this change involves an area in which the utility's facilities are located, then the utility must, at its own cost and expense and upon the request of the city upon reasonable notice, protect or promptly alter or relocate the facilities, or any part thereof, so as to conform with such new grades or lines. In the event the utility refuses or neglects to so protect, alter, or relocate all or part of the facilities, the city will have the right to break through, remove, alter, or relocate all or any part of the facilities without any liability to the utility, and the utility must pay to the city the costs incurred in connection with such breaking through, removal, alteration, or relocation. (d) Installation of poles and other wireholding structures and relocation. Unless otherwise provided in a valid service agreement, no placement of any pole or wireholding structure of the utility is to be considered a vested interest in the right-of-way, and such poles or structures are to be removed, relocated underground, or modified by the utility at its own expense whenever the city determines that the public convenience would be enhanced thereby. The facilities must be so located and installed as to cause minimum interference with the rights and convenience of property owners. (e) Utilities protection. As provided in O.C.G.A § 25-9-6 (the Georgia Utility Facility Protection Act) and other applicable state law currently in place or as amended, no utility may commence, perform, or engage in blasting or in excavating with mechanized excavating facilities unless and until the utility planning the blasting or excavating has given forty-eight (48) hours' notice by submitting a locate request to the utility protection center, beginning the next business day, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 25-9-3(3), after such notice is provided, excluding hours during days other than business days. (Ord. No. 19-01, § 1, 1-14-2019) Sec. 19-94. - Restoration of property. (a) Each utility is responsible for the cost of repairing any facilities in the rights-of-way and adjoining property or other facilities which it or its facilities damage. (b) A utility is liable, at its own cost and expense, to replace, restore or repair, any street, facilities or property or structure on, under, over or adjacent to the right-of-way that may become disturbed or damaged as a result of the construction or installation, operation, upgrade, repair or removal of facilities to a condition as good as or better than its condition before the work performed by the utility that caused such disturbance or damage. If the utility does not commence such replacement or repair within twenty (20) business days following written notice from the city, the city or the owner of the affected structure or property may make such replacement or repair and the utility must pay the reasonable and actual cost of the same. (Ord. No. 19-01, § 1, 1-14-2019) Sec. 19-95. - Inspection. (a) The utility must make the construction site available to the director and to all others as authorized by law for inspection at all reasonable times during the execution and upon completion of the construction. (Ord. No. 19-01, § 1, 1-14-2019) Sec. 19-99. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - SMALL WIRELESS FACILITY SITING
Sec. 19-100. - Declaration of findings, purpose, scope, definitions. (a) Intent and purpose. The purpose of this article is to provide policies and procedures for regulating the placement of small wireless facilities in certain rights-of-way within the jurisdiction of the city, which will provide a public benefit consistent with the preservation of the integrity, safe usage, and visual qualities of the city rights-of-way and the city as a whole. The article is intended to facilitate and promote the expeditious deployment of the small wireless facilities necessary to provide citizens with the benefits of advanced wireless services through establishing uniform standards associated with the siting of such antennas. This article is intended to: (1) Prevent interference with the use of streets, sidewalks, alleys, parkways, poles, and other public ways and places; (2) Prevent the creation of visual and physical obstructions and other conditions that are hazardous to vehicular and pedestrian traffic; (3) Prevent interference with other facilities and operations of facilities lawfully located in city rights-of-way or public property; (4) Protect against environmental damage, including damage to trees or shrubbery including, but not limited, those items planted pursuant to city landscaping, zoning, tree preservation, or other city policies; (5) Preserve the property values of neighborhoods in which small wireless facilities are installed or proposed; (6) Preserve the character of historic structures including, but not limited to, such structures or neighborhoods listed on the National Register of Historic Places and local historic preservation districts or historic districts; (7) Preserve public rights-of-way and areas with underground utility facilities where small wireless facilities would be cost prohibitive and aesthetically incompatible; and (8) Preserve the public rights-of-way with insufficient space to accommodate small wireless facilities. (b) Scope. The provisions of this article apply to the siting of all small wireless facilities employed by any provider of wireless services within the city's rights-of-way. If this article conflicts with any other ordinance of the city, this article will supersede all other ordinances, except that any facilities permitted under this section must also comply with article VI of this chapter. (c) Definitions. For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations, regardless of whether capitalized or lowercase, have the following meanings: Ancillary equipment means equipment not included in the calculation of SWF equipment volume including the electric meter, ground-based enclosures, grounding materials, power transfer switch and cut-off switch. Antenna means communication equipment that transmits or receives electromagnetic radio frequency signals used in the provision of wireless services. Applicable codes means uniform building, fire, electrical, plumbing, or mechanical codes adopted by a recognized national code organization or local amendments to those codes enacted solely to address imminent threats of destruction of property or injury to persons to the extent not inconsistent with the term of this section. Applicant means any person who submits an application for a SWF located on city rights-of-way or city-owned property. Application means a request submitted by an applicant for a permit to install, collocate, modify, or replace a SWF within the city rights-of-way; or to install, modify, or replace a wireless support structure or pole within the right-of-way. Attachment agreement means an agreement between the WIP and the owner of a pole owned by an entity other than the WIP, including the city, utility or other entity, authorizing the attachment of small wireless facilities to the pole. City means the City of LaFayette, Georgia. City-approved pole means a pole which has been evaluated and approved by city staff for use within the right-of-way. A list of pre-approved poles and a set of specifications for newly proposed poles will be maintained by the department for both rights-of-way in protected areas and general use areas. Collocate means to install, attach, maintain, modify, operate, or replace wireless attachments and associated ancillary equipment on or adjacent to a pole or pre-existing wireless support structure which already contains a SWF located thereupon. "Collocation," has a corresponding meaning. Department means the city's public works department. Director means the director of the city's public works department. Fee means a one-time, non-recurring charge. Permit means a permit issued by the city upon review-and approval, of an application for the installation, collocation, modification or replacement of a SWF, wireless support structure, pole, or associated fiber lines within the right-of-way. Person means an individual, corporation, limited liability company, partnership, association, trust, or other entity or organization with experience deploying wireless support structures. Pole means: a. A utility pole owned or operated by the city in the rights-of-way, including a utility pole that provides street and security lighting, traffic control functions and other law enforcement functions, including, but not limited to, other light poles and structures for signage; b. A pole owned, operated or maintained by the city in the rights-of-way that supports wireless facilities; or c. A pole owned, operated or maintained by any person that supports small cell wireless facilities or other utility infrastructure located within the city's rights-of-way by permit or under an agreement with the city. Protected area means areas of the city designated by the city council in which all or a portion of the utilities have been placed underground, or in which new utilities are required to be underground, or in which a future underground project is expected, or for which a corridor in which a design project is being proposed, or for which streetscaping, historic preservation, or other considerations require either the design and construction of small wireless facilities in a manner that conforms to the existing aesthetic and structural schemes. The department will maintain a map designating each protected area and a corresponding list of city-approved poles for each area. Rate means a recurring charge. Right(s)-of-way means the surface and space in, on, above, within, over, below, under or through any real property in which the city has an interest in law or equity, whether held in fee, or other estate or interest, or as a trustee for the public, including, but not limited to, any public street, boulevard, road, highway, freeway, lane, alley, court, sidewalk, parkway, or any other place, area, or real property owned by or under the legal or equitable control of the city. Sign pole means any sign supported by a sign structure secured in the ground and which is wholly independent of any other support. The structure may include guyed wires between two (2) poles on which the sign may be affixed. Small wireless facility ("SWF") means a small cell antenna or distributed antenna system with wireless attachments that meet the following qualifications: a. Antenna(s) that fit(s) within an enclosure of no more than six (6) cubic feet in volume, and b. All other wireless attachments and ancillary equipment associated with the facility whether pole-mounted or located on the ground (where allowed) which may total no more than twenty-four (24) cubic feet in volume. Utility pole means a pole or similar structure that is or may use in whole or in part for electric distribution, telecommunications, cable or electric service, or for lighting, traffic control signage, or a similar function regardless of ownership, including city-owned poles. Wireless attachments means equipment at a fixed location that enables wireless communications between user equipment and a communication network, including: a. Equipment associated with wireless communications; b. Radio transceivers, antennas, coaxial or fiber-optic cable, regular and back-up power supplies, antenna cable combiners, network interface device, surge suppressors, and comparable equipment regardless of technological configuration; and c. Pole-mounted shroud or enclosure, pole-top antenna and mounting hardware. The term does not include: a. The structure or improvements on, under or within which the SWF is located; b. Coaxial or fiber optic cable that is between wireless support structures or poles or that is otherwise not immediately adjacent to or directly associated with a particular antenna; c. Other wireless attachments permitted, but not included in the calculation of the SWF equipment volume include wi-fi radios, surveillance cameras, modems, routers, switches, sensors, beacons and other internet-based devices. Wireless infrastructure provider ("WIP") means any person, including a person authorized to provide wireless communication services within the state, that builds or installs or proposes to build or install wireless facilities, wireless support structures, or communications transmissions facilities in support of wireless facilities. Wireless services means any services provided through the use of small wireless facilities or other wireless technologies, whether on a licensed or an unlicensed spectrum or whether at a fixed or mobile location. Wireless support structure means an existing or proposed free-standing structure, other than a pole, capable of supporting wireless attachments. (Ord. No. 19-01, § 1, 1-14-2019) Sec. 19-101. - Permit required; application process. (a) The placement of a SWF in the right-of-way without first filing an application and obtaining a permit, as provided in this article, is prohibited. (b) The application must be made by the WIP or its duly-authorized agent as demonstrated in a notarized statement from a representative of the WIP with the authority to make such an authorization. (c) An applicant seeking to construct, modify or replace a network of small wireless facilities may, at the applicant's discretion, file a consolidated application for up to five (5) small wireless facilities and receive a single permit for such multiple small wireless facilities, unless permission is obtained in advance from the department to include more than five (5) small wireless facilities in an application. But, the denial of a permit for one (1) or more small wireless facilities in a consolidated application must not delay processing of any other small wireless facilities in the same consolidated application. (d) The applicant must submit its permit application to the department located at 2776 Highway 27 - Bypass, LaFayette, Georgia 30728. (e) The application must the following information: (1) The applicant's name, address, telephone number and email address; (2) The names, addresses, telephone numbers, and email addresses of all consultants, if any, acting on behalf of the applicant with respect to filing the application; (3) A general description of the work to be performed and the purposes and intent of the SWF, wireless attachments, ancillary equipment, pole, wireless support structure, or any other structures or equipment to be installed. The scope and detail of such description must be appropriate to the nature and character of the work to be performed, with special emphasis on those matters including, but not limited to, sub-service utilities, likely to be affected or impacted by the proposed work; (4) Authorization for any consultant acting on behalf of the applicant to speak with the city, or a designee of the city; (5) A specific description of the proposed installation, including the wireless attachments pole, wireless facilities, and any other structures or equipment to be installed. Applicant must provide construction plans certified by an appropriate professional, which must state that the installation is safe and consistent with sound engineering practices. The city reserves the right to determine whether the certification submitted is appropriate, and may require a certification by a professional engineer or architect licensed by the State of Georgia. (6) In the case of any installation involving attachment of small wireless facilities to a structure owned by a third party, the applicant must submit a statement that the applicant has an attachment agreement or other authorization allowing the placement of the SWF on the structure. The city may require the applicant to provide additional information, including an attachment agreement or other document demonstrating the applicant's legal right to place the facility on the structure. Any permit issued under this article is effective and conditioned upon the applicant's demonstration of compliance with this subsection. (f) In addition to the information required in subsection (e), the following must also be included with all permit applications: (1) A check made payable to the city for the fee for all actual, direct, and reasonable costs incurred by the city related to processing the application in the amount of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) each application for up to five (5) identical or similar small wireless facilities addressed in the application and one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each additional application for similar small wireless facilities. (2) Photo simulations, which illustrate "before" and "after" conditions as they relate to installation of the SWF. Photos should be taken from all adjoining public streets and, when adjacent to residential properties, from the vantage point where the SWF and wireless attachments will be visible. (3) Elevation drawings of the SWF, including wireless attachments, ancillary equipment, pole or wireless support structure or both, if applicable. The drawings must indicate the height, appearance, color, and material proposed for the SWF and related collocated equipment and ancillary equipment including underground or overhead infrastructure. (4) A site plan, which indicates the location and height of all existing and proposed small wireless facilities, including wireless attachments, collocated equipment and ancillary equipment. Proposals that include collocated equipment, Ancillary equipment or ground based facilities must show all existing and proposed structures, parking, landscaping, and fencing on the site. (5) Verification from an appropriate professional that the SWF complies with all applicable codes of the city including the most current National Electric Safety Code and American National Safety Institute for structural integrity. (6) Any small wireless facilities that require installing, collocating, modifying, or replacing wireless attachments and ancillary equipment to a pole or wireless support structure, or otherwise attaching or using a third party's pole requires, in addition to obtaining a permit, the applicant to submit a statement that the applicant has an attachment agreement or other authorization allowing the placement of the SWF on the pole or other wireless support structure. (g) Following the submission of a permit application, applicants have a continuing obligation to: (1) Provide information updates, including any change in the information contained in a permit application, which must be submitted in writing to the city as an amendment to the permit application within thirty (30) days after the change necessitating the amendment. (2) Applicants are required to coordinate with city officials to protect existing utilities in the public right-of-way and public utility easements, including all public safety considerations prior to and during installation to ensure public safety response in the case of gas line, water line or electricity disturbance. (3) Though a new application is not be required for routine maintenance or repair; where the maintenance or repair would require the removal or replacement of any other wireless or utility providers equipment no work may be performed until authorization is obtained from the entity in compliance with the applicable attachment agreement. (h) Additional considerations. (1) Nothing in this article is intended to supersede or conflict with applications for eligible facilities requests according to the procedures established under article VI of this chapter. (2) Compliance with the State of Georgia's Open Records Act. a. All records received in connection with the application process provided by this section will be handled by the city in accordance with the State of Georgia's Open Records Act, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-70 et seq. b. The applicant may designate portions of its application materials that it reasonably believes contain trade secrets or other proprietary or confidential information "confidential under O.C.G.A. § 50-18-72" by submitting with it an affidavit affirmatively declaring that specific information in the records constitute trade secrets as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 50-18-72. The applicant is solely responsible for clearly identifying and labeling any applicable material as "confidential" or "proprietary" which it asserts is exempt from disclosure under O.C.G.A. § 50-18-72 of the Open Records Act or any other applicable law. But applicants are advised that such designations on any such confidential or propriety material is not binding on the city or determinative of any issue relating to confidentiality or propriety and neither the city nor any of its agents or employees are liable for the disclosure of any information in response to a request for information under the Open Records Act. c. If the city receives a request for public disclosure of all or any portion of any material identified as "confidential" or "proprietary" by an applicant, the city will endeavor to notify applicant of the request in sufficient time to allow applicant to review such request and take whatever action it deems appropriate to protect the material. But, the city must comply with the deadlines for responding in O.C.G.A. § 50-18-71, and the applicant will bear the sole responsibility for the costs and expenses of all such actions seeking to protect the confidential material. Among others, applicant may seek a protective order or other appropriate remedy. If the applicant or the city determines in good faith that the material identified as "confidential" or "proprietary" is not exempt from disclosure under the Open Records Act, then the city will release the requested information unless otherwise ordered by a court of competent jurisdiction. In the absence of a protective or other similar order rendered by a court of competent jurisdiction, the city will make the final determination regarding whether the requested material is to be disclosed or withheld. Applicant is liable for any costs incurred by the city associated with an action seeking to protect any confidential or proprietary material. If costs are incurred the city, the city will notify applicant in writing of the amount due, and applicant will have thirty (30) days from the date of the notice to reimburse the city. (Ord. No. 19-01, § 1, 1-14-2019) Sec. 19-102. - Application review and approval process. (a) Application review process. (1) Applications for permits under this article are subject to initial review by the city's department and final approval by the city manager or his or her designee. Upon final approval by the city manager or his or her designee, the department will issue a permit on the nondiscriminatory terms and conditions provided by this article. (2) Upon receipt of an applicant's permit application, the department, will initially review the application to ensure conformity with this article and other applicable regulations, and subject to the following requirements: a. Within fifteen (15) days of receiving an application, the city must determine and notify the applicant: i. Whether the application is complete. ii. If the application is incomplete, what specific information is missing. (3) The city manager or his or her designee must make the final decision to approve or deny the application within forty-five (45) days of the submission of a completed application. (4) The city must notify the applicant in writing of its final decision and, if the application is denied, the city must specify the basis for denial and, where applicable, cite to the specific provisions of this article or to the applicable federal, state, or local codes upon which the denial is based. (5) If an application is denied, the applicant may cure any deficiencies identified by the city if curable within thirty (30) days of the denial without paying an additional application fee. The city must approve or deny the revised application within thirty (30) days of receipt of the amended application. (b) Appeals of denied applications. (1) Any applicant who wishes to appeal the denial or revocation of a permit must submit a notice of appeal in writing by certified mail to the city manager within ten (10) days of the date the city issued the written notice of denial. (2) The notice of appeal must be addressed to the city's council and must specify the subject matter of the appeal, the date of any original and amended application or requests, the date of the adverse decision, the basis of the appeal, the action requested of the council, and the name and address of the applicant. (3) The city manager must place the appeal on the agenda of the next regular council meeting occurring not less than five (5) nor more than forty-five (45) days after receipt of the application for council action. (4) At the time and date set by the city clerk for the appeal, the council will receive all relevant testimony and evidence from the applicant, interested parties, and city staff. The mayor will preside over the appeal hearing and may set appropriate time limits for the presentation of evidence. The mayor and council are not be bound by the traditional rules of evidence in hearings conducted under this chapter and, instead, rules of evidence as applied in an administrative hearing will apply. The council may vote to sustain, over-rule, or modify the action complained of by the appellant. The action of the council is final and any appeal of its decision must be to superior court by writ of certiorari as provided by the LaFayette City Code. (Ord. No. 19-01, § 1, 1-14-2019) Sec. 19-103. - Scope of permit; construction and maintenance requirements. (a) Scope of permit. (1) A permit issued by the city authorizes an applicant to undertake only certain activities in accordance with this article, and does not create a property right or grant any authority whatsoever to the applicant to impinge upon the rights of others who may already have an interest in the rights-of-way. (2) A permit for the placement of small wireless facilities within the city rights-of-way may include a provision reasonably addressing the obligations of the parties if there is a substantial change of law at the federal, state, or local level. (3) The city may, in its sole discretion, review the terms and conditions of any permit issued under this article after five (5) years to determine if the terms and conditions for the use of city's rights-of-way are still in the best interests of the city in accordance with the laws and regulations in effect at the time. If city determines that the terms and conditions of the permit are no longer in the best interest of the city under the terms of this article, the city may revoke the permit or may make changes to the permit as necessary to meet the best interests of the city. (4) Unless construction has actually begun and is diligently pursued to completion at that point, no permit for construction issued under this chapter is valid for a period longer than twelve (12) months unless both the city and the applicant agree to a reasonable extension and all required fees are paid for the term regardless of construction. (b) Construction and maintenance requirements. (1) Small wireless facilities and wireless attachments must be constructed and maintained in a manner that does not interfere with the operation of the department's equipment, the operation of other utility equipment, the general public safety, and traffic flow. If it becomes necessary for a permittee's construction or maintenance activities to disrupt traffic flow, appropriate safety and traffic flow measures must be employed to safeguard against accidents and keep traffic moving in an efficient manner. (2) Upon completion of any construction or maintenance of its small wireless facilities, the WIP must return the surface of the city's right-of-way to its prior condition, including any sidewalks, curbing, paving, landscaping or other improvements in place prior to the construction. WIP must not leave sidewalks in an uneven condition and must use similar materials and construction in its repair of the right-of-way such that the appearance of the improvements is substantially identical to its prior condition. If the right-of-way is not returned to a substantially identical condition after construction or maintenance activities, the city may, in its sole discretion, request the WIP to make the appropriate repairs within five (5) days of receiving notice from the city. If the repairs are not made by the WIP within said time, the city may perform the repairs on its own and require reimbursement of any expenses associated therewith. When such repairs are made by the city, written notice will be sent requesting reimbursement upon completion of the repairs, and WIP will have thirty (30) days from the date of the notice to reimburse the city for the expenses. (3) The city retains the authority to exclude certain days, holidays and special events periods during which the WIP may not perform construction or maintenance activities on its small wireless facilities and must be out of the rights-of-way. The department may also require that WIP and their agents not perform construction or maintenance work during certain times of the day in order to lessen the impact on traffic or otherwise address safety concerns. Such times will be as approved by the city council or the director. Prior to commencing construction or maintenance, permittee or its agent must verify that its planned work does not fall into an excluded time period. (4) Any small wireless facilities or associated construction and maintenance activities must comply with Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (Section 504) (29 U.S.C. § 794) and Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA) (42 U.S.C. §§ 12131—12164). The city is not liable for any small wireless facilities or any actions of the WIP which violate the ADA. If at any time the city determines the right-of-way is not in compliance due to the actions or facilities of WIP, the city may, in its sole discretion, request the WIP to make the appropriate repairs within five (5) days of sending of the notice from the city. If the repairs are not made by the WIP, the city may perform the repairs on its own and require reimbursement of any expenses associated therewith. When repairs are made by the city under this subsection, written notice will be sent requesting reimbursement upon completion of the repairs, and WIP will have thirty (30) days from the date of the notice to reimburse the city for its expenses. (Ord. No. 19-01, § 1, 1-14-2019) Sec. 19-104. - Requirements for the siting of distributed and small cell wireless antennas in the city's rights-of-way. (a) An attachment agreement or other authorization for placement on the pole or wireless support structure is required for siting of all SWFs. Siting of SWFs is subject to the following requirements: (1) For any SWF proposed to be located on any pole other than a city-approved pole, the WIP must replace the existing pole with a city-approved pole unless such replacement is shown to be impractical under the circumstances; the city has the authority to determine whether replacement is impractical, and if that determination is made, the city has the right to require placement of the proposed small wireless facilities in such a manner as to minimize its impacts to the right-of-way, including conditions intended to ensure the safety of its citizens and to protect the aesthetics of the surrounding area. (2) Installations in/on utility poles not located within protected areas are limited to in-line tangent poles without transformers and those classified as secondary service poles. (3) To the greatest extent practical, SWFs must not be perceptible by a person of average height from two hundred fifty (250) feet away; if a dispute arises as to this paragraph, the director will make the final determination as to compliance with this paragraph. (4) SWF installations on all poles must utilize a concealed design, with all cabling being inside a hollow pole or otherwise hidden from view without banding or external conduit or panduit. (5) All radios, network equipment and batteries must be enclosed inside the pole or on the pole inside a concealment device approved by the department. (6) SWFs are not permitted on poles with traffic lights or poles that are identified as sign poles. (7) SWFs are not permitted at signalized intersections of city-owned rights-of-way. (8) SWFs must be designed in a manner that does not endanger public safety or impede traffic flow on roads and sidewalks. (9) Any new poles installed must not leach any volatile organic compounds or toxic materials. (10) Any new poles installed should be constructed in a manner to avoid unsightly rust and corrosion. The finish on the pole should conform to city standards, including selection of color, finish method, such as "baked on" or color that is tightly integrated into the material composition of the pole to prevent color fading or erosion or peeling of paint from the exterior of the pole. (11) SWFs placed on a city-owned pole must not interfere with or block any banners or other attachments owned by the city. The SWF must be aesthetically compatible with the surrounding area through application of camouflage and concealment design techniques. (12) Any new, modified, or replacement pole or wireless support structure installed in the rights-of-way located outside of a protected area must not exceed five (5) feet above the tallest pre-existing poles or wireless support structures within two hundred (200) feet of the proposed new wireless facility, located on the same side of the street and within the same right-of-way, except that no pole may exceed sixty-five (65) feet above ground level (AGL). (13) Any poles located in protected areas or streetscaped corridors, must be consistent in height with the other decorative poles located in the right-of-way. The city will not allow new poles in any protected area without a variance from city council, and any replacement poles must match the height of the existing pole it replaces. (14) SWFs proposed to be located with two hundred fifty (250) feet of another SWF must be collocated with other small wireless facilities or neutrally hosted, unless applicant provides sufficient evidence that coverage and capacity needs cannot be met using collocated or neutrally hosted wireless attachments; any small wireless facilities must be designed and constructed in a manner that allows other competing WIPs and carriers to be collocated on/in the same pole or placed on/in nearby poles. It is the express intent of this chapter that in areas where one (1) WIP has installed SWF, all other providers and carriers are permitted to install SWF in the same area consistent with the Telecommunications Act of 1996, including 47 U.S. Code § 224, and other applicable provisions. If collocation or nearby placement is not feasible in certain rights-of-way, WIPs are prohibited from installing SWF in that area of the right-of-way, and the department has authority to deny or revoke any permits for SWF in that area if it is shown that WIP are being blocked by competing WIP from locating there. As SWF technology continues to develop and smaller and more concealed designs are available, the city may review permits and require that WIP upgrade older SWFs so that more WIP may collocate or decrease the footprint of SWFs in the rights-of-way. (b) Protected areas. (1) The city council may designate certain areas of the city in which utilities have been placed underground, or in which streetscaping, historic preservation, or other considerations require the design and construction of small wireless facilities in a manner that conforms to the existing aesthetic and structural schemes. (2) The protected areas are identified on the protected area maps included with this chapter and adopted concurrently herewith. The city council may update the protected area maps as additional areas within the city are designated as protected areas. The department will maintain a corresponding list of city-approved pole(s) for each protected area identified on the map. (3) SWFs located in protected areas with existing decorative poles must use poles that conform to the height and aesthetics of the existing decorative poles. The department will maintain a list of city-approved poles for each protected area and a list of design specifications for SWF placed in each protected area, including height limits, equipment placement, and concealment requirements. (4) Where SWFs are not prohibited, any poles located in protected areas or streetscaped corridors must be consistent in height with the other decorative poles located in the right-of-way. The city will not allow new poles in any protected area without a variance from city council, and any replacement poles must match the height of the existing pole it replaces. (5) Pole-mounted cabinets approved by the city in protected areas must conform to the design and placement specifications determined by the department for each protected area, but cabinets on the ground are wholly prohibited in protected areas. (6) Where the city has or hereafter decides to relocate utility facilities underground or replace poles with decorative poles, the city will designate such area as a protected area and must attempt to work with the WIP to accommodate placement of SWFs on city-approved poles within that area if the SWFs conform to poles used in the area. Once a new protected area has been designated, WIP, at its expense, must remove the SWFs and may apply for a permit for any new SWF. Once utilities have been moved underground and SWF have been removed pursuant to this subsection WIP may not place SWF and associate equipment back into the right-of-way without a variance from city council. (Ord. No. 19-01, § 1, 1-14-2019) Sec. 19-105. - Attachment to city-owned or utility-owned poles in the city's rights-of-way. (a) A permit issued under this article does not confer any right to attach small wireless facilities, wireless attachments, or ancillary equipment, or to remove or replace any city, utility or privately-owned pole with a SWF without having an attachment agreement or other authorization from the owner of the pole or wireless support structure. The city may cause a permit for wireless attachments to a city-owned structure under this article to be made conditional upon the execution of a finalized attachment agreement. Any removed and replaced pole must conform to city-approved pole.
